SUMMARY:
Youâ€™ll learn a lot about your date from how competitive they are and if youâ€™re both terrible, at least youâ€™ll have a laugh.
And if sparks donâ€™t fly between you and your date, at least youâ€™ll have the rest of the day free to enjoy yourself.
It may be better to save a country walk for a second or third date rather than a first.
A post shared by London Coffee shops (@londoncoffeeshops) on Aug 22, 2017 at 2:21am PDTPerhaps the most obvious alternative to a bar is going to a coffee shop for a first date.
This is a great option if you know absolutely nothing about the person youâ€™re meeting and want a safe, unintimidating activity.
TEXT:
Millennials are continuing to turn their backs on booze, so if heading to a bar is your go-to for a first date, it may be time to switch things up.

According to resent research, the typical millennial now consumes just five units of alcohol a week and 42% of us are drinking less than we were three years ago.

Thankfully, there are plenty of ways to get to know a potential love interest that donâ€™t involve waking up with a hangover - you just have to get creative.

With that in mind, here are nine alternative activity ideas for those who are cutting back, have quit booze altogether, or have pledged to Go Sober For October.

1. Try crazy golf.

A post shared by Swingers - the crazy golf club (@swingersldn) on Sep 7, 2017 at 10:03am PDT

Crazy golf is no longer reserved for tacky seaside holidays, with a number of new indoor venues popping up over the country, perfect for a post-work putt.

Many venues, such as Londonâ€™s Swingers (pictured above), do serve alcohol, but if you appoint yourself as score-keeper you have the perfect excuse not to drink.

Better yet, youâ€™ll have plenty to talk about as you navigate the course.

2. Visit a museum.

A post shared by Natural History Museum (@natural_history_museum) on Jul 31, 2017 at 7:05am PDT

Museums and galleries are perfect for dates on a budget thanks to the free entry at most. Many venues also run â€œafter hoursâ€ nights that are catered towards adults, meaning you wonâ€™t have to dodge school children while chatting with your date.

For example, the Natural History Museum runs â€œlateâ€ nights every last Friday of the month with different themes, while more than 150 galleries in east London stay open late the first Thursday of every month. While alcohol is available, getting plastered and knocking over some artwork is not advised.

Check the opening hours at your favourite museum or gallery for details.

3. Get your bowling shoes on.

A post shared by Jade PittsğŸ€ (@jadelouisepitts) on Sep 15, 2017 at 9:16am PDT

Thereâ€™s nothing like clown shoes and the smell of feet to get you in the romantic spirit.

Jokes aside, once you get over the footwear a night at a bowling alley makes a pretty good date, and there are venues open nationwide.

Youâ€™ll learn a lot about your date from how competitive they are and if youâ€™re both terrible, at least youâ€™ll have a laugh.

4. Potter around a market.

A post shared by Bath Christmas Market (@bathchristmasmarket) on Dec 14, 2016 at 3:34am PST

Grab your coat and head to your nearest market with your date for a day out thatâ€™ll provide you with plenty of talking points.

As the cold weather draws, in why not visit one of the UKâ€™s popular winter markets? For example, Bath Christmas Market (pictured above) opens from 23 November - 10 December and is guaranteed to leave you feeling warm and fuzzy inside.

If itâ€™s far too early for you to even think about Christmas, try a food market or flower market such as Londonâ€™s Columbia Road Flower Market instead.

5. Grab a spot of brunch.

A post shared by Lauren Morgan (@laurenmorgannnnn) on Sep 17, 2017 at 4:53am PDT

Brunch does not have to come in the bottomless variety and is just as good with a refreshing smoothie as it is with a glass of Prosecco.

Thanks to the nationâ€™s ever-growing love of avocados there is no shortage of stylish brunch venues around the UK.

And if sparks donâ€™t fly between you and your date, at least youâ€™ll have the rest of the day free to enjoy yourself.

6. Attempt ice skating.

A post shared by L I V E F A S TğŸ¤™ğŸ½ (@_skinnyviera) on Jan 16, 2017 at 12:05pm PST

Ice skating is a no-drink kind of activity. After all, most of us spend the first half hour clinging onto the side for safety.

Slipping and sliding across the floor is also a great way to break the ice (pun intended) with your date.

If all goes to plan, you can heat things up by grabbing a hot chocolate afterwards. Steamy.

8. Hit up an alcohol-free bar.

A post shared by Redemption Bar (@redemptionbar) on Sep 27, 2017 at 9:08am PDT

In 2015 London venue Redemption became the UKâ€™s first alcohol-free bar and since then others have been cropping up around the country, from Bar Zero in Middlesbrough to Cafe Sobar in Nottingham.

These bars still have a grown-up vibe but are strictly tee-total.

Most also sell healthy food options for daters who are truly embracing the wellness revolution.

7. Embark on a country walk.

A post shared by Aimee Heloise (@aimee_heloise) on Sep 26, 2017 at 7:38am PDT

Head for the hills and channel your inner country bumpkin for a date thatâ€™ll help you save some pennies.

If itâ€™s not too cold out, weâ€™d recommend packing a blanket and some picnic nibbles for the afternoon.

It may be better to save a country walk for a second or third date rather than a first. After all, no one wants to get lost in the middle of nowhere with someone theyâ€™re not into.

9. Chill out in a coffee shop.

A post shared by London Coffee shops (@londoncoffeeshops) on Aug 22, 2017 at 2:21am PDT

Perhaps the most obvious alternative to a bar is going to a coffee shop for a first date.

This is a great option if you know absolutely nothing about the person youâ€™re meeting and want a safe, unintimidating activity.
TITLE: 9 Alcohol-Free Date Ideas If You're Going Sober For October

SUMMARY:
â€œThe Second Amendment is clear that Americans have a right to arm themselves for protection.
Oâ€™Reilly was simply distilling the overarching philosophy of the National Rifle Association, its supporters and the lawmakers who reliably toe the line on their interpretation of gun rights.
The glib resignation of that mindset is the final rhetorical stage of a revolution launched a half century ago by gun rights advocates.
President Barack Obama was addressing that acquiescence in 2016, when he gave a speech unveiling new gun control measures in the wake of a mass shooting in San Bernardino, California.
Oâ€™Reilly understands the stakes of our acquiescence, which is never more important to the gun rights cause than in the emotional aftermath of massive gun death.
TEXT:
On Monday, with victims of the previous nightâ€™s massacre still dying at Las Vegas-area hospitals, conservative commentator Bill Oâ€™Reilly had a blunt message to a nation in mourning after the latest high-profile mass shooting, this one the deadliest in modern U.S. history. This sort of death and suffering, he said, is a foregone conclusion.

â€œThis is the price of freedom,â€ the former Fox News anchor wrote on his website. â€œThe Second Amendment is clear that Americans have a right to arm themselves for protection. Even the loons.â€

For all the talk on the right about the importance of not politicizing the tragedy, Oâ€™Reilly was jumping with both feet into the middle of our raging political debate over gun rights. And he was doing us the favor of being explicit about his argument: In a society that supports a largely absolutist and individualist view of the right to bear arms, we should expect to make ritual sacrifices at the altar of the Second Amendment. This violence isnâ€™t pretty â€• itâ€™s â€œthe big downside of American freedom,â€ wrote Oâ€™Reilly â€• but itâ€™s an unavoidable tradeoff for a nation that wants easy access to weapons.

Oâ€™Reilly was simply distilling the overarching philosophy of the National Rifle Association, its supporters and the lawmakers who reliably toe the line on their interpretation of gun rights.

â€œThis is a frank admission of the gun rights movementâ€™s philosophy, which is that, yes, there will be these harms that come from broad civilian ownership of guns, but you have the right, and the rightâ€™s essential to your freedom, so weâ€™ll just have to live with these consequences,â€ said Adam Winkler, a professor of constitutional law at the UCLA School of Law.

The glib resignation of that mindset is the final rhetorical stage of a revolution launched a half century ago by gun rights advocates. Theyâ€™ve spent hundreds of millions of dollars on political lobbying and campaigns, suppressed and distorted gun violence research, and aggressively pushed the paranoid narrative that the government is coming for Americansâ€™ guns.

Having reshaped the Second Amendment to their ends, all that remained for the NRA and its supporters was to encourage a shrugging acquiescence to the supposed holy writ of our Constitution. President Barack Obama was addressing that acquiescence in 2016, when he gave a speech unveiling new gun control measures in the wake of a mass shooting in San Bernardino, California. He urged Americans not â€œto accept this carnage as the price of freedom.â€

But Americans largely have accepted it, if the failure of Congress to pass any gun control legislation in nearly a decade is any indication.

Oâ€™Reilly understands the stakes of our acquiescence, which is never more important to the gun rights cause than in the emotional aftermath of massive gun death. And in this case, there was little room to obfuscate or deflect. Typically, there is a much longer period of finger pointing and what-ifs after a mass shooting, at least when a gunman claims to be an ISIS sympathizer, or is found to have been mentally ill, or in violation of existing firearms law, or carried out the attack in a gun-free zone, where armed bystanders were not free to return fire.

But Stephen Paddock, the gunman in Las Vegas, had legally purchased a veritable arsenal, including numerous assault-style rifles, and did not set off any alarm bells with law enforcement or mental health professionals before carrying out his murderous plot. No number of good guys with guns could have neutralized the shooter as he indiscriminately sprayed gunfire into a crowd of 22,000 concertgoers from his perch on the 32nd floor of the Mandalay Bay Resort and Casino.

The same particulars behind Oâ€™Reillyâ€™s frankness led others to change their minds. Caleb Keeter, a guitarist who performed with the Josh Abbott Band in Las Vegas hours before the shooting, publicly apologized for his lifelong opposition to gun control in a Twitter post on Monday. He recalled that his colleagues received shrapnel wounds merely because they were standing near other gunshot victims, and suggested civilian weaponry had gotten â€œout of hand.â€

Not Oâ€™Reilly.

â€œYou donâ€™t say human lives are a price youâ€™re willing to pay,â€ said Winkler. â€œWe should always try to reduce the loss of life, not increase it, or objectify it as some cost and not recognize the real human beings who are affected.â€

Geoffrey Stone, a professor of constitutional law at the University of Chicago Law School, said thereâ€™s a broader debate to be had about whether society wants to define â€œfreedomâ€ to mean civilians being largely free to purchase and possess whatever firearms they want in whatever quantity.

â€œIn my view, that is an utterly absurd conception of â€˜freedomâ€™ and has absolutely no basis in our Constitution or our Second Amendment,â€ Stone said in an email. â€œOne might just as well say that one has the â€˜freedomâ€™ to drive as fast as one wants or one has the â€˜freedomâ€™ to rape women or the â€˜freedomâ€™ to hold others as slaves.â€

By taking no action whatsoever in the wake of these increasingly deadly and frequent mass shootings, lawmakers and their constituents have given tacit approval to an arrangement in which death tolls are only limited by a would-be gunmanâ€™s depravity, choice of target, planning and marksmanship. As Sundayâ€™s bloodshed shows, there will always be a more heartless person, with higher-powered weapons, better aim and a more sadistic plot to lay waste to innocent civilians.

Although people like Oâ€™Reilly appear determined to sit back and continue to do nothing in the face of these circumstances, not everyone may be resigned to living in the gun lobbyâ€™s stranglehold. As the euphemisms fall away and the issue clarifies itself into a straightforward matter of largely unfettered gun rights versus lives, the courts perhaps will be freer to tip the balance in the other direction.
TITLE: The Las Vegas Massacre Was A Ritual Sacrifice To The Second Amendment

SUMMARY:
One man was detained after a number of pedestrians were injured in a collision with a car near the cityâ€™s Natural History Museum on Saturday, and London police said they were trying to determine the circumstances.
â€œA vehicle has collided with pedestrians near the Natural History Museum entrance at Exhibition Road,â€ the museum, one of the most popular visitor attractions in the country, said in a statement.
Earlier a spokesman told Reuters it was not being treated as a terrorism-related incident at this stage.
Peter Nicholls/Reuters Police officers stand next to a person with a bandaged ankle near the Natural History Museum in London on Oct. 7.
The same month, a van was driven into worshippers near a mosque in north London which left one man dead.
TEXT:
One man was detained after a number of pedestrians were injured in a collision with a car near the cityâ€™s Natural History Museum on Saturday, and London police said they were trying to determine the circumstances.

British media reported a car had mounted the sidewalk outside the tourist attraction, one of several large museums in that area of South Kensington, west London, and police said a man had been detained at the scene.

â€œA vehicle has collided with pedestrians near the Natural History Museum entrance at Exhibition Road,â€ the museum, one of the most popular visitor attractions in the country, said in a statement.

â€œWe are working with emergency services to assess the incident and we are doing all we can.â€

Police described the incident as a collision. Unverified footage from the scene showed a man being pinned to the ground by four people.

â€œInquiries to establish the circumstances and motive are under way,â€ police said.

A spokeswoman for the London force said counter-terrorism officers were assessing the incident but had not yet reached a conclusion as to the circumstances. Earlier a spokesman told Reuters it was not being treated as a terrorism-related incident at this stage.

Prime Minister Theresa May was being updated, a spokesman said, adding it was usual practice in such circumstances.

London Mayor Sadiq Khan said he was in close contact with the policeâ€™s most senior counter-terrorism officer.

Peter Nicholls/Reuters Police officers stand next to a person with a bandaged ankle near the Natural History Museum in London on Oct. 7.

A Reuters witness said there were large numbers of police, including armed officers, and paramedics at the scene although the atmosphere appeared calm.

A BBC reporter at the scene said she could see a car diagonally across the road surrounded by a crowd of people with one or two on the ground. She said she was told by police injuries sustained were minor.

A spokesman for the museum told Reuters that no one was being allowed into the building and people were being let out through a different exit.

Britain is on its second highest security alert level, meaning an attack by militants is considered highly likely. There have been five attacks described by the authorities as terrorism this year, three involving vehicles.

In March, a man drove a car into pedestrians on Londonâ€™s Westminster Bridge killing four before stabbing a police officer to death in the grounds of parliament.

Three Islamist militants drove into people on London Bridge in June before stabbing people at nearby restaurants and bars, killing eight. The same month, a van was driven into worshippers near a mosque in north London which left one man dead.
TITLE: Several People Injured In Car Incident Near London Museum

Anfang des Jahres tauchte ein 35-seitiges Geheimdossier Ã¼ber angebliche Russland-Verbindungen von Donald Trump auf, das sogenannte Steele-Dokument.
FÃ¼r Furore sorgte aber vor allem eine Anekdote in Steeles Bericht, die dem Dossier den Spitznamen "Urin-Dossier" eintrug - und die jetzt auch Sonderermittler Robert Mueller beschÃ¤ftigt.
Trump und die russischen ProstituiertenSo soll Donald Trump laut Christopher Steele in der PrÃ¤sidentensuite des Moskauer Hotels Ritz Carlton mehreren Prostituierten befohlen haben, auf das Bett zu urinieren.
Auch Vertreter der US-Geheimdienste Ã¤uÃŸerten Zweifel Ã¼ber das Dokument und konnten seine Echtheit nicht bestÃ¤tigen.
Einer dieser Mitarbeiter ist Paul Manafort, Trumps ehemaliger Wahlkampfmanager, dessen Wohnung auf GeheiÃŸ Muellers bereits bei einer Razzia durchsucht und der monatelang vom FBI abgehÃ¶rt wurde.
TEXT:
Im sogenannten Steele-Dossier finden sich die wohl bizarrsten Anschuldigungen gegen Donald Trump in der Russland-AffÃ¤re

Der Anfang des Jahres aufgetauchte Bericht eines britischen Geheimagenten enthÃ¤lt unter anderem Passagen Ã¼ber perverse Sexpraktiken

Das Steele-Dossier galt lange als umstritten - doch nun interessiert sich laut verschiedenen Berichten Sonderermittler Robert Mueller dafÃ¼r

Es geht um Urin. Russisches Urin.

Anfang des Jahres tauchte ein 35-seitiges Geheimdossier Ã¼ber angebliche Russland-Verbindungen von Donald Trump auf, das sogenannte Steele-Dokument.

Es ist nach seinem Verfasser, dem ehemaligem britischen Geheimagenten Christopher Steele, benannt und enthÃ¤lt viele Informationen Ã¼ber Trumps Beziehungen nach Moskau und St. Petersburg.

FÃ¼r Furore sorgte aber vor allem eine Anekdote in Steeles Bericht, die dem Dossier den Spitznamen "Urin-Dossier" eintrug - und die jetzt auch Sonderermittler Robert Mueller beschÃ¤ftigt.

Trump und die russischen Prostituierten

So soll Donald Trump laut Christopher Steele in der PrÃ¤sidentensuite des Moskauer Hotels Ritz Carlton mehreren Prostituierten befohlen haben, auf das Bett zu urinieren. Nicht nur eklig, sondern auch brisant - denn in diesem Bett soll zuvor das Ehepaar Obama geschlafen haben.

â¨ Mehr zum Thema: Sex, LÃ¼gen und ein Videotape? Das mÃ¼sst ihr Ã¼ber Trumps angebliche Porno-EnthÃ¼llungen wissen

Trump verurteile Steeles Anschuldigungen gegen ihn als "Fake News" und "Hexenjagd".

TatsÃ¤chlich ist das Dossier des britischen Agenten Ã¤uÃŸerst umstritten. Es zirkulierte schon Monate vor seiner VerÃ¶ffentlichung in mehreren US-Redaktionen - erst das Nachrichtenportal "Buzzfeed" wagte sich an die VerÃ¶ffentlichung. Auch Vertreter der US-Geheimdienste Ã¤uÃŸerten Zweifel Ã¼ber das Dokument und konnten seine Echtheit nicht bestÃ¤tigen.

Doch nun beschÃ¤ftigt sich laut verschiedenen Medienberichten der als seriÃ¶s und unbestechlich geltende Robert Mueller mit dem Steele-Dossier - und gibt diesem somit eine neue Relevanz.

Muellers Team hat mit Christopher Steele gesprochen

DafÃ¼r spricht vor allem, dass Muellers Ermittlerteam das Dossier wohl nicht nur eingesehen hat, sondern sich auch mit Christopher Steele persÃ¶nlich getroffen haben soll. Das berichten Ã¼bereinstimmend die US-Sender NBC News und CNN.

BREAKING NEWS: NBC News confirms that Mueller's office spoke to Trump Dossier Author #TheBeat https://t.co/PqEFJDMcLF â€” TheBeat w/Ari Melber (@TheBeatWithAri) 5. Oktober 2017

Auch die Nachrichtenagentur Reuters hatte zuvor berichtet, dass das Steele-Dossier offizieller Teil von Muellers Ermittlungen Ã¼ber die mÃ¶glichen Verbindungen von Trumps Team nach Russland sei.

Ermittlungen, die gerade enorm an Fahrt aufnehmen.

Steele-Dossier nur kleiner Teil der Untersuchung in der Russland-AffÃ¤re

Denn Mueller beschÃ¤ftigt sich lÃ¤ngst nicht nur mit dem ominÃ¶sen Steele-Dossier. Vielmehr gehe der Ex-FBI-Chef auf breiter juristischer Front gegen Trump vor, wie der ehemalige Bundesstaatsanwalt Renato Mariotti fÃ¼r das US-Magazin "Politico" schreibt.

Demnach hat Mueller nicht nur zahlreiche Unterlagen des WeiÃŸen Hauses angefordert, sondern auch Finanzdokumente von Trumps Unternehmen. Der Sonderermittler hat zudem mehrere Interviews mit ehemaligen und derzeitigen Mitarbeitern von Donald Trump angefragt.

Einer dieser Mitarbeiter ist Paul Manafort, Trumps ehemaliger Wahlkampfmanager, dessen Wohnung auf GeheiÃŸ Muellers bereits bei einer Razzia durchsucht und der monatelang vom FBI abgehÃ¶rt wurde.

Es fÃ¼hren also viele Spuren von Donald Trump nach Russland - und Robert Mueller folgt ihnen allen. Auch, wenn sie nach russischem Urin riechen sollten.





(ll)
TITLE: Sonderermittler Mueller ist Trump auf den Fersen - und untersucht nun auch das berÃ¼chtigte "Urin-Dossier"

SUMMARY:
At that time, I had no concept of just how expensive having a spinal cord injury could be.
It's quite surreal, especially when I'm walking down a busy street in central London, but it's so peaceful and calming.
It has crossed my mind many times that it would be much easier to just not tell people I have epilepsy.
I imagined myself strong and healthy, and assumed I'd always be able to go for runs and lift heavy weights.
Something Kind Of Beautiful Joseph had his usual early start (05:53 approx) and crawled into bed at the side of me.
TEXT:
Life In A Wheelchair - The Questions You Always Wanted To Ask Naturally as a newly injured child, my thoughts didn't turn to mortgages or whether I would be able to get a job. At that time, I had no concept of just how expensive having a spinal cord injury could be. I had far more pressing concerns such as: Head of Bolt Burdon Kemp's spinal injury department

Why Having A Hearing Loss Is Not All Bad For me, peace and quiet is just one click away - all I need to do is turn off my hearing aids, or take them out, and everything is muted. It's quite surreal, especially when I'm walking down a busy street in central London, but it's so peaceful and calming. Writer, marketer and avid chocolate muncher. Firm believer in replacing fear of the unknown with curiosity.

Yes, I Take Full Responsibility For This Disease I Can't Control... It has crossed my mind many times that it would be much easier to just not tell people I have epilepsy. But there is always that chance of a seizure, and the risk of something going wrong - or someone doing something wrong - is reduced if we all talk about epilepsy a little bit more and encourage people with epilepsy to do more. If I've decided I can take the risk, you can too. Writer with a tongue-testing name. Condensing the world into frantic words.

I'm Not Going To Let MS Stop Me From Exercising - It's What Keeps Me Fighting I spent a lot of time in the gym when I was teenager. Initially it was more of a social thing, but slowly exercise became a way of life for me. I imagined myself strong and healthy, and assumed I'd always be able to go for runs and lift heavy weights. What I never considered at 16 was that I'd soon be diagnosed with a condition that would force me to rethink exercise entirely. Mum to Dante and MS Society supporter

Just A Drag Queen With No Arms It wasn't long before they took me under their wing and I eventually decided I wanted to do drag as well. With their help and support I chose the name Venus Dimilo after the statue with no arms and started the occasional promotion shift handing out flyers. Just a drag queen with no arms...

How To Have A Life And IBS Suffering from an embarrassing condition can be tough thing for anyone to deal with, but shutting loved ones out is not the solution to your worries. I find that talking to people about my condition reduces the stress and anxiety I get because I'm not trying to hide it. Beauty, fashion, travel and lifestyle blogger

Three Ways To Help People With Tinnitus Have A Better Quality Of Life If I was to tell you that one in ten people had a disability which couldn't be physically seen, but that often prevented them from working - how would you feel? Managing Director, The Tinnitus Clinic

People Think It's Extraordinary That I Work - But Disability Doesn't Have To Be A Barrier When I graduated from university in 2015, I was under the illusion that with a good degree and a strong CV due to all the volunteering that I'd done, I would find a job pretty quickly. This couldn't have been further from the truth. supporter Scope and Virgin Mediaâ€™s Work With Me campaign

My Brittle Bone Condition Won't Stop Me Living Life To The Full My name is Samantha Renke and I am a Lancashire-born actress and public speaker who currently lives in east London. I am a former teacher and trustee for the brittle bone society. I have a genetic condition called osteogenesis imperfecta, more commonly known as brittle bones condition which means I am a full-time wheelchair user, but this most certainly doesn't stop me from living life to the full. Actress and disability campaigner

Going On The Undateables Taught Me I Don't Need To Be Terrified Of Dating If I can take anything away from being on the show I would say it has given me the confidence to go out and enjoy dating. Rather than being terrified of it. I don't know what the future holds for Tanya and I, but if nothing else, I've make a new friend. Engineer and The Undateables star, living with brittle bones

Six 'Socially Unacceptable' Things I Do Because Of My Chronic Illness One of the most frustrating things about chronic illness is the unpredictability of it -- I never know how I'm going to feel. Sometimes I can do stuff, sometimes I can't, and it's so bloody confusing. Even after almost 10 years of health stuff, I still haven't figured it out, and I don't think I ever will. writer, cartoonist, health activist

How I Came Out Of The Undateables Wiser And More Confident This journey has made me a stronger and a more confident person, it may not work for everyone with a disability but I felt it worked for me. I think that the show is a credit to someone like myself because it focuses on who the person is rather than how their disability affects them. To anyone with a disability I say this, this show made me confident and wiser, I got to meet someone great and if you think this show could help you to date then I encourage you to apply. The Undateables star, living with high functioning autism and severe dyspraxia

Attitudes Haven't Changed? What A Surprise As a wheelchair user due to chronic pain, I find the self same discrimination within my own social circle. They sometimes make comments about the appearance of a disabled person in the news and make assumptions about them based on their appearance. Hi TopladyTalks here, writer/blogger/wheelchair user who writes about what I see from beneath the 'invisibilty cloak' of my wheelchair!

Something Kind Of Beautiful Joseph had his usual early start (05:53 approx) and crawled into bed at the side of me. As it was still dark, he did his usual trick of feeling my face and putting his fingers at the corners of my mouth to check whether I was smiling; I wasn't. Mum, full-time worker and blogger, winner of the 2017 BAPS SEND Newcomer blog award.

Minority Report: Them And (A Much Smaller) 'Us' If you see me walking down the street, dressed up to the nines to meet my friends for a night out, or on my way to work, you'd be forgiven for assuming I was the epitome of Western privilege, and in many ways I am: educated; employed; financially independent; a homeowner, albeit mortgaged - although otherwise debt-free. Cosmetics boutique manager & writer
TITLE: Everybody

The writer of the 2004 fan favorite stopped by â€œLate Night with Seth Meyersâ€ on Wednesday night and shed some light on her two childrenâ€™s ongoing comedy education.
Bruce Glikas via Getty Images Tina Fey hands out cheese fries at the launch event for the Broadway musical production of her film "Mean Girls."
â€œShe was going back to her preschool being like, â€˜Letâ€™s play â€˜Mean Girls.â€™ Iâ€™m Regina.

TEXT:
Evil might take human form in Regina George, but at least Tina Feyâ€™s 6-year-old daughter sees something aspirational in the on-screen teen queen.

The writer of the 2004 fan favorite stopped by â€œLate Night with Seth Meyersâ€ on Wednesday night and shed some light on her two childrenâ€™s ongoing comedy education. Fey shares daughters Alice and Penelope with husband and composer Jeff Richmond.

While Feyâ€™s older daughter couldnâ€™t get past the opening episodes of â€œ30 Rockâ€ (â€œItâ€™s just too weird to meâ€), her younger child immediately took a liking to â€œMean Girls.â€ Fey brought her children along to rehearsals for the upcoming musical adaptation, which is set to open on Broadway in March 2018.

Bruce Glikas via Getty Images Tina Fey hands out cheese fries at the launch event for the Broadway musical production of her film "Mean Girls."

But instead of internalizing the lessons learned from the perils of popularity-seeking high schoolers, Penelope left with all the wrong takeaways.

â€œShe was going back to her preschool being like, â€˜Letâ€™s play â€˜Mean Girls.â€™ Iâ€™m Regina. I yell at you. Iâ€™m a sassy teenager,â€ Fey told Meyers.

The â€œGreat Newsâ€ star tried to remind her daughter that at the storyâ€™s core thereâ€™s a positive message, but it was already too late.
TITLE: Tina Fey's Daughter Saw 'Mean Girls' And Now Wants To Be Regina George

SUMMARY:
KC is at best, discrimination wrapped in pseudo-love, and at worst, a subtle instrument of social control.
Captain Obvious tells me that the Indian connotation potpourri has no bigger moral component than mera suhaag (my matrimony, a.ka.
So when I say that Karva Chauth (KC), the Hindu Valentine's Day, is nothing but a grim reflection of a dystopian mindset that smacks of chauvinism and reeks of gender bias.
This decision, I suspect, is more to assuage his own culpability than any real faith in the 'fast' at hand.
Most Indian women now actually revel in genuflecting in front of their husbands, elevating this regressive gesture to a moral trait.
TEXT:
ADVERTISEMENT

Here's a scene straight out of a ubiquitous Saas Boohoo K-serial. Or a live telecast from your neighbour's house, or possibly, yours. It is Karva Chauth. The urban Hindu wife draped in servility, a big bindi of enslavement on her forehead, the mehndi of servitude on her palms, a mangal sutra (the mother of all married tokenisms) around her neck, dolls up to fast and pray for her Lord and Master. A pallu on her head completes the look of mental confinement and surrender.

This is a slightly aggressive way of introducing the Big Daddy of all Hindu festivals, you'd say, right? Probably yes.

But I've decided not to succumb to the 'Spiral of Silence,' the mass communication theory which states that minority opinions aren't usually expressed in group settings for fear of social isolation. The fear more pronounced in cases where the issue has a moral component.

KC is at best, discrimination wrapped in pseudo-love, and at worst, a subtle instrument of social control.

Captain Obvious tells me that the Indian connotation potpourri has no bigger moral component than mera suhaag (my matrimony, a.ka. the husband), whisker-trailed, of course, by ghar ka chiraag (the light of the son).

So when I say that Karva Chauth (KC), the Hindu Valentine's Day, is nothing but a grim reflection of a dystopian mindset that smacks of chauvinism and reeks of gender bias. I'm not just ruffling a few moral feathers; I'm committing social harakiri and possibly exposing myself to public lynching by my own extended family.

Thank God, Facebook doesn't have a hate button, because this write-up threatens to cost me my already anorexic friends. Still, encashing my constitutional privilege revalidated three summers ago by tattooing my forefinger, I dare reiterate that KC is at best, discrimination wrapped in pseudo love and at worst, a subtle instrument of social control.

You may spin any number of reconciliatory webs around this blunt starker, give it a veneer of modernity by roping in the poor husband to fast along with the wife, but there's no way you can wish away its inherent misogyny. Because misogyny is not always explicit violence; it is also the pita bread on which the meat sauce of cultural legitimacy is slathered to make it look like a family celebration.

A minuscule number of Indian couples, ridden perhaps by a subconscious guilt for their growing western proclivity, keep a 'conjoined' fast in a brave attempt to inject parity into KC's congenital lop-sidedness. The husband's role here mutates from a smug-as-a-bug-in-the-rug receiver of spousal attention to a grudging 'co-faster' (Chetan Bhagat, are you listening?). This decision, I suspect, is more to assuage his own culpability than any real faith in the 'fast' at hand. The happy involvement seeks to cover a murky inequality.

In any case, whether a man chooses to fast along with his wife or not, the cultural dice remains implicitly loaded in his favour. Heads, he's a magnanimous and caring metrosexual. Tails, he's a virile alpha stud.

What is baffling about KC is that in spite of being a blatant reassertion of traditional gender roles, it enjoys ecstatic patronage by many members of the so-called estrogen brigade. These cause-crusaders are more than happy strutting around with sindoor-smeared partings, flaunting their mehndi-stained palms, jauntily playing passing-the-parcel with traditional thalis.

So what is it about KC that causes even the garden-variety 'feminazis' to kowtow such?

Well, there appear to be more than a couple of elements at play here, the foremost being a neo-traditional sheen bestowed upon the festival through clever packaging by commercial forces.

KC is uber-romantic ( thank you DDLJ ). KC is uber-moralistic (thank you, Ekta Kapoor).

Our TV channels feature pseudo-contemporary ads, with coy brides propounding the virtues of fasting for their husbands, playing an oxymoronic rub-a-dub with progressive ad campaigns espousing gender equality. This contra-positioning ensures that materialism thrives and consumption-industry coffers keep ringing.

What is a few hours of fasting in place of all those goodies? It's good to detox anyway!

A resurgence of KC also has its genesis in the big-fat-wedding syndrome, the driving force, once again, being consumption. Afterall, mega celebrations mean mega bucks!

For the urban woman, KC is fast becoming a win-win. She seems to bask in its celebratory aura, the mushy romance, those brownie points with a beaming ma-in-law, the generous gift from an obliged husband (an equivalent of the modern-day push-present for new moms). What are a few hours of fasting in place of all those goodies? It's good to detox anyway!

A milch cow of sorts for the consumer industry, KC's misogynistic origin is now sadly a forgettable footnote in its CV. In a society that fasts at the drop of a religious hat (Shiva to Shani and Krishna to Navratri), what's one more for a husband, you might ask. The lady's happy, the hubby's happy, so what's your problem dude?

It is no secret that the Indian society starts to instil a feeling of inferiority in its women from a young age.

Yeah really, what is my problem? My problem is that I like to envisage a gender-neutral and proportionate playing field for men and women. A cultural scenario that does not subject one spouse to social discrimination at the hands of the other. A social climate where love need not be expressed through overt rituals (not to be mistaken with voluntary gestures of affection). My problem is that KC makes a religious mascot out of a flesh and blood mortal by placing him on a pedestal reserved for the divine.

Unlike other festivals where devotees beseech a supreme being for blessings, KC demands that the wife genuflect and seek the blessings of her husband (besides the Moon God). This simple ritual creates an utterly expendable divine halo around the 'Y' chromosome. It shows the wife that her place is at the feet of her husband who is the protector of her womanhood and her purity as if she were a piece of 24-carat gold or a glass of aqua-guarded water!

It is no secret that the Indian society starts to instil a feeling of inferiority in its women from a young age. Through superstition. Through discrimination. Through coercion (both overt and covert). Women are conditioned to believe that their abstinence will ensure longevity for their spouse. For centuries, KC has fanned this conditioning.

Most Indian women now actually revel in genuflecting in front of their husbands, elevating this regressive gesture to a moral trait. Those who choose not to kowtow are looked down upon as 'indignant feminists', toxic for the society.

Marriage is a bond of love, equality, companionship and mutual respect. It has no place for patriarchal rituals that create some subtle and some not-so-subtle instruments of social control to oppress women.

Any tradition that urges women to deify men is no less cruel than explicit violence. It's time to scrap this power asymmetry. It's time to shuffle the deck. It is time to deactivate my Facebook account.

The opinions expressed in this post are the personal views of the author. They do not necessarily reflect the views of HuffPost India. Any omissions or errors are the author's and HuffPost India does not assume any liability or responsibility for them.
TITLE: Patriarchy Always Has A Feast On Karva Chauth

SUMMARY:
El desgarro, la ruptura y una EspaÃ±a convertida en la vergÃ¼enza de Europa y en profundo motivo de preocupaciÃ³n de todos sus socios.
El caso es que la consulta independentista no era mÃ¡s que la excusa para la DeclaraciÃ³n Unilateral de Independencia.
Si el Parlament declara unilateralmente la independencia entraremos en una maraÃ±a institucional y en una tensiÃ³n permanente entre gobiernos.
Con todo, y para no dejarse parasitar por el gobierno, ha exigido a Rajoy que abra de inmediato un diÃ¡logo sin exclusiones, que se reÃºna tambiÃ©n con Puigdemont y que busque el acuerdo.
De ahÃ­ su empeÃ±o en que Rajoy incluya a Pablo Iglesias en el diÃ¡logo al que le ha emplazado de inmediato para resolver la crisis catalana.
TEXT:
Â¿Y ahora, quÃ©? Esta vez no hay refrÃ¡n que valga. Tras la tempestad, no se atisba la mÃ¡s mÃ­nima calma. Tampoco liderazgo capaz de solucionar la mayor crisis de Estado de cuantas ha vivido EspaÃ±a en los Ãºltimos 40 aÃ±os. Ni Puigdemont estÃ¡ por la labor ni Rajoy, a la altura.

Pase lo que pase el 1-O serÃ¡ ya para la historia de EspaÃ±a una fecha maldita, y no solo por la desobediencia y la flagrante ilegalidad cometida por el independentismo, tambiÃ©n por la torpe respuesta que el gobierno de Rajoy ha decidido dar al desafÃ­o secesionista: primero esconderse tras la toga de los jueces y, despuÃ©s, tras el material antidisturbios de la policÃ­a. Y todo para seguir no haciendo polÃ­tica.

Â¿El resultado? El desgarro, la ruptura y una EspaÃ±a convertida en la vergÃ¼enza de Europa y en profundo motivo de preocupaciÃ³n de todos sus socios.

Lo que no habÃ­an conseguido durante aÃ±os Mas, Puigdemont, Junqueras y Romeva lo ha logrado solito en 24 horas el Gobierno. Ya tenemos aquÃ­ la internacionalizaciÃ³n del conflicto. Y encima el Parlamento Europeo va a discutir sobre la crisis catalana antes de que lo haga nuestro Congreso.

Eso es lo que ha logrado la derecha espaÃ±ola con su peculiar defensa del Estado de Derecho, ademÃ¡s de reiterar hasta la nÃ¡usea algo obvio, que lo del 1-O no fue un referÃ©ndum, y que el presidente estÃ¡ ahora dispuesto a dialogar con todos.

El independentismo consigue la internacionalizaciÃ³n del conflicto. El gobierno, al borde del abismo.

Â¡A buena hora! De haberlo hecho hace cinco aÃ±os, no estarÃ­amos donde estamos, ante una crisis de Estado de consecuencias incalculables que EspaÃ±a afronta, por cierto, con la clase polÃ­tica mÃ¡s mediocre de cuantas ha dado la democracia y con una situaciÃ³n de debilidad como nunca antes ha tenido un gobierno.

Ahora resulta que el mÃ¡s sensato va a ser el socialista Pedro SÃ¡nchez. Sin su apoyo, Rajoy, al borde del abismo, estÃ¡ condenado a adelantar elecciones. Y cuidado, que ya sabemos que, aunque la crisis catalana ha resucitado al rancio nacionalismo espaÃ±ol al que el PP da cobijo en sus siglas, las urnas en este paÃ­s las carga el diablo. Al fin y al cabo, el independentismo es el principal responsable de los daÃ±os causados, pero el gobierno ha contribuido indiscutiblemente a agrandarlos.

El caso es que la consulta independentista no era mÃ¡s que la excusa para la DeclaraciÃ³n Unilateral de Independencia. Y no serÃ¡ porque no estuviera escrito y anunciado. Solo el PP se negÃ³ rotundamente a verlo, como se negÃ³ tambiÃ©n a aceptar que las costuras de la EspaÃ±a territorial habÃ­an estallado hace mucho tiempo. De aquellos fuegos, estas cenizas.

El presidente catalan, Carles Puigdemont, y otros miembros del gobierno regional marchan con la gente en la Plaza Sant Jaume en apoyo a la protesta iniciada por diferentes grupos independistas para que los ciudadanos se reunieran al anochecer en frente de los Palacios Municipales en toda CataluÃ±a el pasado 2 de octubre.

Y ahora hablan de diÃ¡logo, de acuerdo y de ese pacto que nunca quisieron. Lo que no aclaran, por miedo al demonizado 155 de la ConstituciÃ³n, es cÃ³mo antes de sentarse en una mesa -si es que el independentismo acepta- piensan reestablecer la legalidad en una Comunidad autÃ³noma que ha decidido no respetar el marco general pero tampoco el suyo propio.

CataluÃ±a es hoy una regiÃ³n sin ley , donde la autoridad del Estado ha quedado seriamente daÃ±ada tras las imÃ¡genes del 1-O, y en la que no hay CÃ³digo Penal que pueda arreglar el destrozo causado.

Guste o no, hay una parte de CataluÃ±a que, aun sin declaraciÃ³n de independencia, ya se ha desconectado emocionalmente de EspaÃ±a y asÃ­ seguirÃ¡ durante dÃ©cadas. Y lo que tenemos por delante no es un problema, sino la cronificaciÃ³n de un gravÃ­simo conflicto. Por muchas apelaciones que se hagan al diÃ¡logo, esto no se resuelve ni maÃ±ana, ni pasado, ni en una comisiÃ³n parlamentaria por la que vayan desfilando todo tipo de expertos.

La crisis catalana se debatirÃ¡ antes en Estrasburgo que en el Congreso. SÃ¡nchez garantiza estabilidad pero exige ya diÃ¡logo sin exclusiones.

Si el Parlament declara unilateralmente la independencia entraremos en una maraÃ±a institucional y en una tensiÃ³n permanente entre gobiernos. Y el independentismo -por muy dividido que ande-, despuÃ©s de la implicaciÃ³n social del 1-O no tiene mÃ¡s remedio que seguir hacia adelante y soslayar la inmediata convocatoria de elecciones autonÃ³micas, como reclama el bloque constitucionalista.

La situaciÃ³n es tan crÃ­tica que no extraÃ±arÃ­a que tardÃ¡ramos poco en escuchar llamadas para la constituciÃ³n de un gobierno de gran coaliciÃ³n, un escenario del que el PSOE no quiere ni oir hablar. Una cosa es garantizar la estabilidad institucional, a pesar de no compartir la respuesta policial del gobierno en CataluÃ±a, y otra dejarse embaucar por una derecha tan dada a patrimonializar los Ã©xitos como a socializar los fracasos.

'Podemos' trabaja en una alternativa a la DeclaraciÃ³n Unilateral de Independencia

El PSOE navega estos dÃ­as entre dos aguas: la de la defensa del Estado frente a la ilegalidad y la de la repulsa a las cargas policiales que dejaron un balance de centenares de heridos en CataluÃ±a. Con todo, y para no dejarse parasitar por el gobierno, ha exigido a Rajoy que abra de inmediato un diÃ¡logo sin exclusiones, que se reÃºna tambiÃ©n con Puigdemont y que busque el acuerdo.

Para SÃ¡nchez, se puede y se debe hablar ya con el independentismo, al margen de que haya o no declaraciÃ³n unilateral de independencia. Si Rajoy decide antes restablecer la legalidad y aplicar el 155, no tendrÃ¡ mÃ¡s remedio que apoyarlo. Siempre, eso sÃ­, que se sepa para quÃ© y por cuÃ¡nto tiempo.

Y esto a pesar de que esa desdibujarÃ­a, sin duda, al Pedro SÃ¡nchez que ganÃ³ las primarias. Su apoyo al gobierno le aleja de un Podemos con el que se habÃ­a propuesto reconstruir puentes y al que, sin duda, necesitarÃ¡ en el futuro si quiere llegar a La Moncloa.

De ahÃ­ su empeÃ±o en que Rajoy incluya a Pablo Iglesias en el diÃ¡logo al que le ha emplazado de inmediato para resolver la crisis catalana. El secretario general de los morados trabaja, por su parte, con el independentismo en una alternativa a la DeclaraciÃ³n Unilateral de Independencia. Las conversaciones, se solemnicen o no, son a varias bandas. Y todos estÃ¡n enterados. Los prÃ³ximos dÃ­as son crÃ­ticos, pero decisivos para el futuro de EspaÃ±a.

Este texto fue publicado originalmente en El HuffPost.

TEXT:
â€˜Coronation Streetâ€™ stars past and present gathered to say farewell to Liz Dawn at the starâ€™s funeral on Friday (6 October).

The Vera Duckworth actress was remembered with a service taking place at Salford Cathedral in Manchester, following her death last month at the age of 77.

The likes of Helen Worth, Sally Dyvenor, Jenny McAlpine, Alan Hansall, Bruce Jones, Jack P Shepherd, Kym Marsh and Alison King were all seen arriving at the cathedral prior.

PA Wire/PA Images Liz Dawn's funeral took place on Friday (6 October)

The funeral details were announced by ITV last week so fans could pay their final respects, with many lining the streets outside the cathedral.

A private family committal took place following the Requiem Mass and Holy Communion Service which was conducted by Father Brendan Curley.

Liz Dawn funeral

Liz Dawn funeral

1 of 16 Sally Dynevor and Michael Le Vell arriving at Salford Cathedral for the funeral service of Coronation Street actress Liz Dawn. Share this slide:

PA Wire/PA Images

Her family also requested that donations to both the British Lung Foundation and Breast Cancer Care UK were to be made in her honour.

Prior to her death, Liz had been battling chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), having previously suffered from emphysema, which she was diagnosed with in 2004.

Liz starred as Vera for more than 30 years, until the characterâ€™s death in 2008.

She did return for one memorable scene, playing her characterâ€™s ghost when her on-screen husband, Jack Duckworth, died in 2010.

Liz Dawn 1939-2017
TITLE: Liz Dawn's Funeral Sees 'Coronation Street' Stars Past And Present Gather To Pay Their Respects

TEXT:
Die CSU hat bei der Bundestagswahl das schlechteste Ergebnis seit 1949 erzielt

Daher fordert die Partei nun umso lauter eine VerschÃ¤rfung der FlÃ¼chtlingspolitik

6 Zitate zeigen, wie absurd die Diskussion Ã¼ber die Obergrenze mittlerweile ist

Deutschland braucht eine Regierung - aber die CSU braucht Aufmerksamkeit. Also blockieren die Christsozialen die BemÃ¼hungen von FDP, GrÃ¼nen und CDU bei den Verhandlungen zur GrÃ¼ndung einer Jamaika-Koalition.

Zum Beispiel, indem sie offen die Partnerschaft mit der Schwesterpartei CDU in Frage stellen. Vor allem aber, indem die CSU bei jeder sich bietenden Gelegenheit auf ihre Forderung nach einer Obergrenze fÃ¼r FlÃ¼chtlinge pocht.

Dass FDP, GrÃ¼ne und CDU die Festlegung einer solche BeschrÃ¤nkung fÃ¼r Asylsuchende ablehnen, dass der Vorsitzende des Bundesverfassungsgerichts, Andreas VoÃŸkuhle, sie fÃ¼r unvereinbar mit dem VÃ¶lkerrecht hÃ¤lt - dass Deutschland dafÃ¼r womÃ¶glich sogar aus der Genfer FlÃ¼chtlingskonvention aussteigen mÃ¼sste: Der CSU ist es egal.

Die Lokalpartei will ihren bayerischen Stiefel durchziehen - sie muss es, denn an der Basis rumort, es nach dem schwÃ¤chsten Wahlergebnis seit 1949.

Und so wird die Obergrenzen-Diskussion zum Zwergenaufstand. Hier sind die 6 absurdesten Zitate und Aussagen in der CSU-Posse:

1. Alexander Dobrindt: "Die CSU ist die einzige Volkspartei"

38,8 Prozent der Wahlberechtigten in Bayern haben die CSU bei der Bundestagswahl gewÃ¤hlt. Bundesweit macht das einen Anteil von 6,2 Prozent der abgegebenen Stimmen. Rechnet man diesen Anteil auf die GesamtbevÃ¶lkerung um, haben 4,62 Prozent der Deutschen die bayerischen Christsozialen gewÃ¤hlt - etwas mehr als 3,8 Millionen Menschen.

Die CSU ist also eine Kleinpartei. In ihrem SelbstverstÃ¤ndnis ist dieser Umstand jedoch noch nicht angelangt. Und so sagte Alexander Dobrindt am Freitag dem Magazin "Focus": "Die CSU ist aktuell die einzige Volkspartei. Sie ist modern und in der politischen Struktur der Bundesrepublik unverzichtbar."

Kein Wunder, dass die Partei also glaubt, beim Thema Obergrenze auch bundesweite AnsprÃ¼che stellen zu kÃ¶nnen.

2. Nochmal Dobrindt: "Die Obergrenze hat einen thematischen Unterbau"

Dabei weiÃŸ die Partei, wie unpopulÃ¤r sie sich damit macht. Eine ihrer Taktiken ist deswegen: Die Obergrenze fordern - aber jeden Tag etwas anderes damit zu meinen.

Eigentlich ist die CSU-Definition der FlÃ¼chtlings-Obergrenze klar: Mehr als 200.000 Asylsuchende im Jahr sollen nicht nach Deutschland einreisen dÃ¼rfen. Doch gleich mehrere der bayerischen Lokalpolitiker haben diese Definition zuletzt aufgeweicht.

FederfÃ¼hrend war dabei Verkehrsminister Dobrindt. Der reinterpretierte den Begriff in einem Interview mit der "Augsburger Allgemeinen": "Die Obergrenze hat einen thematischen Unterbau und der heiÃŸt: Fluchtursachen bekÃ¤mpfen, Grenzen schÃ¼tzen, Integration fÃ¶rdern, RÃ¼ckfÃ¼hrungen beschleunigen."

3. Joachim Herrmann: "Es hat in der CSU-FÃ¼hrung nie jemand von einer BeschrÃ¤nkung des Asylrechts gesprochen"

In der FlÃ¼chtlingspolitik ist Bayerns Innenminister Joachim Herrmann ein Mann der harten Phrasen. Er fordert gern einmal hÃ¤rtere Grenzkontrollen, Smartphone-Verbote oder die prÃ¤ventive Gefangennahme und Aussetzung der Unschuldsvermutung fÃ¼r islamistische GefÃ¤hrder.

Auch die Obergrenze fordert Herrmann immer wieder - wenngleich er fortwÃ¤hrend betont, dass in Deutschland das Asylrecht gelte.

So sagte Herrmann der "Rheinischen Post" zuletzt: "Es hat in der CSU-FÃ¼hrung nie jemand von einer BeschrÃ¤nkung des Asylrechts gesprochen."

Das eine Obergrenze genau das zur Folge hÃ¤tte - wen kÃ¼mmert's?

4. Horst Seehofer: "Wir garantieren eine Obergrenze nach der Wahl"

Horst Seehofer schon mal nicht. Der verkÃ¼ndete im vergangenen Dezember vollmundig: "Wir garantieren eine Obergrenze nach der Wahl." Auf die Nachfrage, ob die CSU sonst in die Opposition gehe, sagte Seehofer: "Das haben Sie richtig verstanden."

Im August ruderte der CSU-Chef dann zurÃ¼ck. Die Zeiten im politischen Berlin hÃ¤tten sich geÃ¤ndert - und Ã¼berhaupt, die Zuwanderungszahlen seien ja nun zurÃ¼ckgegangen.

Da war die Obergrenze fÃ¼r Seehofer auf einmal keine Koalitionsbedingung mehr.

Parteikollege Dobrindt scheint das allerdings nicht mitbekommen zu haben. Er bekrÃ¤ftigte erst am Donnerstag, die Obergrenze sei fÃ¼r die CSU "nicht verhandelbar".

5. Angela Merkel: "Mit der CDU wird es eine Obergrenze nicht geben"

Das ist in der Tat ungÃ¼nstig. Denn das gleiche gilt fÃ¼r Bundeskanzlerin Angela Merkel.

Die hatte schon im vergangenen Jahr deutlich gemacht: "Mit der CDU wird es eine Obergrenze nicht geben." Bei ihrem ARD-Sommerinterview im Juli legte Merkel nach: "Zur Obergrenze ist meine Haltung klar: Das heiÃŸt, ich werde sie nicht akzeptieren."

Merkels klare Haltung zeigt, wie unsinnig die stÃ¶rrische Haltung der CSU bei der Obergrenze ist. Die Kanzlerin wird sich nicht von ihrem bayerischen Lokalpartner vorfÃ¼hren lassen. DafÃ¼r mÃ¼sste dieser dann schon tatsÃ¤chlich in die Opposition gehen - und das wÃ¼rde der CSU genauso schaden, wie der CDU.

6. Wolfgang SchÃ¤uble: "Juristen wissen, dass Ã¼berflÃ¼ssige Dinge nicht extra erwÃ¤hnt werden mÃ¼ssen"

Und so war es an Wolfgang SchÃ¤uble, Ende der vergangenen Woche der CSU den Spiegel vorzuhalten.

Der scheidende Finanzminister zeigte sich in einem Interview mit der "Bild am Sonntag" spÃ¼rbar genervt. "Hier wird um einen Begriff ein Scheinstreit gefÃ¼hrt, obwohl es inhaltlich keine wirklichen Differenzen gibt", sagte SchÃ¤uble.

Zwar erklÃ¤rte SchÃ¤uble auch, in der FlÃ¼chtlingspolitik gelte, was der ehemalige BundesprÃ¤sident Joachim Gauck gesagt habe: "Unser Herz ist groÃŸ, unsere MÃ¶glichkeiten sind begrenzt." Auf die Hilfsbereitschaft der Deutschen wÃ¼rden kommende Generationen stolz sein, die Ordnung mÃ¼sse in der BewÃ¤ltigung der FlÃ¼chtlingskrise aber bewahrt werden.

Angesprochen auf die Obergrenze sagte SchÃ¤uble jedoch in Richtung der CSU: "Juristen wissen, dass Ã¼berflÃ¼ssige Dinge nicht extra erwÃ¤hnt werden mÃ¼ssen."

Und ewig grÃ¼ÃŸt die Obergrenze

Doch die CSU tut genau das, aus einem guten Grund.

Denn die bayerischen Konservativen haben fÃ¼r sich schon immer in Anspruch genommen, der Ausdruck des Volkswillens zu sein. Das galt bei der MÃ¼tterrente und der PKW-Maut - und das gilt in der FlÃ¼chtlingspolitik.

Und tatsÃ¤chlich: Laut einer aktuellen Umfrage will eine Mehrheit der Deutschen, dass eine FlÃ¼chtlings-Obergrenze eingefÃ¼hrt wird. 54 Prozent der Befragten sprachen sich dafÃ¼r aus.

Das reicht der CSU als Rechtfertigung. Die EinfÃ¼hrung einer Obergrenze wird dadurch nicht wahrscheinlicher - ebenso wenig wie die Bildung einer Jamaika-Koalition.

Aber die Aufmerksamkeit der Republik, die ist der CSU gewiss. Und das ist schon einmal was, in diesen schwierigen Zeiten fÃ¼r die Konservativen.

(mf)
TITLE: Zwergenaufstand: Die merkwÃ¼rdige Obergrenzen-Posse der CSU in 6 Zitaten

SUMMARY:
LAS VEGAS â€• At least 58 people were killed, plus the gunman, and more than 500 wounded after a gunman unleashed a storm of bullets on an outdoor country music concert in Las Vegas late Sunday.
The Mandalay Bay casino was largely empty Monday afternoon with a heavy security presence throughout the casino floor.
The main casino floor bars, still at low capacity but busier than all other areas of the casino floor, were serving the guests who remained.
President Donald Trump called the shooting an â€œact of pure evilâ€ and said he would travel to Las Vegas on Wednesday.
People fleeing (video from the Mandalay Bay hotel) pic.twitter.com/hs98J5uK6T â€” Eiki Hrafnsson (@EirikurH) October 2, 2017Some of the festivalâ€™s performers tweeted about the incident:Gun shots!!!
TEXT:
Stephen Paddock, 64, opened fire on 22,000 concertgoers from his room at the Mandalay Bay Hotel in Las Vegas around 10 p.m. on Sunday night.



At least 58 people were killed, plus the gunman, and over 500 were injured.



Paddock, who had no serious criminal history, died of an apparent self-inflicted wound. Police could not immediately determine a motive for the attack.

LAS VEGAS â€• At least 58 people were killed, plus the gunman, and more than 500 wounded after a gunman unleashed a storm of bullets on an outdoor country music concert in Las Vegas late Sunday. It was the deadliest mass shooting in modern U.S. history.

Singer Jason Aldean was performing in the final act of the Route 91 Harvest Festival, a massive three-day country music event, when his set was interrupted by rapid gunfire around 10 p.m. Stephen Craig Paddock, 64, was shooting at the approximately 22,000 concertgoers from a room on the 32nd floor of the nearby Mandalay Bay Hotel, police later said.

Hordes of panicked fans rushed to flee the scene, hiding under cars and bleachers to escape the bombardment. SWAT team members stormed the hotel and found Paddock in his room, dead of apparent self-inflicted wound and surrounded by at least 20 firearms, including â€œlong rifles,â€ police said. The windows of his room were smashed open.

Police later found 18 additional firearms, â€œsomeâ€ explosives and several thousand rounds of ammunition at Paddockâ€™s home in Mesquite, Nevada.

Victims, including some in critical condition, were taken to five nearby hospitals. Police said they expected the death count to rise in the coming hours and days.

The Mandalay Bay casino was largely empty Monday afternoon with a heavy security presence throughout the casino floor. Guards blocked exists to the famed Las Vegas Strip. The tense feeling hovering over the main casino floor was offset by friendly staff ready for gamblers to resume their usual activities. The main casino floor bars, still at low capacity but busier than all other areas of the casino floor, were serving the guests who remained. Occasional applause and cheering trickled out of the casino floor, celebrations of those still gambling.

Some staff said the lack of guests in the casino was normal for a Monday afternoon, but others said they saw an unusual number of guests with luggage checking out. Some nearby shops were closed; others remained open for business as usual.

Officials are still investigating the motive behind the attack. Paddock, a white male who was described as the â€œsole aggressor,â€ had no serious criminal record, police said. He lived in a retirement community in Mesquite, Nevada, with a female companion, Marilou Danley, but he had been staying in the Mandalay hotel room since Sept 28. Authorities said that Danley, 62, was not a suspect.

Eric Paddock, the suspectâ€™s brother, said Stephen Paddock was a retired accountant with â€œno religious affiliation, no political affiliation,â€ and no history of mental illness. Family and friends described the suspect an an avid gambler.

â€œWe are completely dumbfounded,â€ Eric Paddock told the Orlando Sentinel. â€œWe canâ€™t understand what happened.â€

The owner of the gun shop that recently sold Paddock a shotgun offered a similar assessment.

â€œHe didnâ€™t set off any of my alarms, anything than I felt like thereâ€™s a problem in any way shape or form with him,â€ he told an ABC affiliate. â€œHe was a normal, everyday guy.â€

David Becker via Getty Images

ISIS on Monday claimed responsibility for the attack through its Amaq News site, but an FBI spokesman said that authorities had found â€œno connection to an international terrorist group.â€

â€œWe donâ€™t understand whatâ€™s happened... but as we move on weâ€™ll learn moreâ€ Nevada Gov. Brian Sandoval (R) said Monday at a press conference. â€œIt was a cowardly despicable act that I am very angry about. There is not much we can do but learn.â€

Ji-Sub Jeong/HuffPost

Witnesses to Sundayâ€™s attack described frantic concertgoers running for their lives as intermittent rounds of bullets rained down on the crowd. Many thought the pops were coming from fireworks.

â€œThe concert was going on and we heard what sounded firecrackers going off,â€ witness Megan Kearny told NBC News. â€œAll of a sudden we heard what sounded like a machine gun and people just started screaming that they were hit and to get down, and about every 20 seconds after that you would hear a round of machine guns, and people just dropping, hundreds of bodies over the ground.â€

Joseph Ostunio told the Las Vegas Review Journal that he and his friends â€œheard shots ring out and we thought they were fireworks so we stayed. And then all of a sudden they just kept coming and coming.â€

Ostunio said he realized something was wrong after Aldean abruptly left the stage.

Justin Leyva, a 22-year-old graphic designer from Riverside, California, was at the concert with his girlfriend, Jenna Newton, and her family when he heard the initial gunfire.

â€œI look back to my girlfriends father who just yells to get down â€• and we did,â€ Leyva said. â€œMy instinct kicked in and I knew I had to get myself as far away from the firing as possible. I grabbed my girlfriend as she was staying down for cover and began throwing chairs out of our path until we finally decided to make a break for it.â€

Aldean and his crew were unharmed, he said in an Instagram post, calling the incident â€œbeyond horrific.â€

VIDEO: Rapid fire from shooter(s) in Las Vegas pic.twitter.com/jgzCTQRUZP â€” Joel Franco (@OfficialJoelF) October 2, 2017

One off-duty police officer was killed and multiple others were injured, including one from the Bakersfield Police Department in Bakersfield, California, authorities said. The Bakersfield officerâ€™s injuries were not life-threatening. Police said that two on-duty police officers were also injured in the shooting, one critically.

President Donald Trump called the shooting an â€œact of pure evilâ€ and said he would travel to Las Vegas on Wednesday.

â€œThis was a day I wish I had never had to see here in my 27 years of law enforcement,â€ Las Vegas Police Department Undersheriff Kevin McMahill said. â€œSeeing that scene was probably the most disturbing thing I have had to see in those 27 years.â€

The shooting was the third attack on a major music event in recent years. Earlier this year, 22 people were killed at an Ariana Grande concert in Manchester in the United Kingdom. And 90 people died in 2015 during a suicide attack at a performance by the Eagles of Death Metal at the Bataclan theatre in Paris.

A post shared by Vincent Sager (@vincestagramen) on Oct 1, 2017 at 10:57pm PDT

Several videos posted online contained what sounded like rapid gunfire:

Footage from someone who said he was at the Mandalay Bay hotel appeared to show people running from the event:

Shooting in Las Vegas. People fleeing (video from the Mandalay Bay hotel) pic.twitter.com/hs98J5uK6T â€” Eiki Hrafnsson (@EirikurH) October 2, 2017

Some of the festivalâ€™s performers tweeted about the incident:

Gun shots!!! Vegas. Pray to god. Love you guys. Love you Pearl. â€” Jake Owen (@jakeowen) October 2, 2017

Active shooter at @Route91Harvest in Vegas. We're safe. Love you guys. â€” Luke Combs (@LukeCombsMusic) October 2, 2017

Mandalay Bay said in a statement that it was â€œgrateful for the immediate actions of our first responders.â€

Our thoughts & prayers are with the victims of last night's tragic events. Weâ€™re grateful for the immediate actions of our first responders. pic.twitter.com/Arf8edj1iZ â€” Mandalay Bay Resort (@MandalayBay) October 2, 2017

CORRECTION: A previous version of this story reported that an Ariana Grande concert in Manchester was attacked last year. That incident occurred in May 2017.
TITLE: Over 50 Dead, Hundreds Wounded In Shooting At Las Vegas Country Music Festival

SUMMARY:
Joanna Lumley has been vegetarian for 45 years, but for the first time on Wednesday night she tried the revolutionary new vegan burger which is said to â€œsizzleâ€ and â€œbleedâ€ like real meat.
Compassion in World Farming Joanna Lumley and Philip Lymbery, CEO of Compassion in World Farming, at the Extinction and Livestock Conference food innovation event.
Yet she admits that the idea of more expensive meat is hard to sell as people want meat that â€œcosts the gutterâ€.
Its creator, Beyond Meat, says the plant-based burger has 20g of protein, is cholesterol free and contains no gluten, soy or GMO ingredients.
Compassion in World Farming Joanna Lumley tells HuffPost UK: 'Weâ€™ve never been taught about it because the farming lobby is so strong and so powerful'.
TEXT:
Joanna Lumley has been vegetarian for 45 years, but for the first time on Wednesday night she tried the revolutionary new vegan burger which is said to â€œsizzleâ€ and â€œbleedâ€ like real meat.

The British actress and model, who is passionate about farm animal welfare and is a patron of Compassion in World Farming, is hopeful that the Beyond Burger will spur more people to ditch meat.

Speaking exclusively to HuffPost UK ahead of sampling the new Beyond Burger, which isnâ€™t yet available in the UK, the 71-year-old says she is confident that plant-based alternatives to meat and fish will â€œcatch onâ€.

â€œThe idea (of not eating meat) panics people. They wonder â€˜how do you get your proteinâ€™, but the truth is that weâ€™ve never been taught about it because the farming lobby is so strong and so powerful, itâ€™s rather like the oil lobby, which manages to bury or stifle any new ideas which is not to do with oil,â€ Lumley says.

Compassion in World Farming Joanna Lumley and Philip Lymbery, CEO of Compassion in World Farming, at the Extinction and Livestock Conference food innovation event.

The food innovation event took place on London on Wednesday night as part of the worldâ€™s first ever conference to explore the impact of livestock production on our planet.

Lumley stresses the importance of working with farmers and calls for meat to be more expensive in order to limit the amount that is being consumed.

Yet she admits that the idea of more expensive meat is hard to sell as people want meat that â€œcosts the gutterâ€.

â€œAnd then thereâ€™s something slightly aggressive about it (peopleâ€™s arguments) â€˜I donâ€™t see why I should go without meatâ€™, â€˜animals are there for usâ€™, Lumley adds.

She stresses the importance of meat alternatives being appetizing.

â€œIf you can lay the breadcrumbs to the cage then you can catch any animals you want. Itâ€™s got to be delicious, so you mustnâ€™t do it to feel virtuous and a slog,â€ Lumley says.

The Beyond Burger, which is backed by Bill Gates and Twitter founder Biz Stone, is the first of its kind to be stocked in the meat section of US supermarkets.

Vegans are hopeful that the burger will soon make its way onto the shelves of Britainâ€™s retailers, although no plans have yet been announced.

Its creator, Beyond Meat, says the plant-based burger has 20g of protein, is cholesterol free and contains no gluten, soy or GMO ingredients. The effect of the burger â€œbleedingâ€ comes from beetroot.

Compassion in World Farming Joanna Lumley tells HuffPost UK: 'Weâ€™ve never been taught about it because the farming lobby is so strong and so powerful'.

Lumley says she is hopeful that people, particularly the younger generation, are starting to embrace a plant-based diet.

â€œOnce itâ€™s in your head that itâ€™s completely normal not to eat meat or fish, thereâ€™s no battle to be fought because the next generation will have expensive meat when they do eat it, they will eat much less of it, and they will be much, much healthier.â€

But Lumley says apathy is the biggest threat to people embracing a diet richer in plant-based alternatives.

â€œThe difficult part to sell about this is to try to say to people to do something good for the planet. 50% of people will do something good for the planet but 50% couldnâ€™t give jack anything, they will continue to chuck stuff out of the window, buy 74 plastic bags a day and throw them away, they will not recycle stuff because they donâ€™t care.
TITLE: Joanna Lumley Backs New Vegan Burger That 'Bleeds' Like Meat
