King Salman had arrived in Moscow for a state visit, exiting his private plane as usual, on the custom-made glittering escalator.
King Salman disembarking a plane in Moscow via his gold escalatorAfter a few seconds of confusion, the 81-year-old gathered his robes around him and nobly opted to finish his journey on foot and unaided.

TEXT:
If youâ€™re going to enter the country via a golden escalator youâ€™re going to turn heads, so youâ€™d better hope there are no embarrassing glitches like the one the King of Saudi Arabia suffered on Thursday.

King Salman had arrived in Moscow for a state visit, exiting his private plane as usual, on the custom-made glittering escalator.

His stately glide began without incident, but saw the monarch grind to an undignified halt halfway down.

King Salman disembarking a plane in Moscow via his gold escalator

After a few seconds of confusion, the 81-year-old gathered his robes around him and nobly opted to finish his journey on foot and unaided.

King Salman, who is worth a reputed $17billion, was in Russia to discuss cooperation on oil production and their differences over Syria and Iran.

In 2015 the Saudi Kingâ€™s 1,000 person entourage caused consternation on the French Riviera by sealing off a beach to ensure his privacy during a three-week holiday.
TITLE: Saudi Arabiaâ€™s King Salman Suffers Indignity Of Golden Escalator Breaking Down

SUMMARY:
Australia lobbied for years to enter the confederation, and to qualify through it for the FIFA World Cup.
We qualified directly for the World Cup in 2010 and 2014 via one of the automatic four spots afforded the continent.
We are also the reigning Asian Cup champions.
This year is the first time the Socceroos have not qualified directly for the FIFA World Cup since admission to Asia.
Despite this year's hiccup, our success in recent years, and the rise in mainstream interest in Australian football, owe virtually everything to our participation in the Asian confederation.
TEXT:
If we want to play in Asia, then maybe we shouldn't argue about the refereeing.

The Socceroos drew 1-1 with Syria overnight, in the first leg of their FIFA World Cup qualifier (which, should they win, will put them through to another two-leg playoff against a Central or North American team).

But there were some serious sour grapes from some of the Socceroos, even though the match result reflected the periods of dominance both teams enjoyed -- us in the first half, Syria late in the second.

Among the loudest to complain was Germany-based striker Robbie Kruse, who said of a dubious penalty which the Syrians were awarded:

"It's never a pen, but you come to expect that in this confederation."

The penalty did indeed look marginal at best.

Robbie Kruse says referee always wanted to give a penalty for Syria despite minimal contact made in the box https://t.co/L6j43QfPbe #WCQ2018 pic.twitter.com/kA1rzi9Gl7 â€” ABC Grandstand (@abcgrandstand) 5 de outubro de 2017

But to say "you come to expect that in this confederation" could be interpreted as a swipe at the standard of either Asian Confederation refereeing, or the (perceived low) standard of football in the regional conference, or both.

Kruse took a second dig at Iranian referee Alireza Faghani who has officiated Socceroos games before, saying:

"You expect that from this referee, we've had him before. I think he wanted to give it as soon as he made contact."

For the record, he also scored a brilliant goal with a lovely deft touch.

Australia leads with Robbie Kruse goal at the 40' | Syria 0-1 Australia pic.twitter.com/PTHsUEoXTC â€” Dinie Syahmi (@DinieSyahmii) 5 de outubro de 2017

Much clumsier were his words after the game and there's no small irony in an Australian player questioning the competence of the refereeing in the Asian Confederation.

Australia lobbied for years to enter the confederation, and to qualify through it for the FIFA World Cup. Previously, we qualified through Oceania, where for years we thrashed Pacific island nations and only had genuine competition against New Zealand, who we almost always beat before facing tougher opposition from elsewhere on the globe in a last stage qualifier.

That's how we came to play, and eventually beat, Uruguay in that famous 2005 John Aloisi moment which sent football fans into raptures and took Australia to the 2006 World Cup in Germany, where we preformed well.

Hypokrusey?

After that 2006 Cup the Socceroos were admitted to Asia. The move paid immediate dividends. We qualified directly for the World Cup in 2010 and 2014 via one of the automatic four spots afforded the continent. We are also the reigning Asian Cup champions.

This year is the first time the Socceroos have not qualified directly for the FIFA World Cup since admission to Asia. Having missed one of the automatic four spots after failing to score heavily enough against Thailand, we are forced to go the long way round.

Despite this year's hiccup, our success in recent years, and the rise in mainstream interest in Australian football, owe virtually everything to our participation in the Asian confederation.

While some fans are arguing Kruse made some valid points, others say it's hypocritical to criticise Asia when things don't go our way.
TITLE: Socceroo Takes Major Swipe At Asian Confederation, Which We Were So Desperate To Join

SUMMARY:
As you're growing up, you're taught to try and reduce the risk of getting sick.
National Cholesterol Month 2017 Having high cholesterol has been associated with increased risk of cardiovascular disease and stroke.
Supporter of Meningitis NowIt's Time For A Cardiovascular Disease Prevention Programme Detecting, treating and preventing these conditions cost the NHS billions of pounds every year.
And the number of people affected by cardiovascular disease is likely to rise with an ageing and growing population.
Records show that the number of hospital visits for cardiovascular disease has reached the highest level for decades.
TEXT:
I Didn't Know What Meningitis Was Until The Day I Almost Died From It After the brain scan, I can vaguely recall crying and thinking that this was the end of my life. I asked my parents to give me a pen and piece of paper, so I could write my will. From the complete lack of energy, it was a challenge to even hold a pen. It took me a long time to write just a few sentences. Supporter of Meningitis Now

I Was Diagnosed With Endometriosis 30 Years After My Mum But We Were Both Let Down By Our Doctors There was a 30 year period in between the time my mum received her diagnosis and I received mine. While there is no doubt that treatment for endometriosis has improved, it doesn't seem that the process leading to diagnosis has, and this is so, so disheartening. Blogs Assistant, HuffPost UK

Living With Trichotillomania; When Hair Pulling Takes Over Your Life I was 15 years old when I first became aware of my hair pulling. It was around the time I first noticed split ends and my immediate reaction was to pull on the hair to get it off my head; at first it was a soothing release and something I wasn't even aware of half the time. Little did I know that that was only the beginning of a journey I'm still taking today. Client of Lucinda Ellery and experiencer of Trichotillomania

We Need To Teach Kids How To Look After Their Mental Health We've never been taught to put our mental health first in the same way we've been taught to look after and listen to our bodies. This is simply ludicrous and irresponsible. As you're growing up, you're taught to try and reduce the risk of getting sick. Twenty-something aspiring writer. Lover of tea, animals and winter.

Bell's Palsy: What Is It And Who Does It Affect? What do Pierce Brosnan, Ayrton Senna, and George Clooney all have in common ... other than their fame? They all at one point suffered from Bell's Palsy - and they aren't the only celebrities to have had it! London Doctors Clinic founder and Senior NHS GP

Life Expectancy And Antibiotic Resistance Life expectancy has increased, but antibiotic resistance could become another contributing factor in how that increase is slowing. To make sure that medical advancements support life expectancy, we need to find new innovative ways of tackling bacterial infections and however difficult, continue to research and develop the next generation of antibiotics to help fight the superbugs that already exist today. Vice President of Antibacterial Discovery for GSK

Gaming For A Good Cause? The number of diagnosed cases of dementia is on the rise, and it is currently estimated that 130 million people will be affected worldwide by 2050. As it stands medical and scientific research can't keep up, which is why a fresh approach to the problem is now a necessity. Game Design Director, GLITCHERS

Self Care For People Who Think Self Care Is Hippy Nonsense I speak from experience. I am a great magnet for stress-related illness. So in order to make sure my ageing body doesn't crumble into a pile of jittering nerve endings I try to look after myself in a very lazy, non-committal way. So here are some things busy people forget to do, which might make you feel less shitty. Most accurately described as a giant dork. Armchair activist, lover of cheeseburgers, writer of things.

National Cholesterol Month 2017 Having high cholesterol has been associated with increased risk of cardiovascular disease and stroke. Thus keeping your cholesterol in check is imperative and implementing healthy practices, like eating a healthy balanced diet and being physically active can help prevent a high cholesterol level. Master of Science in Human Nutrition, Nutritionist & Public Health Advocate

When My Newborn Son Started Laughing I Had No Idea How Serious It Would Be When my son Oscar was about 3 hours old he had started grunting. The Midwifery Care Assistant had come to check on us both to see if he was feeding and I told her he was laughing. She immediately took him from me and pressed the emergency button. Supporter of Meningitis Now

It's Time For A Cardiovascular Disease Prevention Programme Detecting, treating and preventing these conditions cost the NHS billions of pounds every year. And the number of people affected by cardiovascular disease is likely to rise with an ageing and growing population. Records show that the number of hospital visits for cardiovascular disease has reached the highest level for decades. Chief Executive, British Heart Foundation and President of the European Heart Network

The Freshers' Week Mayhem Has Settled - Here's How To Thrive At Uni University is probably the first time that you've had to take control of every aspect of your life - from studying and budgeting, to cooking and keeping yourself healthy. It's natural to try to freestyle it and just see how it goes. Education Community Manager for The Student Room, specialising in Clearing and Results Day

My Soul Mate, Secondary Breast Cancer And Me On 12th September 2009, I married my soulmate. Daniel and I had been together since we were 17, a clichÃ©, but we are childhood sweethearts. At the age of 28 we made the formal commitment in front of friends and family to spend the rest of our lives together. Supporter of Breast Cancer Haven

Everyone Should Familiarise Themselves With The Symptoms Of Meningitis I tried to play it down as my children Ellie and Riley were trying to spoil me as it was Mothers' Day but I just couldn't move from my bed. I went to bed early that night and woke at 5am with the worst pain I have ever felt in my head. I instantly knew something was wrong and my husband Dale called for an ambulance. Supporter of Meningitis Now

What Pregnancy Does To Your Body - Inside And Out - And How To Fix It What pregnancy does to your body isn't a secret. It's hard to conceal a swelling stomach, and I can't be the only mum whose breasts leaked in Tescos. My belly expanded, but so did my fingers, and I pulled off my wedding ring a few weeks before birth only to find I couldn't get it back again. London mum, gin addict, perma-knackered, fan of food, coffee & cheese. And my children. Sometimes.
TITLE: Health: the latest news and advice on cancer, heart disease and health issues

TEXT:
AndrÃ©a a la foi. Mais elle Ã©tait bien embÃªtÃ©e lorsque son amie l'a approchÃ©e pour Ãªtre la marraine de son bÃ©bÃ© Ã¢gÃ© de quelques mois. Â«Bien sÃ»rÂ», voulait-elle rÃ©pondre. Mais les choses ne sont pas aussi simples dans son cas. Car AndrÃ©a n'est officiellement une femme que depuis l'an dernier.

AndrÃ©a, qui prÃ©fÃ¨re taire son nom de famille par respect pour la vie privÃ©e de son amie et de l'enfant, a longtemps Ã©tÃ© mal dans sa peau. NÃ©e garÃ§on, la dame de la rÃ©gion de QuÃ©bec a vÃ©cu un long processus de changement avant de se trouver.

Â«Mon histoire est particuliÃ¨re par rapport aux autres. J'avais un handicap physique, c'est peut-Ãªtre pour Ã§a que je me trouvais diffÃ©rente. J'ai grandi avec Ã§aÂ», dit-elle. AnxiÃ©tÃ©, crises de panique et colÃ¨re occupaient une grande place dans sa vie. Â«Je n'ai jamais Ã©tÃ© un homme. Et si j'avais continuÃ© avec mon identitÃ© ancienne....Â» Elle s'arrÃªte. Elle prÃ©fÃ¨re parler de qui elle est vraiment.

Elle a commencÃ© sa transition en 2013, avant de faire son coming out en 2014.

Â«J'ai fait une Ã©valuation psychologique pour avoir le droit de prendre des hormones. On a vu que je n'avais pas une maladie mentale, mais que mon cerveau et mon corps ne vont pas ensemble. J'ai donc dÃ©butÃ© un traitement hormonal en 2015 et Ã§a m'a aidÃ©e. En dÃ©cembre 2015, j'ai fait ma demande de changement de sexe Ã  l'Ã©tat civil. Elle a Ã©tÃ© acceptÃ©e en avril 2016Â», prÃ©cise-t-elle.

ParallÃ¨lement, elle s'est toujours considÃ©rÃ©e comme croyante. Tous ses sacrements de l'initiation chrÃ©tienne ont Ã©tÃ© faits lorsqu'elle Ã©tait plus jeune et elle participait occasionnellement Ã  des activitÃ©s pastorales. Son premier emploi d'Ã©tÃ© fut Ã  l'oratoire Notre-Dame-du-Mont-Saint-Joseph, en GaspÃ©sie.

Â«Beaucoup de transgenres rejettent la foi. Il y a une entente non-Ã©crite entre l'Ã‰glise et les transgenres pour s'exclure mutuellement. L'Ã‰glise nous regarde de haut et les trans disent 'on va aller se faire regarder ailleurs' ! Mais je ne peux pas faire Ã§a. Pour Ãªtre la vraie moi, je ne peux pas me promener avec un bras en moins, le bras Ã©tant la foiÂ», dit-elle.

Mais face Ã  la demande de son amie, elle Ã©tait prise au dÃ©pourvue: l'Ã‰glise lui permettra-t-elle d'Ãªtre marraine ?

De nouvelles questions posÃ©es Ã  l'Ã‰glise

Cette question jadis thÃ©orique frappe de plus en plus Ã  la porte de l'Ã‰glise. Surtout depuis qu'un cas a retenu l'attention en Espagne il y a deux ans. Pris de court par la demande d'un jeune transgenre de 21 ans et par la controverse publique entourant cette affaire, Mgr Rafael Zornoza Boy, Ã©vÃªque du diocÃ¨se de CÃ¡diz et Ceuta, a sollicitÃ© l'avis de la CongrÃ©gation pour la doctrine de la foi. La rÃ©ponse Ã©tait sans Ã©quivoque: Â«impossibleÂ».

Pour la congrÃ©gation, adopter un Â«comportementÂ» transgenre dÃ©note Â«publiquementÂ» une Â«attitude opposÃ©e Ã  l'exigence morale de rÃ©soudre son problÃ¨me d'identitÃ© sexuelle selon la vÃ©ritÃ© de son sexeÂ». Elle jugeait donc que l'un des critÃ¨res pour Ãªtre parrain ou marraine â€“ c'est-Ã -dire avoir une vie conforme Ã  la foi catholique â€“ n'est pas rencontrÃ©. On prÃ©cisait alors qu'il ne s'agit pas d'une Â«discriminationÂ» mais bien de la Â«reconnaissance objective de l'absence des conditions nÃ©cessairesÂ» pour Ãªtre parrain ou marraine.

Au Canada, face Ã  l'Ã©volution des mÅ“urs sexuelles dans la sociÃ©tÃ©, l'Ã‰glise se prÃ©pare Ã  faire face Ã  de telles demandes.

Â«Si on regarde comment la sociÃ©tÃ© civile Ã©volue, Ã§a pourrait venir plus souventÂ», estime Chantal LabrÃ¨che, professeure adjointe Ã  la FacultÃ© de droit canonique de l'UniversitÃ© Saint-Paul et spÃ©cialiste du droit canonique. Pour l'instant, elle note que la plupart des cas qui aboutissent dans les chancelleries diocÃ©saines concernent surtout les cas de futurs parrains ou marraine qui n'ont pas fait leur confirmation.

Elle prÃ©cise que mÃªme si AndrÃ©a est lÃ©galement reconnue comme une femme, la loi ne pourrait pas contraindre l'Ã‰glise Ã  accepter sa demande pour cause de discrimination.

Â«Ce n'est pas un droit d'Ãªtre parrain ou marraine. L'Ã‰glise ne pourrait pas Ãªtre poursuivie au niveau civil pour un tel refusÂ», explique-t-elle.

Dans le cas d'AndrÃ©a, les sacrements de l'initiation â€“ baptÃªme, confirmation, premiÃ¨re communion â€“ ont tous Ã©tÃ© faits. Mais mÃªme si elle se faisait discrÃ¨te sur son changement de genre, elle ne pourrait pas aller signer sur la ligne Â«parrainÂ»: elle se mettrait en situation de parjure par rapport Ã  l'Ã©tat civil, oÃ¹ elle n'a plus le droit de s'identifier comme un homme. Ce serait de toute maniÃ¨re Â«loin de l'esprit du droit canoniqueÂ» qu'une paroisse propose un tel procÃ©dÃ© pour trancher la question, prÃ©cise la professeure LabrÃ¨che.

Des critÃ¨res Ã  respecter

De son cÃ´tÃ©, l'abbÃ© Francesco Giordano, vice-chancelier pour le diocÃ¨se de MontrÃ©al, croit que les critÃ¨res pour devenir parrain ou marraine sont assez bien dÃ©finis dans l'Ã‰glise.

Â«Dans ce cas particulier, on peut facilement passer Ã  travers la checklist: Ãªtre baptisÃ©, avoir vÃ©cu les sacrements d'initiation et avoir 16 ans. Mais avec le dernier item sur la liste, on peut s'enfarger: est-ce qu'elle vit sa foi de faÃ§on conforme Ã  l'Ã‰glise?Â», dit-il.

On a le credo, des enseignements qui touchent la vie morale, les disciplines. Alors, il y a des critÃ¨res plus spÃ©cifiques Ã  considÃ©rerÂ», explique l'expert en droit canonique.

Â«Pour une personne transgenre, cela pose problÃ¨me car il y a une incohÃ©rence entre la biologie et l'identification de soi-mÃªme. Une personne qui est tÃ©moin de sa foi, ce n'est pas juste subjectif: 'je me sens comme'Â», poursuit-il.

Â«Cela dit, si un transgenre est capable de vivre sa foi et continue malgrÃ© tout Ã  assumer son identitÃ© sexuelle biologique, elle peut rÃ©pondre aux critÃ¨res pour devenir parrain ou marraine. On reconnait que des personnes portent des souffrances, vivent des situations difficilesÂ», assure le vice-chancelier.

Dans sa pratique de canoniste, l'abbÃ© Giordano n'a pas encore eu de dossier concret Ã  gÃ©rer sur cette question. Il affirme faire confiance aux paroisses pour que les critÃ¨res de l'Ã‰glise soient bien respectÃ©s.

Â«Ã‡a va nous Ãªtre demandÃ©. Qu'est-ce qu'on fait Ã  ce moment-lÃ ?Â» Yves CÃ´tÃ©, agent de pastorale

Ã€ la paroisse Saint-Pierre-ApÃ´tre, dans le village gai de MontrÃ©al, l'agent de pastorale Yves CÃ´tÃ© a accompagnÃ© l'hiver dernier une personne transgenre qui avait Ã©tÃ© approchÃ©e pour Ãªtre parrain. Le baptÃªme, qui devait se dÃ©rouler Ã  Brossard, n'a finalement jamais eu lieu et la question est restÃ©e en suspens.

Â«Je crois que la question va Ã©merger davantage au cours des prochaines annÃ©esÂ», dit M. CÃ´tÃ©. Â«Il faut se prÃ©parer. J'en parlais rÃ©cemment Ã  mon curÃ©. Ã‡a va nous Ãªtre demandÃ©. Qu'est-ce qu'on fait Ã  ce moment-lÃ ?Â»

Ã€ ses yeux, l'Ã‰glise devrait pouvoir tenir compte du changement de sexe lorsqu'elle est accompagnÃ©e d'une dÃ©marche auprÃ¨s du gouvernement. Â«Par contre, je sais que l'Ã‰glise est trÃ¨s...Â» Il s'arrÃªte et prend quelques instants pour bien choisir ses mots. Â«C'est un gros bateau difficile de faire tourner de bordÂ», ajoute celui qui cÃ´toie la communautÃ© LGBTQ dans son travail pastoral.

AndrÃ©a reste dÃ©Ã§ue de la position de l'Ã‰glise sur cet enjeu, mais elle croit que la question mÃ©rite d'Ãªtre scrutÃ©e attentivement. Â«Je trouve Ã§a correct que l'Ã‰glise ne tourne pas sur un 10 cennes. Les lois humaines, on peut les changer n'importe quand. Mais au niveau de l'Ã‰glise, c'est une bonne idÃ©e de prendre le temps de rÃ©flÃ©chir.Â»

En attendant, elle continue d'explorer sa foi et met cette question au cÅ“ur de ses priÃ¨res.

Â«Je prie. Mes priÃ¨res sont trÃ¨s personnalisÃ©es. Je demande Ã  Dieu d'Ãªtre aiguillÃ©e. Quels arguments je peux leur amener pour leur dire que je ne suis pas une abomination?Â», demande-t-elle.

Elle invite l'Ã‰glise Ã  lui poser des questions pour voir si elle vit effectivement selon la foi catholique. Â«Je vais rÃ©pondre, et on verra si je suis une bonne personne. Mais parce que je suis transgenre, il n'y a pas de discussion possibleÂ», regrette-t-elle. Â«Mon identitÃ© de genre, c'est ce qui existe au fond de moi. Je ne peux pas arriver Ã  faire abstention de moi-mÃªmeÂ», dit-elle en rÃ©ponse Ã  la proposition d'endurer son sexe biologique.

Â«Certaines personnes s'Ã©loignent de la religion? Oui. Mais parfois, c'est la religion qui les fait fuir.Â»

L'abbÃ© Giordano assure qu'il sera du devoir des chancelleries qui auront Ã  recevoir ces demandes de faire preuve de sensibilitÃ© et de comprÃ©hension.

Â«Ce que je dis aux personnes transgenres, c'est: 'viens nous en parler'. Si vous avez des questions, on sera contents d'y rÃ©pondre. Ce n'est pas facile, c'est une nouveautÃ©. Mais la rÃ©ponse de l'Ã‰glise est assez claire dans le cas des parrains et marraines: il faut Ãªtre prÃªt Ã  assumer une vie catholique. Et ce qui constitue la vie catholique est bien Ã©tabli.Â»

SUMMARY:
Jacob Skarratts and Tania Miller planned to tie the knot in 2018, with their four-year-old daughter Paige over the moon to be a flower girl on the big day.
But tragically, less than two months ago, Paige was diagnosed with incurable brain cancer, dashing her dream of being a flower girl at her parent's wedding.
Faced with the heartbreaking news, Jacob and Tania did something beautiful -- they fast-tracked their wedding plans so Paige's wish could come true.
Tania said Paige, whose cancer cannot be treated, "had such excitement about us getting married".
"Every time we would see people she'd say 'My mummy and daddy are getting married and I'm going to be a flower girl'," Tania told the Gold Coast Bulletin.
TEXT:
Jacob Skarratts and Tania Miller planned to tie the knot in 2018, with their four-year-old daughter Paige over the moon to be a flower girl on the big day.

But tragically, less than two months ago, Paige was diagnosed with incurable brain cancer, dashing her dream of being a flower girl at her parent's wedding.

Faced with the heartbreaking news, Jacob and Tania did something beautiful -- they fast-tracked their wedding plans so Paige's wish could come true.

Tania said Paige, whose cancer cannot be treated, "had such excitement about us getting married".

"Every time we would see people she'd say 'My mummy and daddy are getting married and I'm going to be a flower girl'," Tania told the Gold Coast Bulletin.

"We were planning this big wedding next year that I thought would be perfect but this was beyond perfect."

Thirty close friends and family are said to have attended the wedding at Brisbane's Lady Cilento Children's Hospital, which was organised by Innez Stonnell, Jacob's sister.

"I had people phoning to say what they had done. My sister's best friend is a cake maker. One of the mums from Paige's kindy works for a wedding co-ordinator and organised all the decorations and music," Innez is quoted as saying.

"We pulled the wedding together for $1000 and it was the most magical night ever."

Since the tragic diagnosis, a GoFundMe page has been set up for the family, who have had to take time off work in order to spend time with their daughter.

"I know they are the type of people to do it on their own, but I want them to know that everyone genuinely means it when they have said they will help in anyway they can," the page states.

So far, more than $38,000 has been raised from almost 800 individual supporters.

Ex-NRL star Clinton Toopi is contributing in a unique way, with the former sportsman cutting his hair for the first time in six years in order to raise money for Paige's parents.

Toopi has raised more than $2000 in the past week.
TITLE: Terminally Ill Toddler's Flower Girl Wish Comes True At Mum And Dad's Wedding

Friedrich Engels est nÃ© le 28 novembre 1820 Ã  Barmen dans une famille d'industriels. Son pÃ¨re a fait fortune dans l'industrie du textile. Il doit quitter le lycÃ©e pour raisons de famille. En 1838, tout en travaillant comme commis dans une sociÃ©tÃ© commerciale Ã  BrÃªme, il commence Ã  Ã©tudier profondÃ©ment la philosophie en se rapprochant de Hegel qui prÃ©domine de la philosophie allemande de l'Ã©poque. C'est lÃ  qu'il publie en 1845 Â» La situation de la classe laborieuse en Angleterre. La mÃªme annÃ©e Friedrich Engels contribue au journal franco-allemand Ã©ditÃ© et publiÃ© par Karl Marx. GrÃ¢ce Ã  cette premiÃ¨re rencontre, ils dÃ©couvrent qu'ils partagent les mÃªmes idÃ©es et dÃ©cident de collaborer plus Ã©troitement. AprÃ¨s l'expulsion de Karl Marx Ã  Paris, ils s'installent en Belgique. Jenny, Karl et Friedrich, oÃ¹ la libertÃ© d'expression est plus grande que dans d'autres pays d'Europe. Marx accompagne Friedrich en Angleterre ou il rencontre Marie Burns, une ouvriÃ¨re irlandaise avec laquelle il vivra jusqu'Ã  sa mort. En 1848, Engels et Marx sont expulsÃ©s de Belgique. Ils s'installent Ã  Cologne oÃ¹ ils fondent un nouveau journal La Nouvelle Gazette. Karl Marx et Friedrich Engels ont traversÃ© le temps, parcouru l'Europe, avec leurs Ã©pouses avec la mÃªme dÃ©termination. AprÃ¨s la mort de Karl Marx, en 1883, Friedrich Engels rÃ©unit les brouillons pour assurer la publication posthume des livres II et III du Capital. Il meurt Ã  Londres en 1895, sans enfant.

Ce n'est pas tout Ã  fait le film, mais c'est une belle histoire.

TEXT:
Soll ich mein Baby bei mir im Bett schlafen lassen? Darf ich es schreien lassen, wenn es nachts aufwacht? Bis zu welchem Alter soll ich mein Kind stillen? Und soll es lieber Brei bekommen oder gleich feste Nahrung?

Junge Eltern stellen sich viele Fragen. Ihre grÃ¶ÃŸte Angst ist es, Fehler zu machen. Fehler, die sich womÃ¶glich nie wieder rÃ¼ckgÃ¤ngig machen lassen. Und die Antworten auf ihre Frage finden viele von ihnen in Erziehungsratgebern.

Die Regale mit solchen Publikationen fÃ¼r Eltern in den Buchhandlungen sind daher meterlang.

Doch PÃ¤dagogen sehen den Ratgeber-Boom mit Skepsis. Wenn Eltern sich zu sehr auf diese Literatur fixieren, warnen die Experten, kÃ¶nnen sie ihren Kindern schlimmstenfalls sogar schaden.

Largo hÃ¤lt die meisten Erziehungsratgeber fÃ¼r kontraproduktiv

Der wahrscheinlich bekannteste Kritiker von Erziehungsratgebern ist der Schweizer Kinderarzt Remo Largo. Nur wenige Experten im deutschsprachigen Raum haben sich so intensiv mit dem Thema Kindesentwicklung beschÃ¤ftigt wie er. Sein Buch "Babyjahre" gehÃ¶rt seit fast zwei Jahrzehnten zur Grundausstattung junger Eltern.

Den GroÃŸteil der neuen Erziehungsratgeber hÃ¤lt Largo fÃ¼r kontraproduktiv. "Die meisten dieser BÃ¼cher behandeln nur ein bestimmtes Thema und sind problemorientiert", sagte er der HuffPost.

â¨ Mehr zum Thema: Kinderarzt Remo Largo erklÃ¤rt: Mit diesem Fehler schaden Eltern ihren Kindern

"Was mache ich, wenn mein Baby nicht durchschlÃ¤ft? Was, wenn es den Brei nicht essen will? Ich halte von dieser Art von Ratgeber nicht viel."

Sie seien sehr direktiv geschrieben und versprÃ¤chen, dass es auf das eine Problem auch die eine LÃ¶sung gebe. "Doch DIE LÃ¶sung in dem Sinne gibt es beim Thema Erziehung nicht", sagt er.

"Diese Form von Erziehungsratgebern macht die Eltern hilflos"

Die Folge, so warnt Largo, seien Ratlosigkeit bei den Eltern und Schaden fÃ¼r die Kinder. "Diese Form von Erziehungsratgebern macht die Eltern hilflos - und die Kinder leiden darunter, dass die Eltern ihr Problem nicht lÃ¶sen kÃ¶nnen."

Der Kinderarzt erlÃ¤utert das an einem Beispiel: "Nehmen Sie etwa einen Ratgeber zum Thema SchlafstÃ¶rung. Da wird den Eltern also direktiv gesagt, was sie tun sollen. Doch was ist, wenn diese eine Methode nicht funktioniert? Dann kÃ¶nnen die Eltern ein weiteres Buch kaufen oder sich irgendwann Hilfe bei einem Experten suchen."

â¨ Das kÃ¶nnte euch interessieren: Ein Hirnforscher erklÃ¤rt, was Kinder mehr als alles andere von ihren Eltern brauchen

Dass Ratgeber in vielen FÃ¤llen mehr Negatives ausrichten als sie nÃ¼tzen, kritisieren auch andere Experten. "Viele Eltern, die unsere Beratungsstelle aufsuchen, sind durch die vielen unterschiedlichen Ratgeber verunsichert", sagte Bettina Lamm, Familientherapeutin und Entwicklungspsychologin an der UniversitÃ¤t OsnabrÃ¼ck, der "Rhein Main Presse".

Fehlende praktische Erfahrung verunsichert Eltern

Sie und andere Wissenschaftler beobachten, dass das PhÃ¤nomen vor allem die gebildete, gut situierte Mittelschicht betrifft. "Die FamiliengrÃ¼ndung findet meist Ende 20 oder Anfang 30 statt und oft haben Mutter und Vater dann zum ersten Mal in ihrem Leben ein Baby im Arm", sagte Lamm.

Die fehlende praktische Erfahrung verunsichere die Eltern, der Griff ins BÃ¼cherregal sei eine logische Folge. Das Problem, so warnt sie: Diese Eltern suchten oft nach der einen, allgemeingÃ¼ltigen LÃ¶sung fÃ¼r eine Erziehungsfrage - die nicht existiere, wie auch Largo betont.

Statt nach Patentrezepten zu suchen, sollten Eltern lieber eines tun, rÃ¤t der Kinderarzt: versuchen, das Kind zu verstehen.

"Ich habe Hunderten von Kindern dabei zugesehen, wie sie groÃŸ geworden sind", sagt Largo. Er habe immer versucht, kein Ratgeber zu sein und auch keine zu schreiben.

Jedes Kind entwickelt sich unterschiedlich

"Stattdessen ist es mein Ziel, den Eltern zu erklÃ¤ren, wie ihr Kind tickt und welche BedÃ¼rfnisse es hat. Denn nur wenn die Eltern ihre Kinder verstehen, kÃ¶nnen sie auch ihre Probleme lÃ¶sen."

Die Paar- und Familienberaterin Ursula Keller ist sehr Ã¤hnlicher Ansicht. "Ein guter Erziehungsratgeber berÃ¼cksichtigt, dass Kinder sich unterschiedlich entwickeln", sagte sie dem Onlineportal "familienleben.ch".

"Vorsichtig sollten Eltern immer dann auf einen Erziehungsratgeber reagieren, wenn er versucht, Patentrezepte zu verkaufen. Denn Patentrezepte, die fÃ¼r alle Familien gelten, gibt es nicht."

â¨ Das kÃ¶nnte euch interessieren: Das passiert mit Kindern, die frÃ¼h in die Kita kommen

Sie nennt auÃŸerdem einen weiteren Punkt, der aus Ihrer Sicht gegen die LektÃ¼re vieler Erziehungsratgeber spricht: "Die Ratgeber sind oft sehr unterschiedlich. Auf gleiche Fragen bieten sie unterschiedliche Antworten. Das kann Eltern zusÃ¤tzlich verwirren."

"Die eine LÃ¶sung fÃ¼r die Probleme aller Kinder gibt es nicht"

Entwicklungspsychologin Lamm rÃ¤t verunsicherten Eltern, die zu ihr in die Familientherapie kommen: "Packt die BÃ¼cher weg und vertraut eurem Bauch" - auch wenn sie wisse, dass das nicht einfach sei und meist erst beim zweiten oder gar dritten Kind gelinge, wie sie selbst sagt.

Auch fÃ¼r Kinderarzt Largo ist die Sache klar: "Jedes Kind ist einmalig", sagt er. "Die eine LÃ¶sung fÃ¼r die Probleme aller Kinder gibt es nicht. Wenn Eltern ihr Kind und seine Entwicklung verstehen, brauchen sie all die Erziehungsratgeber nicht."

(sma)
TITLE: Kinderarzt Remo Largo kritisiert Erziehungsratgeber: "Es ist viel wichtiger, das Kind zu verstehen"

Unreine Haut wird oft durch Stress, falscher ErnÃ¤hrung oder hormonelle VerÃ¤nderungen hervorgerufen

Dass Stress, Hormone oder eine falsche ErnÃ¤hrung fÃ¼r unreine Haut verantwortlich sein kÃ¶nnen, ist schon lÃ¤nger bekannt. Spannend ist aber, wie viel eigentlich die Stelle, an der die Pickel auftreten, Ã¼ber deren Ursache aussagt.

â€œDrÃ¼ckt eure Pickel niemals aus. Am besten versucht ihr euer Gesicht so wenig wie mÃ¶glich zu berÃ¼hren. Denn das verschlimmert das Ganze nurâ€.

SUMMARY:
Every time more emojis are released we have to spend less time using actual words, sentences and punctuation to express what we want to say -- praise technology.
Now, thanks to the newest emojis Apple just dropped with the iOS 11.1 update, we can finally let loved ones know that we're going to be wearing a trench coat to go rock climbing with our pet dinosaur.
The set of new emojis includes more smiley faces, some gender-neutral characters (brace yourself for the outrage) and a giraffe, which was sorely missing TBH.
Apple says that there's even more to come in next week's developer and public beta seeds.
What a time!
TEXT:
Every time more emojis are released we have to spend less time using actual words, sentences and punctuation to express what we want to say -- praise technology.

Now, thanks to the newest emojis Apple just dropped with the iOS 11.1 update, we can finally let loved ones know that we're going to be wearing a trench coat to go rock climbing with our pet dinosaur.

The set of new emojis includes more smiley faces, some gender-neutral characters (brace yourself for the outrage) and a giraffe, which was sorely missing TBH.

There's also an orange heart -- completing the rainbow -- as well as a fairy, a mermaid and a curler, which we can imagine everyone around the world was desperate for (no, not a curler for your hair, the thing they use during sport).

Apple says that there's even more to come in next week's developer and public beta seeds. What a time!
TITLE: Apple Just Released A Bunch Of New Emojis

TEXT:
Lisa Bloom, a high-profile attorney and former adviser to Harvey Weinstein, had plans to discredit the women who accused the Hollywood mogul of sexual harassment, according to The New York Times.

In emails obtained by the Times, Bloom suggested to the Weinstein Company board that Weinsteinâ€™s team could do â€œmore and different reportingâ€ in response to the newspaperâ€™s bombshell story, which reported the film executive had settled at least eight sexual harassment claims. Journalist Lauren Sivan added to the allegations on Friday, telling HuffPost Weinstein had once trapped her in a restaurant hallway and masturbated in front of her.

Bloomâ€™s planned strategy, as written in her email, included â€œphotos of several of the accusers in very friendly poses with Harvey after his alleged misconduct,â€ according to the Times.

After the Times published its first report on the allegations against Weinstein, Bloom issued a statement Thursday saying that although Weinstein â€œdenies many of the accusations as patently false,â€ he would not â€œdemean or attackâ€ his accusers.

Bloom told HuffPost in an email that she did not have plans to gather or share photos of his accusers, but she declined to share the full copy of her emails with the board.

â€œThere was no â€˜plan.â€™ I was simply pointing out that there was intense media interest in the story and there would be more to come,â€ Bloom said. â€œThat everyone should take a breath and wait until an investigation got to the bottom of the facts and then make a decision.â€

â€œHard to understand how someone could criticize that approach but the board would not have it until later they decided to do exactly that.â€

I have resigned as an advisor to Harvey Weinstein.

My understanding is that Mr. Weinstein and his board are moving toward an agreement. â€” Lisa Bloom (@LisaBloom) October 7, 2017

Board members Bob Weinstein (Harveyâ€™s brother and company co-founder) and Lance Maerov were reportedly upset with the plan laid out in Bloomâ€™s email. According to the Times, Maerov asked Bloom to step down, saying that a business deal she has with Harvey Weinstein makes her unable to be impartial when giving the film executive legal advice.

Bloom announced earlier Saturday that she was stepping down from her role as Weinsteinâ€™s adviser. Lanny Davis, another one of Weinsteinâ€™s legal advisers, followed suit.

When asked if Maerovâ€™s criticisms played a role in her resignation, Bloom said, â€œThe criticism I had of the board and the board had of me had as much relevance to my resignation decision as what I had for breakfast today.â€

A self-described â€œwomenâ€™s rights advocate,â€ Bloom also said she would be working on completing a â€œcomprehensive reviewâ€ of the Weinstein Companyâ€™s workplace and gender equality policies.

In the wake of its searing report, the Times has called for Weinstein to release his accusers from any nondisclosure agreements he may have with them so they can speak about issues of gender equality.

This story was updated on Saturday at 10:45 pm ET with a comment from Bloom.
TITLE: Attorney Lisa Bloom Planned To Discredit Harvey Weinstein's Accusers: Report

Nun gibt es den nÃ¤chsten Versuch: Wenige Tage vor der erwarteten UnabhÃ¤ngigkeitserklÃ¤rung der nordwestlichen Region hat das spanische Verfassungsgericht die dafÃ¼r vorgesehene Sitzung des katalanischen Parlamentes untersagt.

TEXT:
Streit um UnabhÃ¤ngigkeit spitzt sich zu: Spaniens Verfassungsgericht verbietet Plenarsitzung in Katalonien | dpa

Die spanische Regierung zeigt sich im Katalonienkonflikt hart und versucht alles, um die UnabhÃ¤ngigkeitsbewegung zu stoppen

Nun verbietet das Verfassungsgericht den Separatisten im Regionalparlament zusammenzukommen

Manche warnen schon vor einem BÃ¼rgerkrieg

Die spanische Regierung versucht alles, um die immer schneller rollende UnabhÃ¤ngigkeitsbewegung in Katalonien noch zu stoppen.

Nun gibt es den nÃ¤chsten Versuch: Wenige Tage vor der erwarteten UnabhÃ¤ngigkeitserklÃ¤rung der nordwestlichen Region hat das spanische Verfassungsgericht die dafÃ¼r vorgesehene Sitzung des katalanischen Parlamentes untersagt.

Dies berichteten spanische Medien am Donnerstag unter Berufung auf Justizkreise. Die katalanischen Sozialisten (PSC) - strikte Gegner der Separatisten - hatten Beschwerde gegen die geplante Sitzung eingereicht, weil sie die Verfassung verletzte und die Rechte der Abgeordneten missachte.

Das Regionalparlament wollte am kommenden Montag zusammentreten, um die Konsequenzen aus dem Volksabstimmung zu ziehen, bei der sich die groÃŸe Mehrzahl der Abstimmenden fÃ¼r die UnabhÃ¤ngigkeit von Spanien ausgesprochen hatte. Schon das Referendum war von der Justiz untersagt worden - ohne Konsequenzen.

An der Abstimmung hatten sich 42 Prozent der Stimmberechtigten beteiligt, 90 Prozent stimmten fÃ¼r die UnabhÃ¤ngigkeit. Jedoch waren die Gegner einer Abspaltung der Wahl Ã¼berwiegend ferngeblieben.

â¨ Mehr zum Thema: Der Katalonien-Konflikt gilt als Freiheitskampf - doch er ist vor allem ein Duell rigoroser Nationalisten

Kein Dialog mit der Regionalregierung

Der spanische MinisterprÃ¤sident Mariano Rajoy lehnt jeden Dialog mit der Regionalregierung Kataloniens ab.

In der Nacht zum Donnerstag wies er ein neues GesprÃ¤chsangebot der Separatisten energisch zurÃ¼ck. "Sie haben schon viel Schaden verursacht, ziehen Sie die Drohung einer Abspaltung zurÃ¼ck", hieÃŸ es in einem KommuniquÃ© an die Adresse des katalanischen Regierungschefs Carles Puigdemont.

Puigdemont hatte Madrid zuvor zu Verhandlungen aufgerufen. Er habe bereits viele Vermittlungsangebote erhalten und "es wÃ¤re unverantwortlich", diese nicht anzunehmen, erklÃ¤rte der 54-JÃ¤hrige in einer Fernsehansprache in Barcelona. Gleichzeitig stellte er klar, dass die PlÃ¤ne zur Ausrufung der UnabhÃ¤ngigkeit auf jeden Fall verwirklicht werden sollen.

Spanischen Medien zufolge werde es immer wahrscheinlicher, dass die Regierung versuche, die Regionalregierung zu entmachten und die Kontrolle Ã¼ber die autonome Region zu Ã¼bernehmen.

Oettinger: "BÃ¼rgerkrieg mitten in Europa"

EU-Kommissar GÃ¼nther Oettinger (CDU) warnte derweil vor der Gefahr einer dramatischen Eskalation: "Die Lage ist sehr, sehr besorgniserregend. Da ist ein BÃ¼rgerkrieg vorstellbar, mitten in Europa", sagte er bei einer Podiumsdiskussion in MÃ¼nchen.

"Man kann nur hoffen, dass zwischen Madrid und Barcelona bald ein GesprÃ¤chsfaden aufgenommen wird." Die EU kÃ¶nne sich in den Streit aber nicht aus eigenem Antrieb einmischen. "Eine Moderation durch die EU wÃ¤re nur denkbar, wenn wir gefragt werden, aber nicht ungefragt", betonte Oettinger.

â¨ Mehr zum Thema: Konflikt um Katalonien: Wie eine verfassungswidrige Abstimmung eine politische und soziale Krise auslÃ¶st

(jg)
TITLE: Streit um UnabhÃ¤ngigkeit spitzt sich zu: Nun verbietet Spaniens Verfassungsgericht eine Plenarsitzung in Katalonien

SUMMARY:
Eleven people were injured after a car mounted the pavement and struck pedestrians outside Londonâ€™s Natural History Museum.
â€” Metropolitan Police (@metpoliceuk) October 7, 2017Reports on the ground of a car being driven into people outside the Natural History Museum.
pic.twitter.com/10ePBhqVMF â€” Patrick Greenfield (@pgreenfielduk) October 7, 2017People believed to have been injured after a car ploughed into pedestrians outside London's Natural History Museum.
#BREAKING: First picture of car used to hit pedestrians outside the Natural History Museum pic.twitter.com/NvtViDfOXQ â€” Politics Condensed (@PCondensed) October 7, 2017Police said a man had been detained.
We are working w/ @metpoliceuk and will provide an update when we have more information â€” NaturalHistoryMuseum (@NHM_London) October 7, 2017People were evacuated from the Natural History Museum and the nearby Science Museum.
TEXT:
Eleven people were injured after a car mounted the pavement and struck pedestrians outside Londonâ€™s Natural History Museum.

A huge police presence descended on the scene in Exhibition Road, South Kensington, which is also near the Science Museum and the V&A Museum.

London Ambulance Service said it treated 11 people â€œmostly for leg and head injuriesâ€. Nine of them went to hospital.

We attended an incident at Cromwell Road, South Kensington this afternoon. Our statement is below. pic.twitter.com/yBdANOXuZH â€” London Ambulance (@Ldn_Ambulance) October 7, 2017

After nearly four hours of speculation about the cause - and fears it was terrorism - police said this was not the case.

The incident in #ExhibitionRoad #SouthKensington earlier is not being treated as a terror-related incident. It is a road traffic collision. â€” Metropolitan Police (@metpoliceuk) October 7, 2017

Reports on the ground of a car being driven into people outside the Natural History Museum. All media free to use this video. pic.twitter.com/10ePBhqVMF â€” Patrick Greenfield (@pgreenfielduk) October 7, 2017

People believed to have been injured after a car ploughed into pedestrians outside London's Natural History Museum. pic.twitter.com/cPXBVj5M3H â€” Stephen Brian Lowe (@SBrianLowe) October 7, 2017

Police have blocked off the road right in front of the natural history museum towards south ken station pic.twitter.com/xqtk6Xa6lq â€” Gina Duggan (@ginaduggan) October 7, 2017

Javert Borja, who is on holiday in London from Spain, was in the queue for the Natural History Museum when he noticed â€œat leastâ€ 30 people running past the entrance, including families and children.

â€œPeople were running scared,â€ he said. â€œWe didnâ€™t know what was happening, so we decided to go into the museum to be safer. We tried to keep calm... Museum workers didnâ€™t know anything either.â€

One picture showed a car crashed into two others.

#BREAKING: First picture of car used to hit pedestrians outside the Natural History Museum pic.twitter.com/NvtViDfOXQ â€” Politics Condensed (@PCondensed) October 7, 2017

Police said a man had been detained. They said they were called at 2.21pm to â€œreports of a collisionâ€.

Footage from the scene appeared to show a man being held on the ground by others.

Peter Nicholls / Reuters Police officers stand in the road outside the Natural History Museum

Dylan Martinez / Reuters A police officer stands at a cordoned off area near the museum

Peter Nicholls / Reuters Police officers stand next to a person with a bandaged ankle

A police spokesperson said: â€œWhilst enquiries continue it is believed a car mounted the pavement and collided with a number of pedestrians.

â€œ11 people were found at the scene with varying injuries and nine of them have been taken to hospital, and this includes the man that was detained by police. Their injuries are not believed to be life-threatening or life-changing.

â€œThe man detained by officers is currently under arrest and is in custody at a north London police station.

â€œThe incident is a road traffic investigation and not a terrorist-related incident.

Police tweeted they would release more information later.

The museum said there had been a â€œserious incidentâ€ and said it was working with police.

Thereâ€™s been a serious incident outside the Museum. We are working w/ @metpoliceuk and will provide an update when we have more information â€” NaturalHistoryMuseum (@NHM_London) October 7, 2017

People were evacuated from the Natural History Museum and the nearby Science Museum.

Been evacuated from Science Museum - lots of police. Think there has been an attack â€” Clifford Fleming (@cliffordfleming) October 7, 2017

Clifford Fleming told HuffPost UK he and his friends were evacuated and he saw â€œlots of police with guns and ambulances and a police helicopterâ€.

Tom Smith, who was in South Kensington tube station shortly after the incident, said an alarm told customers to evacuate.

He said between 50 and 60 people ran into the station after the alarm.

â€œPeople were running and screaming and even running down the wrong escalator, so we assumed the worst and ran on the next Piccadilly train,â€ he told HuffPost.

Downing Street said the prime minister was being â€œkept up to date on eventsâ€.

Mayor Sadiq Khan said details were â€œstill emergingâ€ and he was in contact with Assistant Commissioner Mark Rowley, the national head of counter-terrorism policing.

My statement on the incident in South Kensington: https://t.co/uTeo2HabXy pic.twitter.com/sZ0uIHUZHM â€” Mayor of London (@MayorofLondon) October 7, 2017

Jeremy Corbyn tweeted that the reports were â€œvery concerningâ€.
TITLE: Natural History Museum: 11 People Injured After Car Crashes Into Pedestrians

Ãœber Donald Trump, der sich mit seinem Rassismus, seiner Kriegstreiberei und seiner UnfÃ¤higkeit zu Regieren zum unbeliebtesten US-PrÃ¤sidenten der Neuzeit gemacht hat?
Laut ihm gibt es gleich vier GrÃ¼nde, warum Trump sich Hoffnungen auf eine zweite Amtszeit im WeiÃŸen Haus machen kann:Grund 1: Trump braucht keine Mehrheit fÃ¼r den WahlsiegDie Mehrheit der US-Amerikaner hat Donald Trump nicht gewÃ¤hlt.

TEXT:
Die Mehrheit der US-BÃ¼rger denkt, dass Trump ungeeignet ist, dass PrÃ¤sidentenamt auszufÃ¼hren

Doch Doug Sosnik, einer der renommiertesten Politikstrategen des Landes, glaubt: Trump wird wiedergewÃ¤hlt werden

Im Video oben seht ihr, warum zudem ein vorzeitiges Ende von Trumps Amtszeit unwahrscheinlich

Was soll man noch schreiben, Ã¼ber einen Mann, der auf jedem Meter derart aneckt, dass die ganze Welt erzittert? Ãœber Donald Trump, der sich mit seinem Rassismus, seiner Kriegstreiberei und seiner UnfÃ¤higkeit zu Regieren zum unbeliebtesten US-PrÃ¤sidenten der Neuzeit gemacht hat?

Doug Sosnik hat diese Frage in einem Artikel fÃ¼r die "Washington Post" fÃ¼r sich beantwortet: Er schreibt, dass Donald Trump seine Wiederwahl im Jahr 2020 gelingen wird. Obwohl 56 Prozent der US-BÃ¼rger ihn fÃ¼r ungeeignet halten, sein Amt auszufÃ¼hren. Und obwohl Trumps Beliebtheitswerte am Freitag wieder einmal auf ein Rekordtief fielen.

Sosnik war jahrelang Top-Berater des ehemaligen US-PrÃ¤sidenten Bill Clinton. Er ist als Politstratege fÃ¼r die Demokratische Partei in den USA tÃ¤tig.

Laut ihm gibt es gleich vier GrÃ¼nde, warum Trump sich Hoffnungen auf eine zweite Amtszeit im WeiÃŸen Haus machen kann:

Grund 1: Trump braucht keine Mehrheit fÃ¼r den Wahlsieg

Die Mehrheit der US-Amerikaner hat Donald Trump nicht gewÃ¤hlt. Seine Konkurrentin Hillary Clinton hat bei der Wahl drei Millionen Stimmen mehr bekommen als der jetzige US-PrÃ¤sident.

Trump gewann, weil es bei Wahlen in den USA darum geht, mehr WahlmÃ¤nner und -frauen fÃ¼r sich zu gewinnen als der Gegner.

Und das tat Trump. Mit Wahlsiegen in wichtigen Staaten wie Florida, die besonders viele Wahlmandate stellen. Doug Sosnik argumentiert nun: Bei der Wahl im Jahr 2020 kÃ¶nnte Trump auf die gleiche Weise gewinnen. "Trump weiÃŸ, dass die absolute Mehrheit zu gewinnen keine Voraussetzung ist, sondern hÃ¶chstens ein Anspruch", schreibt Sosnik.

TatsÃ¤chlich seien aber zwei der letzten drei PrÃ¤sidenten ohne absolute Mehrheit gewÃ¤hlt worden: George W. Bush - und eben Trump.

Grund 2: Die Politikverdrossenheit in den USA hilft Trump

Das Vertrauen in die Politik ist in den USA schwer beschÃ¤digt. Nicht nur die Demokraten haben damit zu kÃ¤mpfen, sondern auch die Republikaner. Donald Trumps Wahlsieg war Ausdruck dieses Frusts, dieser Wut auf das politische Establishment in Washington.

Sosnik schreibt, dass diese Stimmung im Land die Wahrscheinlichkeit erhÃ¶he, dass 2020 ein dritter, unabhÃ¤ngiger Kandidat sich um den Posten im WeiÃŸen Haus bemÃ¼hen werde. AuÃŸerdem kÃ¶nnten noch weitere Kandidaten vom politischen Rand das Duell von Republikanern und Demokraten stÃ¶ren.

"So ein breites Kandidatenfeld kÃ¶nnte dafÃ¼r sorgen, dass die Anti-Trump-Front aufgespalten wird", schreib Sosnik. "Das wÃ¼rde ihm die Wiederwahl sichern, wenn seine AnhÃ¤nger gleichzeitig weiter zu ihm halten."

Grund 3: Trumps Beliebtheit wird unterschÃ¤tzt

Und danach sieht es aus.

Zwar sehen nur 32 Prozent der US-BÃ¼rger Donald laut einer Umfrage der Nachrichtenagentur AP Donald Trumps PrÃ¤sidentschaft derzeit positiv - doch Sosnik glaubt, dass Erhebungen wie diese Trumps Beliebtheit unterschÃ¤tzen. So wÃ¼rden die Umfragen alle Wahlberechtigten berÃ¼cksichtigen. Und nicht nur diejenigen, die tatsÃ¤chlich als WÃ¤hler registriert und gewillt sind, zur Wahl zu gehen.

Hinzu kommt laut Sosnik: "Viele WÃ¤hler wollen einfach nicht offen zugeben, dass sie Trump gewÃ¤hlt haben und unterstÃ¼tzen."

Grund 4: Der fanatische Kern von Trumps AnhÃ¤ngerschaft

Dem harten Kern von Donald Trumps AnhÃ¤ngerschaft geht das anders. Sie halten eisern und lautstark zu ihrem PrÃ¤sidenten. Egal, was dieser macht. Sosnik erinnert in diesem Zusammenhang daran, dass Trump einmal im Wahlkampf sagte, er kÃ¶nne mitten auf der Fifth Avenue in Manhattan jemanden erschieÃŸen, und seine Fans wÃ¼rden weiter zu ihm halten.

Und noch einer weiteren Gruppe an AnhÃ¤ngern kÃ¶nne der US-PrÃ¤sident sich gewiss sein: "Denen, die ihm weiter die Treue halten, weil sie fest davon Ã¼berzeugt sind, dass er das System in die Luft jagen und echte VerÃ¤nderungen bewirken wird."

Sosniks Fazit: In einem gespaltenem Land wird Trump gewinnen

Ob Trump dies gelingen wird, bleibt hÃ¶chst fraglich. Auf jeden Fall hat der US-PrÃ¤sident mit einer RekordfÃ¼lle an politischen Traditionen in den Vereinigten Staaten gebrochen. Warum sollte er also nicht wiedergewÃ¤hlt werden, obwohl er so unbeliebt ist, wie noch nie ein PrÃ¤sident zuvor?

FÃ¼r Sosnik ist klar, dass Trump dies in einem politisch gespaltenem Land gelingen kann. "Wenn die Demokraten Trump schlagen wollen, mÃ¼ssen sie sich hinter einem Kandidaten vereinen", schreibt der Wahlkampf-Stratege.

Soll heiÃŸen: Einen innerparteilichen Grabenkampf, wie er 2016 zwischen Hillary Clinton und dem Senator Bernie Sanders stattfand, kÃ¶nnen sich die Demokraten bei der nÃ¤chsten Wahl nicht erlauben.

Die Demokraten dÃ¼rfen Trump auf keinen Fall unterschÃ¤tzen, warnt Sosnik. Er schreibt: "Es wÃ¤re ein Fehler zu glauben, Trump kÃ¶nnte 2020 nicht gewinnen. Genau so, wie es ein Fehler war zu glauben, er wÃ¼rde erst gar nicht PrÃ¤sident werden."
TITLE: Renommierter Politik-Analyst: "Donald Trump ist auf dem besten Weg, wiedergewÃ¤hlt zu werden"

ADVERTISEMENTKOCHI -- Malayalam superstar Dileep, arrested for alleged involvement in the kidnapping of an actress, was on Tuesday granted bail by the Kerala High Court.
This is the third time Dileep approached the High Court for bail.
The court order on his bail was brought to Aluva sub-jail, where Dileep has been housed, by his brother.
His fans, including women, began collecting soon after he was granted bail by the Kerala High Court around 2 p.m.
After detailed questioning, police unearthed a conspiracy angle in the abduction and arrested Dileep.
TEXT:
ADVERTISEMENT

KOCHI -- Malayalam superstar Dileep, arrested for alleged involvement in the kidnapping of an actress, was on Tuesday granted bail by the Kerala High Court. The actor later left Aluva sub-jail here to loud cheers from hundreds of his fans.

The bail conditions include surrendering his passport, furnishing a bond of Rs 1 lakh, a pledge to stay away from witnesses in the case and to keep away from the media.

This is the third time Dileep approached the High Court for bail. He had also sought bail earlier twice from the trial court.

The court order on his bail was brought to Aluva sub-jail, where Dileep has been housed, by his brother.

In stark contrast to being hooted by angry crowds who had gathered to see Dileep following his arrest on July 10, on Tuesday hundreds of fans gathered to cheer the star. His fans, including women, began collecting soon after he was granted bail by the Kerala High Court around 2 p.m. They were seen distributing sweets and chanting slogans in his favour.

Dileep was arrested for his alleged involvement in the conspiracy behind the kidnapping of a popular actress in February this year.

Dressed in a white shirt and a fully grown beard, Dileep stood on the running board of the car and waved to his fans, and also stood with folded hands as the car drove away to his home where his mother, actress wife Kavya Madhavan, his daughter and close relatives were waiting to receive him.

The police was present in large numbers in the jail and also at the two homes of the actor near here.

Ernakulam rural Superintendent of Police A.V. George, who was one of the key officials in the probe team, told the media that the charge sheet in the case would be filed soon.

The arguments on the bail plea got over last Friday.

Actor Mahesh, who had been defending Dileep all through, expressed happiness.

"Every time a bail plea was moved, we hoped against hope that he would get bail. Finally, the prayers of his fans have been answered," he said.

The abduction of the popular actress took place in February when she was on way from Thrissur to Kochi.

She was taken around in her vehicle forcefully and allegedly molested for about two hours before being dumped near an actor-director's home.

The key accused -- Pulsar Suni and his accomplices involved in the actual abduction -- were arrested a week later. After detailed questioning, police unearthed a conspiracy angle in the abduction and arrested Dileep.
TITLE: Malayalam Actor Dileep Gets Bail In Kidnapping And Sexual Assault Case

SUMMARY:
Founder at www.mamabuys.co.ukDo You Want To Be More Involved In Your Child's School Life?
But it's not always easy to get the balance right when you are juggling work and other commitments.
Focussed on ensuring that schools have the information they need to support every child in achieving all they are capable of.
Criminal law partner at Kingsley Napley specialising in cases of rape and domestic violenceDear Kids... You're all hilarious, clever, kind, beautiful people and I'm so lucky to have known you.
As you're growing up, you're taught to try and reduce the risk of getting sick.
TEXT:
How We Found A Nursery That We Love, Our Son Included Starting nursery for our first born and only child was anxiety ridden for us, but fortunately both nurseries our son has been to thus far have met our expectations and, most importantly, make him happy. I want to share the issues we considered to help other parents who are in a similar situation. Founder at www.mamabuys.co.uk

Do You Want To Be More Involved In Your Child's School Life? Whether a child has just started school or in their final year, most parents want to know how they can best support their children's education and play their part in the school community. But it's not always easy to get the balance right when you are juggling work and other commitments. Focussed on ensuring that schools have the information they need to support every child in achieving all they are capable of.

My Legal Advice To My Fresher Son As I waved my son off to uni this week, I tried to give him some motherly legal advice (although as it comes from me, I fear he may well ignore it). The advice is drawn from my years of representing other mothers' sons who have been accused of rape or other sexual crimes on campus. Criminal law partner at Kingsley Napley specialising in cases of rape and domestic violence

Dear Kids... You're all hilarious, clever, kind, beautiful people and I'm so lucky to have known you. Life is short and the world we live in isn't what it used to be, but you and Mummy/Mum/The Old Lady are the reasons I was always an optimist. How else could I have carried on supporting Spurs for so long, eh? proud husband of one, dad of three and master of none

I Wish Doctors Had Listened To My Concerns Over My Daughter's Health On the Thursday Demi seemed hot to me, so me and my husband Ian took her to the GP. She did indeed have a temperature but they said it was a viral illness and to keep her as cool as possible. Supporter of Meningitis Now

How Do We Build Our Teenage Girls' Self-Esteem? Beauty and appearance are thorny issues when raising girls. Our girls are vulnerable. All it takes is one throw away comment at the wrong time and their sense of self-worth can become quickly wrapped up in this body image nightmare, which even if they don't come to it until later, is still an issue to be confronted, not trivialised or ignored. PR, writer, mother, blogger : www.motherofteenagers.com

Godzilla Attacks And Other Stay 'N' Play Lessons I'd been watching, with growing horror, as one little boy - at least 6 months older than Sam - wreaked havoc in the vicinity. This child, who seemed to be part human, part concrete - seriously he was built like the proverbial brick lavatory - was roaming among the (much smaller) other kids with a gleefully sadistic look on his face. The Out Of Depth Dad (outofdepthdad.wordpress.com).

Top Tips For Moving To Another Country With A Family You're about to be launched headlong in to a new adventure accompanied by a feeling of trepidation and general anxiety. I've been there and know those feelings only too well, I've recently moved from the UK to Switzerland with my family in tow (change not being my biggest forte, I'm still harking back to a time of Grange Hill and a regular helping of Dynasty). Blogger, Mum and PR girl sharing adventures on life in a new country, all with a touch of 80s nostalgia

What To Expect When You Are (Not) Expecting A Child With Cerebral Palsy William needs 24/7 care, but he loves being with people, whether they are children or 'grown-ups'. If you're (not) expecting a child with cerebral palsy you won't be expecting the feelings of relief, comfort and happiness when you see them build relationships with adults who want to help them as much as you do. Writer & Disability Campaigner

My Letter Of Life Firstly, table manners. Wherever you go and whatever you do in life, you will be judged by your table manners. Keep your mouth shut as you chew, put your knife and fork down between mouthfuls, and for goodness sake remember that your side plate is to the left and your glass is to the right. Writer and editor of dadbloguk.com

There Wasn't Time To React When My Daughter Got Meningitis - I Went Into Practical Mode This is something even now I don't think I have quite accepted happened, or dealt with, but remaining positive and focused on what needed to be done is what helped us through it. Supporter of Meningitis Now

Embracing The Title Of Stay At Home Mother When I had my daughter, I relaxed a little more into the role. Maybe I felt that having two children, and the doubling of work that entailed, was more worthy of my staying at home. Perhaps with two I could now justify the breaks I crave, the exhaustion I feel and the money I spend. Irish-based blogger and at-home-mother - www.iamlauriem.com

We Need To Teach Kids How To Look After Their Mental Health We've never been taught to put our mental health first in the same way we've been taught to look after and listen to our bodies. This is simply ludicrous and irresponsible. As you're growing up, you're taught to try and reduce the risk of getting sick. Twenty-something aspiring writer. Lover of tea, animals and winter.

Days Out With The Kids As An Undercover Mum Having Fun! Over the years I've endured some really shit days out, really bloody boring. Not because I didn't like being out with my kids, no sir-reeeeee I love being with my kids, the shit days were mainly down to attractions being a total let down. Mother, Blogger & avoider of recipes with more then 4 ingredients.

Caesarean Sections... Through A Dad's Eye With our twins 'coming out' early at 35 weeks, we were having a caesarean section which when 'planned' does feel like you're booking into some form of mini break, except as a dad, you don't get a bed, you're not included on the meal plan and you're the bag carrier... A dad blogger whose scriblings and instagram posts (@themultidad) set out to show the lighter side of a life with a Toddler AND Twins...
TITLE: Parent Voices

SUMMARY:
Jagmeet Singh, centre, went sockless during a NDP leadership debate hosted by HuffPost Canada on Sept. 27, 2017.
Like Trudeau, Singh boasts charisma, flash, social media prowess, and remarkable confidence.
Like Trudeau, Singh will be called on to prove he's about more than Snapchat and saccharine slogans.
Like Trudeau, Singh knows what it means to have international attention thrust upon him.
With files from Althia RajListen to an interview with Jagmeet Singh on HuffPost Canada's politics podcast:
TEXT:
ADVERTISEMENT

"Socks are out."

Jagmeet Singh made the quip days before he won the leadership of Canada's left-wing New Democratic Party on the first ballot, a stunning rout of three experienced members of Parliament.

Just ahead of a debate hosted by HuffPost Canada, Singh â€” immaculately dressed in a pinstriped navy suit and bright orange turban â€” used the line to explain his noticeably bare ankles.

The 38-year-old politician can't help but stand out. His fashion sense has landed him on best-dressed lists and a profile in GQ. Uncommon stuff for someone aspiring to lead a party that champions the poor and marginalized.

Jagmeet Singh, centre, went sockless during a NDP leadership debate hosted by HuffPost Canada on Sept. 27, 2017. (Photo: Charla Jones/HuffPost Canada)

But one couldn't help but wonder if Singh's sartorial comment was also something of a dig at Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, whose penchant for wacky socks â€” Look, Chewbacca! â€” seems to catch the eyes of international media more than his policies.

Or, for that matter, the things Trudeau might not want to talk about, including his abandoned pledge to reform Canada's electoral system or the fact that his government is not complying with a human rights order to boost funding for Indigenous children on reserves.

Like Trudeau, Singh boasts charisma, flash, social media prowess, and remarkable confidence. Both know how to draw a crowd and capture the attention of young people. Both have that thing.

But while Trudeau is the son of a former prime minister, Singh is the child of immigrants from the Indian state of Punjab, who enrolled their boy in taekwondo to fend off bullies. He became a skilled martial artist and wrestler.

Jagmeet Singh was captain of his high school wrestling team. (Photo courtesy Jagmeet Singh)

While Trudeau tells the world that diversity is Canada's strength, Singh knows what it means to grow up with people calling him dirty because of his brown skin.

It's those kinds of contrasts that have New Democrats â€” a party often seen as playing for the bronze â€” bullish that Trudeau may have met his match. They hope that progressives who two years ago were eager to send Conservatives packing will tack further left next time to make history in more ways than one.

A Sikh who boasts a long, black beard, Singh is now the first person of colour to lead a major federal party in Canadian history. Singh was open throughout his campaign about the bigotry he has faced because of the way he looks. He has beaten back questions that he will be rejected in the battleground province of Quebec because of its culture of secularism.

"Growing up with brown skin, long hair and a funny-sounding name meant I faced some challenges," Singh said in his acceptance speech in Toronto Sunday â€” the "funny name" bit containing unmistakable shades of the speech that made Barack Obama a star.

"I've been stopped by the police multiple times for no other reason than the colour of my skin. It makes you feel like you don't belong. Like there's something wrong with you for just being you.

"And that's why, as prime minister, I will make sure that no one in Canada is stopped by the police because of the way they look or the colour of their skin."

New NDP leader Jagmeet Singh credits his mother as being his biggest influence. (Photo courtesy Jagmeet Singh)

Singh, a criminal defence lawyer before making the jump to politics, also told the crowd how, in his 20s, he became the sole income earner for his family and a surrogate parent to his younger brother when his father became ill and couldn't work.

Singh suggested that's another reality that Trudeau doesn't understand. He accused the Trudeau government of delivering a message that Canadians should get used precarious, paycheque-to-paycheque work.

"Maybe if you look at employment as a hobby you can just get used to unstable work, but if your work means the difference between putting food on the table or a roof over the head of your family, then job insecurity is unacceptable," Singh said.

There has never been an acceptance speech quite like it because, simply, there's never been a leader like this. Not here, anyway. Not until now.

Jagmeet Singh speaks during an NDP leadership debate on Sept. 27, 2017. (Photo: Charla Jones/HuffPost Canada)

Singh is the same age as the new Conservative leader, Andrew Scheer, who will be 40 by the time the next election rolls around. At 45, Trudeau â€” dismissed by some as too green two years ago â€” is suddenly the oldest of Canada's three main party leaders.

Like Trudeau after he won the Liberal Party leadership in 2013, Singh will face questions about whether he has the chops to lead a G7 country. He lacks a federal seat and appears is no rush to get one before the 2019 election, instead hinting he'll spend the days in between criss-crossing the country to rebuild the party at the grassroots.

Like Trudeau, Singh will be called on to prove he's about more than Snapchat and saccharine slogans. His, by the way, is "love and courage."

Like Trudeau, Singh knows what it means to have international attention thrust upon him.

Just before NDP members started to vote last month, a heckler spewing ugly words about Shariah law and the Muslim brotherhood confronted Singh at an event.

He urged the crowd not to be intimidated by hate.

"We welcome you. We love you," he told the shouting woman with more grace than she was owed.

Later, Singh said he didn't tell that woman he's Sikh because his response to Islamophobia has never been to say that he's not Muslim, but that "hate is wrong."

The video was shared around the world. Famous Americans talked about it on Twitter, scratching that itch some Canadians have not only to be noticed but for it to be known that maple-washed notions of Canada as a land devoid of racism don't hold up.

It was all so much more important than socks.

With files from Althia Raj

Listen to an interview with Jagmeet Singh on HuffPost Canada's politics podcast:
TITLE: Jagmeet Singh, Canadaâ€™s New Political Star, Hopes To Beat Trudeau At His Own Game

SUMMARY:
Shorten appeared on popular program Fitzy and Wippa, agreeing to get stuck into a rap battle on the air.
He dropped some rhymes over 50 Cent's hit 'In Da Club', and look, he wasn't exactly the best MC out.
Shorten has recently dropped his patented zingers from his public speeches, but bringing them back saw him present a daggy, relatable side on radio.
But the bigger surprise was still to come, with talkback radio star Ray Hadley dropping in to battle the Labor leader -- basketball jersey, backwards cap, gold chain and all.
"What's doing homie," the 63-year-old AM radio host said, before launching into an even worse rap than Shorten, which included calling Turnbull a "number one wanker".
TEXT:
Malcolm Turnbull and Bill Shorten have been battling for supremacy over the nation's FM airwaves in a media strategy meant to engage with ordinary voters, but the Labor leader engaged in a radio battle of a different kind on Friday -- dropping raps like a daggy dad against an ever daggier dad in talkback king Ray Hadley.

There's a bit to unpack here so bear with us.

Shorten appeared on popular program Fitzy and Wippa, agreeing to get stuck into a rap battle on the air. He dropped some rhymes over 50 Cent's hit 'In Da Club', and look, he wasn't exactly the best MC out.

We're not exactly sure if he writes his own raps or uses a ghost writer. But while Bill's flows weren't the smoothest, he did manage to sneak in a solid burn or two on the Government, rhyming "our economy's in debt but Malcolm's just chillin', hey Malcolm can you lend us a couple million?" and spitting, "Will I rap again? It's anyone's guess, but there's more chance of Tony Abbott voting yes".

Shorten has recently dropped his patented zingers from his public speeches, but bringing them back saw him present a daggy, relatable side on radio. But the bigger surprise was still to come, with talkback radio star Ray Hadley dropping in to battle the Labor leader -- basketball jersey, backwards cap, gold chain and all.

"What's doing homie," the 63-year-old AM radio host said, before launching into an even worse rap than Shorten, which included calling Turnbull a "number one wanker".

The hosts, Shorten and Hadley then finished off with a dab. It's vintage viewing. Happy Friday.
TITLE: Bill Shorten Just Had A Radio Rap Battle With Ray Hadley, And Oh God

"Les propos odieux de Valls sur les Roms provoquent enfin une prise de conscience sur ce personnage et la politique qu'il conduit. Il nie le but rÃ©publicain en assignant les individus Ã  leur ethnie, l'ethnie Ã  un invariant", Ã©crivait-il sur son blog. Cette mÃªme annÃ©e, il estimait que Manuel Valls Ã©tait "contaminÃ© par l'extrÃªme droite" et qu'il Ã©tait "nÃ©faste pour la gauche".

Une fois Ã  Matignon, l'ex-maire d'Evry a utilisÃ© Ã  six reprises le 49-3, notamment au moment de l'adoption des lois Macron et El-Khomri, toutes deux contestÃ©es dans la rue. Du pain bÃ©nit pour Jean-Luc MÃ©lenchon et ses soutiens, qui avaient alors beau jeu d'opposer l'autoritarisme de Manuel Valls Ã  la colÃ¨re populaire.

Tout cela a contribuÃ© Ã  faire de Manuel Valls (plus encore que de FranÃ§ois Hollande) l'ennemi numÃ©ro 1 de la France insoumise. Une animositÃ© Ã  des annÃ©es lumiÃ¨res de la courtoisie qui prÃ©vaut aujourd'hui entre Jean-Luc MÃ©lenchon et l'actuel premier ministre Edouard Philippe.

En tÃ©moigne l'Ã©lection de Manuel Valls aux Ã©lections lÃ©gislatives, toujours contestÃ©e Ã  ce jour devant le Conseil constitutionnel. En rÃ©sumÃ©, la candidate de la France insoumise, Farida Amrani, accuse l'actuel dÃ©putÃ© de l'Essonne d'avoir trichÃ©. Ce qui, au moment de la communication des rÃ©sultats dans le hall de la mairie d'Evry, a donnÃ© lieu Ã  une scÃ¨ne pour le moins surrÃ©aliste.

Une escalade rÃ©cente

Mais le ton est encore montÃ© entre Jean-Luc MÃ©lenchon et Manuel Valls quand ce dernier a quittÃ© Matignon pour se tailler un costume de candidat, Ã  la primaire de la gauche d'abord, puis aux lÃ©gislatives. Jean-Luc MÃ©lenchon s'est d'ailleurs rendu dans sa circonscription de l'Essonne pour expliquer aux Ã©lecteurs que Manuel Valls Ã©tait "plus misÃ©rable que tout".

Il faut dire que le natif de Barcelone avait trouvÃ© un angle d'attaque particuliÃ¨rement virulent: la "compromission" dont ferait preuve la France insoumise Ã  l'Ã©gard des islamistes. Depuis, Manuel Valls n'a pas arrÃªtÃ©, et a persistÃ© dans ce registre, allant jusqu'Ã  qualifier les dÃ©putÃ©s de la France insoumise "d'islamo-gauchistes" dans l'hÃ©micycle. Une intervention applaudie par le FN.

Et cela prend des proportions toujours plus importantes. Ce samedi, le camp Valls accuse dÃ©sormais la formation de Jean-Luc MÃ©lenchon de nourrir "une complicitÃ© de plus en plus explicite avec les sinistres de la RÃ©publique, avec les thÃ¨ses de DieudonnÃ© et Alain Soral".

Taper sur MÃ©lenchon pour se faire une place

En s'attaquant mutuellement, Jean-Luc MÃ©lenchon et Manuel Valls se nourrissent donc du sentiment de rejet que provoque leur adversaire dÃ©signÃ© auprÃ¨s d'une partie des FranÃ§ais.

Mais si le leader de la France insoumise, qui apparaÃ®t pour l'heure comme le premier opposant Ã  la politique de l'exÃ©cutif, a plus intÃ©rÃªt Ã  tirer sur le tandem Macron-Philippe que sur l'ancien premier ministre, Manuel Valls a au contraire un besoin vital d'exister, lui qui paraÃ®t isolÃ© au sein de la nouvelle majoritÃ©.

D'oÃ¹ cette stratÃ©gie de la mitraille adoptÃ©e par l'ancien premier ministre qui, Ã  dÃ©faut de pouvoir peser au sein du groupe LREM, continue d'Ãªtre exposÃ© en endossant le rÃ´le de l'adversaire du premier opposant au prÃ©sident de la RÃ©publique.

SUMMARY:
Shadow Chief Secretary to the Treasury, Labour MP for Feltham and HestonWho Would Win In A Fight: Parliament Or The U.S. Congress?
But it does limit the life of a Parliament to five years.
In the 18th century, Britain's Parliament redefined modern democracy; in the 21st, it can do so again.
Head, ACCA UKWomen Our Parliament Still Needs You!
Photo: 50:50 Parliament the 21st Century Suffragettes demanding political equality So the 2017 General Election is over.
TEXT:
Brexit: Under The Cover Of Darkness The government should be open with the British people and make public the information they have to allow for a full and factual debate that covers both the risks and benefits of leaving the European Union and informs the debate about our priorities for Brexit negotiations. It is their responsibility and duty to do so. Shadow Chief Secretary to the Treasury, Labour MP for Feltham and Heston

Who Would Win In A Fight: Parliament Or The U.S. Congress? Let's assume that they do not have any weapons, and we're talking about a fist fight... A place to share knowledge and better understand the world

Why I Am Supporting The International Week Of The Deaf This is a community which is underappreciated and often underrepresented and that is why this week we must celebrate the achievements of the deaf community who are often not recognised enough. It is vital that we give deaf people the right support to enable the full inclusion of sign language in everyday life. Labour MP for Brent Central

How Long Until The Next General Election? It Could Be Longer Than You Think The FTPA (as anyone who has got this far probably knows) means Parliament will sit for a fixed 5-year term rather than the Prime Minister of the day calling a General Election when it suits them (yes, yes, I know). But it does limit the life of a Parliament to five years. Except that under the Withdrawal Bill, a minister could argue that the Brexit process is still incomplete... Officially Endorsed by the President of the United States... I wish that were a good thing

Lord Neuberger's Salutary Warning Many recent bad court decisions cry out for revocation, but I wonder whether the current British government is even aware of the existence of this nuclear option, let alone courageous enough to use it. Barrister at Law, Sometime Fellow of St John's College, Cambridge

Scrapping Tuition Fees Is Regressive, We Need Reform And To Bring Back Grants The current system needs change: bring back grants, keep interest rates to inflation and explore more ways to reform the progressive system we have now. If income tax needs to be raised to fund the grants, go ahead, but abolishing tuition fees is taking two steps back after moving an inch forward. Lib Dem campaigner in Cambridge, bodyman for Susan van de Ven. Toby Ziegler wannabe.

Want To Help Those Struggling To Find Secure Work, Prime Minister? Back My Bill It's going to be tough work, but I'm excited and driven by the opportunity to make things a bit better for people. I hope you will get behind me and lobby your own MP to back my Bill. If you want to share your experiences of unpaid trial shifts, or just give me your views on the Bill then visit my website - www.stewartmcdonald.scot - and respond to my online consultation today. SNP MP for Glasgow South

We Must All Echo Theresa May's Sense Of Duty And Public Service To Get Brexit Right I'm glad the Prime Minister decided to tackle what's been going on behind her back. Not for her sake, but for everyone else's. It's safe to say that Theresa May will not be remembered as a brilliant politician, but what she has going for her is a great sense of duty and public service. And don't knock it as some consolation prize. Right now, it's what the country needs. Conservative peer and former Leader of the House of Lords

This Is Not The Political Silly Season So far from the Summer being the political 'silly season' it will be critical to pay attention to what happens this year. Your promised 'digital detox' sitting on a beach will have to wait. Instead, look forward to checking Twitter, news sites and your digital subscriptions. Public affairs consultant at Bircham Dyson Bell

Why Can't May Cosy Up To Trump Like Macron Did? What I find fascinating is the difference in tone many of these publications took when covering Theresa May's visit to Washington in January. Then, a leader of a large European country with a surprisingly fragile economy cosying up to Trump was seen as desperate. Now, it's being portrayed as a bromance. Why? Student journalist, blogger and contributor to The National Student

Politicians Can't Agree On Brexit - Give The People A Say The rallying cry of 'take back control,' which inspired so many voters, will not be realised within the constraints of our Parliamentary democracy. More ambition is required. In the 18th century, Britain's Parliament redefined modern democracy; in the 21st, it can do so again. Rob J Adam is an independent journalist and researcher.

Charities Should Seize The Opportunity Offered By The Parliamentary Arithmetic Let's hope that charities and others will act and not stand aside. I have confidence that there is an opportunity for social action at a local and national level on an unprecedented scale with the result that there will be change - and that this change will be for the better. Independent strategic advisor

Government Needs To Listen To Business On Brexit As Downing Street discovered the hard way, a shielded and closed door approach will not work on an issue that affects so many in many different ways. An inclusive approach is what is needed to create a cohesive Brexit plan that gets the support of business and society alike. Now is the time for government to listen. Head, ACCA UK

Women Our Parliament Still Needs You! Photo: 50:50 Parliament the 21st Century Suffragettes demanding political equality So the 2017 General Election is over. There are 12 more women at ... Founder of the 50:50 Parliament Campaign
TITLE: Parliament
