TEXT:
li"The 5 S's."

If you've had a baby in the past 15 years, you've likely had someone whisper these three little words to you as you stood helpless in the face of your baby's crying.

The phrase, which comes from Dr. Harvey Karp's The Happiest Baby on the Block, is part of the pediatrician's regimen for calming babies and helping them get to sleep happily.

What it's all about

They stand for "swaddle" (i.e. the baby burrito), "side" (holding a baby on their side or over your shoulder), "shush" (just like it sounds .. or alternatively, white noise), "swing" (rocking a baby firmly for movement) and "suck" (if you've ever seen a pacifier work its magic on a newborn, you know what this is about).

Doing these five things, either one at a time or all together, can help soothe babies and also (more importantly?) new parents. Dr. Karp is a guy who knows what he's talking about (he's even invented a crib that brings all these ideas together), which is why we invited him into our studio to ask him some of the most common sleep questions when it comes to babies.
TITLE: The Answers To The Baby Snooze Questions Every Sleep-Deprived Parent Has

SUMMARY:
Noting that his government has been criticised on economic front, Modi said: "We are a sensitive government.
Quoting the RBI, the prime minister said the growth is expected to improve to 7.7% in the last quarter of the fiscal.
Observing that the number of EPFO subscribers has gone up from 3.26 crore in 2014-end to 4.80 crore, the prime minister said this cannot happen without an increase in job creation.
The government, he said, was aware that the growth has slowed and is taking steps to improve it.
Modi assured the traders that the government will not re-open their records if they join the mainstream of the economy.
TEXT:
ADVERTISEMENT

NEW DELHI -- Lashing out at critics of his economic policies, Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Wednesday said the Indian economy was on firm footing and that he will never jeopardise the country's future for immediate gains.

In an over hour-long speech, punctuated with sharp comments and comparisons with a track record of previous UPA regime, Modi told a gathering of company secretaries that his government will continue reforms and will not hesitate to take decisions to reverse the GDP slowdown witnessed in the last two quarters.

In the same vein, he said his government will graciously accept criticism on the economic front and will make amends wherever necessary.

Inaugurating the Golden Jubilee Year Celebrations of the Institute of Company Secretaries of India (ICSI), Modi said he has asked the GST Council to identify bottlenecks and technological hurdles faced by businesses, especially small and medium enterprises.

"I will not jeopardise the future of the country for my present gains," he said, adding the government would focus on structural reforms rather than giving doles to win praises.

Modi said his critics were seeing slowdown in the last two quarters but were ignoring the fact that the BJP government had brought down inflation from 10% in the UPA regime to 2.5%, shrunk Current Account Deficit to near 1% from 4% and brought down fiscal deficit to 3.5% from 4.5%.

GDP growth was 5.7% or less than that on eight occasions during previous UPA government, he said, lamenting how pessimists were describing the April-June growth of 5.7% as doomsday.

Modi made comments days after senior BJP leader Yashwant Sinha in an article headlined "I need to speak up now", described the economy as a "mess" that will not resuscitate before the next general elections.

"The government is committed to reverse this trend ... we are capable of that and ready to take decisions," Modi said, adding the decisions taken by the government will take India to a new growth trajectory.

Noting that his government has been criticised on economic front, Modi said: "We are a sensitive government. We accept the strongest criticism and we have considered them with humility ... 125 crore people have an expectation of high growth".

Quoting the RBI, the prime minister said the growth is expected to improve to 7.7% in the last quarter of the fiscal.

According to the RBI, the economic growth, which had slipped to 5.7 in the first quarter, is likely to improve to 6.4% in second, 7.1% in third and 7.7% in the last quarter.

Observing that the number of EPFO subscribers has gone up from 3.26 crore in 2014-end to 4.80 crore, the prime minister said this cannot happen without an increase in job creation.

Modi further said the NDA government in the last three years has undertaken 87 reforms in 21 sectors and the country has come out of "policy paralysis" to become a nation of "policymaker and policy implementor".

The prime minister said there was a time when India was part of 'fragile-5' and the BJP government pulled it out to make it the fastest growing economy for the most part of its three-year rule.

The government, he said, was aware that the growth has slowed and is taking steps to improve it.

The government, he said, is ready to make amends to help small traders.

Modi said registration of 2.1 lakh out of 3 lakh suspected shell companies identified post note ban have been canceled in a crackdown on the black money.

Modi assured the traders that the government will not re-open their records if they join the mainstream of the economy.

"In the changing economic scenario, honesty will command a premium and the government will protect the interest of honest persons," he said and called upon the company secretaries to encourage their clients to honestly pay taxes.

Also on HuffPost India:
TITLE: PM Modi Promises Steps To Reverse GDP Slowdown, Says Situation Exaggerated By 'Pessimists'

TEXT:
NahrungsergÃ¤nzungsmittel sind im Trend und das gilt besonders fÃ¼r Vitamine. Immer mehr Menschen greifen zu VitaminprÃ¤paraten anstatt zu frischem Obst und sind der Meinung, sich so gesund zu ernÃ¤hren. Das ist nicht immer der Fall, denn wie eine Untersuchung jetzt zeigt, nehmen viele Menschen dadurch Vitamine in einer viel zu hohen Dosierung zu sich. Vitamine sind zwar gesund, wenn sie in der richtigen Menge zugefÃ¼hrt werden, oft werden sie aber viel zu hoch dosiert, wie die Stiftung Warentest jetzt herausgefunden hat.

Kaum Kontrolle

Anders als bei Medikamenten wird der Handel mit NahrungsergÃ¤nzungsmitteln deutlich weniger reguliert. Es gibt in Deutschland keine Regel, die die Dosis an VitaminprÃ¤paraten eingrenzt, aber das ist offenbar dringend erforderlich. Jedem, der sich Ã¼ber einen Vitaminratgeber informiert, sollte schnell klar sein, dass zusÃ¤tzliche Vitamine nicht in jedem Fall notwendig sind. Viele Lebensmittel, die tÃ¤glich auf den Tisch kommen, sind mit Vitaminen angereichert, auÃŸerdem essen viele Menschen frisches Obst, wenn auch unregelmÃ¤ÃŸig. Dazu kommt, dass der Markt fÃ¼r NahrungsergÃ¤nzungsmittel mehr als groÃŸ ist. Wer sich mit den vermeintlich gesunden Vitaminen in Tablettenform versorgen mÃ¶chte, der verliert sehr schnell den Ãœberblick. Studien, die es zu diesem Thema gibt, sind leider oftmals nicht sehr hilfreich. Sie schÃ¼ren teilweise die Angst vor Krankheiten, die entstehen kÃ¶nnen, wenn Vitamine fehlen.

Gut informiert mit der Stiftung Warentest

Die Stiftung Warentest hat sich die angebotenen VitaminprÃ¤parate in ihrer aktuellen Ausgabe einmal genauer angesehen. Im Artikel ist unter anderem eine Tabelle zu finden, in der die 35 am hÃ¤ufigsten gekauften VitaminprÃ¤parate in Deutschland aufgefÃ¼hrt sind. Der Leser kann sich auf diese Weise einfach, Ã¼bersichtlich und vor allem ausfÃ¼hrlich Ã¼ber den Namen des Produkts wie Ã¼ber den Preis und die empfohlene Tagesdosis informieren. Zudem bietet die Stiftung Warentest genaues Hintergrundwissen. Was ist beim Einkauf von VitaminprÃ¤paraten besonders wichtig und welche gesetzlichen Vorgaben gibt es eigentlich fÃ¼r NahrungsergÃ¤nzungsmittel? AusfÃ¼hrlich berichtet die Stiftung Warentest zudem Ã¼ber die einzelnen Vitamine A, C, D, E, K sowie die B-Vitamine, und wofÃ¼r der KÃ¶rper sie benÃ¶tigt.

Sind Vitamine als NahrungsergÃ¤nzung sinnvoll?

Rund 30 % der Menschen in Deutschland nehmen mehr oder weniger regelmÃ¤ÃŸig VitaminprÃ¤parate zu sich. Sie fÃ¼rchten sich davor, unterversorgt zu sein und dass die Ration an Obst nicht ausreicht, um den Vitaminhaushalt zu decken. In den meisten FÃ¤llen ist diese Sorge unbegrÃ¼ndet. Leider ersetzt die Vitamintablette allein zudem keine gesunde ausgewogene ErnÃ¤hrung mit Obst und GemÃ¼se. Die tÃ¤gliche Dosis Vitamine kann aber auch hilfreich sein. Menschen, die krank sind oder wenn der Arzt es verordnet, kÃ¶nnen ihren Mangel an Vitaminen mit den entsprechenden Mitteln ausgleichen. Wie so oft, gilt auch hier: Die Dosis macht das Gift. Zu viele Vitamine wirken kontraproduktiv und sind nicht mehr gesund, zu wenige Vitamine hingegen lÃ¶sen Mangelerscheinungen hervor.

â¨ Mehr zum Thema: Dieser vÃ¶llig absurde ErnÃ¤hrungstrend zeigt, wie krank unsere Gesellschaft wirklich ist

Wer sich ganz sicher sein mÃ¶chte, der sollte mit seinem Arzt darÃ¼ber sprechen, welche Vitamine in welcher Menge sinnvoll sind.

____

Ihr habt auch ein spannendes Thema?

Kathleen Wynne cheers with Deb Matthews at the Ontario Liberal leadership convention in Toronto on Jan. 26, 2013.

TEXT:
Kathleen Wynne cheers with Deb Matthews at the Ontario Liberal leadership convention in Toronto on Jan. 26, 2013.

TORONTO â€” Two Ontario cabinet ministers announced Friday they won't seek re-election next year, adding to a growing tally of prominent Liberals bowing out at a time when the party struggles in the polls.

Both Deputy Premier Deb Matthews and Treasury Board President Liz Sandals, however, insist that is not the reason for their upcoming departures.

Matthews will remain as the Liberals' campaign co-chair through the election, saying she has enormous respect for Premier Kathleen Wynne.

"I am confident that, on June 7, 2018, the people of Ontario will give her and her team the mandate to continue to serve," Matthews wrote in a statement Friday.

Various polls would suggest a different outcome, however, with most putting the Liberals behind the Progressive Conservatives, and one survey even putting the Liberals in third, behind the NDP.

Sandals, 70, stressed that her 30 years of service and her age were behind her decision to retire.

"This was a challenging decision to make because while I'm ready to be a full-time grandmother, I've never had more faith in Premier Kathleen Wynne and the Ontario Liberal Party," she wrote in a statement.

"Over the last several months, I've spent time knocking on doors across Guelph and I know that our policies are resonating with my constituents."

Other key figures not seeking re-election

Matthews, who was elected in 2003, will stay as the representative for London North Centre and as advanced education minister until the election. Sandals, who first got into politics through her local school board and was elected to the legislature in 2003, will stay as the representative for Guelph, Ont., and in cabinet until the election, too.

Economic Development Minister Brad Duguid announced last month that he would not run in next year's provincial election.

Former environment minister Glen Murray recently left government for the private sector, and Speaker Dave Levac, the Liberal representative for Brant, and Monte Kwinter, Ontario's oldest MPP, have also announced they won't seek re-election.
TITLE: Deb Matthews, Liz Sandals Won't Run In 2018 Ontario Election

Le trumpisme a eu beau, rÃ©cemment, exporter le principe de l'outrance verbale prÃ©sidentielle, les deux PrÃ©sidents FranÃ§ais ont bien Ã©tÃ© critiquÃ© par l'usage de ces "gros" mots qu'on a du mal Ã  accepter quand ils sont prononcÃ©s par un chef de l'Etat en exercice.

Enfin, troisiÃ¨me et grande diffÃ©rence avec Sarkozy. Ce dernier avait thÃ©orisÃ©, instrumentalisÃ© et fini par surexploiter jusqu'Ã  l'usure, le clivage permanent et rÃ©pÃ©tÃ©, l'hystÃ©risation volontaire du dÃ©bat, Ã©coutant beaucoup (trop) l'un des doctrinaires du clivage provocateur appliquÃ© aux enjeux de sociÃ©tÃ© et aux questions dÃ®tes "identitaires", Patrick Buisson, formÃ© Ã  l'Ã©cole Le Pen pÃ¨re. Chez Emmanuel Macron, la thÃ©orie est prÃ©sente mais inverse: pour le PrÃ©sident actuel, ce n'est pas une position "ultra" qu'il faut incarner, pour tenter de rallier ensuite des courants satellites dans un sillage de conquÃªte (une stratÃ©gie qui a Ã©chouÃ© en 2012 et aux primaires de la droite en 2016), c'est au contraire une posture du rassemblement "et gauche, et droite" qui a fait sa marque de fabrique et l'ample succÃ¨s de la prÃ©sidentielle de 2017, confirmÃ©e aux lÃ©gislatives qui ont suivi. 'A headache'Over at the Toronto Sun, columnist Lorne Gunter describes Singh as bad news for the prime minister and great news for the Conservatives.
"And Prime Minister Justin Trudeau turned 45 last year â€” decrepit for a music festival attendee, but a fledgling in the political arena."
TEXT:
NDP Leader Jagmeet Singh arrives to his first caucus meeting since being elected leader, in Ottawa on Oct. 4, 2017.

This is Jagmeet Singh, the new leader of the federal New Democrats.

NDP Leader Jagmeet Singh arrives to his first caucus meeting since being elected to the leadership of the New Democrats, in Ottawa on Oct. 4, 2017.

The 38-year-old's victory in his party's leadership race has been hailed as a win for diversity and representation in politics. He's been called youthful, charismatic and energetic, but he's also been talked about in less, shall we say, commonplace ways:

'He's an alpha'

Behold what The Globe and Mail's Margaret Wente said, for example, in a column published the day after his leadership win. After declaring that Singh is "hotter" than Prime Minister Justin Trudeau and has a "brilliant branding device" in his turbans, she writes:

"He has the posture of a warrior â€” brash, worldly, fearless and also supermanly. Not a beta male, as Justin sometimes tends to be. He's an alpha, with a full luxuriant beard and a serious kirpan to match."

At the end of her column, Wente wonders if we could get the two of them in an MMA match. Are you there, God? It's Margaret, and she has a wonderful idea.

'A headache'

Over at the Toronto Sun, columnist Lorne Gunter describes Singh as bad news for the prime minister and great news for the Conservatives. He argues the NDP leader will be a "headache" for Trudeau because he is younger, "smarter, at least as well-dressed and even more of a trendy, politically correct symbol."

"Singh is as distinctive for his designer suits and immaculately tied turban as the Liberal leader is for his dandy socks," he writes.

'An Obama-like leader'

The National Post's John Ivison also sees Singh as potential good news for the NDP and Conservatives, especially if he can galvanize left-leaning voters who opted for the Liberals in the 2015 federal election.

Ivison argues Singh is an "Obama-like leader" who has "interpreted his race as a social construct, not a biological reality." He then points out there are doubts whether Singh is "all pink turban and no perspicacity."

'A dreamboat'

Slide back to The Globe and we find television critic John Doyle writing about Singh and...television, sort of? The columnist starts off his Tuesday piece by saying that although the soon-to-be-former Ontario MPP has yet to perfect his live-TV performance, he is already "masterful" in his use of visual imagery.

"What emanates from him is cosmopolitan masculinity, virility, style, confidence, ease with himself and empathy. He has sex appeal," Doyle writes.

"He is, to a lot of people, especially millennials, a dreamboat."

Doyle lauds Singh for his reaction to a heckler who yelled at him about Shariah law at a campaign event in Ontario. He says the video of that moment is "rich in meaning and fascination."

'Spring chicken'

Finally, at the Toronto Star, columnist Emma Teitel describes the NDP leader as "practically an adolescent" when compared to Trudeau and other MPs, but points out that he is not the only "spring chicken in the federal political coop."

"Federal Conservative Leader Andrew Scheer is also 38 (though like most conservatives, his soul is around 83)," Teitel wrote in Monday's piece.

"And Prime Minister Justin Trudeau turned 45 last year â€” decrepit for a music festival attendee, but a fledgling in the political arena."

Congratulations to the NDP on its new strong, cosmopolitan, suit-wearing spring chicken!
TITLE: Jagmeet Singh Is Already Earning The Weirdest Descriptions In Politics

are searching for a man who went into a Tim Hortons location in the wee hours Thursday, ordered a drink and paid for it.
Security camera footage shows the suspect walking out of the store, drink in hand, after pulling off the casual heist.
A screengrab from surveillance footage shows the suspect wearing what Windsor Police described as a "unique multicoloured purple and yellow baseball cap."
He was wearing blue jeans, a blue sweater and a "unique multicoloured purple and yellow baseball cap" at the time of the incident, police said.
The force is asking anyone with information to contact Windsor Police Service at 519-255-6700 ext.
TEXT:
Police in Windsor, Ont. are searching for a man who went into a Tim Hortons location in the wee hours Thursday, ordered a drink and paid for it.

You know, classic customer stuff.

But the force says in a press release that he then "demanded money from the cash register" and announced he was robbing the place.

The employee at the till complied. Security camera footage shows the suspect walking out of the store, drink in hand, after pulling off the casual heist.

The force's major crimes department is now investigating the incident.

A screengrab from surveillance footage shows the suspect wearing what Windsor Police described as a "unique multicoloured purple and yellow baseball cap."

The suspect is described as a white male, around 40 years old and approximately six feet tall. He was wearing blue jeans, a blue sweater and a "unique multicoloured purple and yellow baseball cap" at the time of the incident, police said.

The force is asking anyone with information to contact Windsor Police Service at 519-255-6700 ext. 4830, Crime Stoppers anonymously at 519-258-8477 (TIPS) or online at www.catchcrooks.com
TITLE: Windsor Police Searching For Tim Hortons Customer Who Pulled Off Super-Casual Heist

Quant au govern, il voulait isoler dÃ©finitivement la Catalogne, mais ses citoyens se sont mis Ã  espÃ©rer Ã  nouveau une transformation au niveau de l'Etat espagnol.

MÃªme les partis Catalunya en ComÃ¹ et Podemos avaient des raisons de dÃ©sirer ce scÃ©nario en secret. Pour les formations d'Ada Colau et de Pablo Iglesias, la seule lÃ©gitimitÃ© du 1er octobre Ã©tait de mobilier les citoyens pour revendiquer le droit Ã  organiser un rÃ©fÃ©rendum encadrÃ©. Cependant, rien dans la maniÃ¨re dont les Ã©vÃ©nements se sont dÃ©roulÃ©s n'invitait Ã  cette interprÃ©tation; de nombreux dÃ©fenseurs du rÃ©fÃ©rendum Ã©taient sincÃ¨rement persuadÃ©s de l'imminence historique de l'indÃ©pendance, et le govern s'est montrÃ© plus que dÃ©terminÃ©. S'il y avait eu un minimum de contrÃ´le des listes Ã©lectorales et du vote, la rÃ©publique catalane aurait Ã©tÃ© acclamÃ©e avant minuit. Le rÃªve de transversalitÃ©, atteint grÃ¢ce Ã  une erreur de Rajoy. Quel paradoxe tragique!

La formation d'un nouveau front transversal qui s'oppose au gouvernement de Mariano Rajoy incite l'intelligentsia des nouveaux courants politiques Ã  vouloir organiser des Ã©lections de toute urgence pour rÃ©soudre la crise systÃ©mique du pays. C'est en adoptant une attitude humble que nous pourrons redonner un sens au civisme et Ã  nos institutions. Si nous nous rÃ©concilions tous, alors nous pouvons imaginer qu'un jour PiquÃ© sera applaudi quand il portera le maillot de l'Ã©quipe nationale.

SUMMARY:
Thrashed by the Conservatives in rural Scotland while Labour ate into their central belt support base, the General Election was a sobering experience for the SNP.
So, as the SNP membership meets for its annual conference in Glasgow, what next for the party?
On one, an increasingly left-wing Labour Party under fresh leadership who will be perfectly positioned to absorb Yes-inclined voters with radical pledges such as the re-nationalisation of rail - which the SNP faithful back in greater numbers than Labour voters.
It would be premature for anyone, least of all Davidson, to declare we have reached â€˜peak SNPâ€™.
Maintaining their left of centre stance is good politics, considering Scottish Labour looks set to elect Corbyn-support Richard Leonard as its next leader.
TEXT:
Thrashed by the Conservatives in rural Scotland while Labour ate into their central belt support base, the General Election was a sobering experience for the SNP.

After the heady heights of winning all but three of Scotlandâ€™s Westminster seats in 2015, Nicola Sturgeon put all her chips on pro-Remain Scots getting behind a second independence referendum in order to escape Brexit.

But the First Ministerâ€™s gamble backfired and the party lost a third of its seats, including those of talismanic figures Alex Salmond, Angus Robertson and Tasmina Ahmed-Sheikh.

So, as the SNP membership meets for its annual conference in Glasgow, what next for the party?

The Nats face an attack on two fronts. On one, an increasingly left-wing Labour Party under fresh leadership who will be perfectly positioned to absorb Yes-inclined voters with radical pledges such as the re-nationalisation of rail - which the SNP faithful back in greater numbers than Labour voters.

PA Wire/PA Images Scottish Conservative party leader Ruth Davidson

Secondly, a revived Scottish Conservative Party, under the talented and influential Ruth Davidson, has a foothold in the rural north-east and borders and are making hay from the Scottish Governmentâ€™s faltering education reforms week-in week-out.

As Brexit looms large, the road ahead is far from clear now the voters have delivered their verdict on Sturgeonâ€™s hasty post-Brexit claim that â€˜Indy Ref 2â€™ was then â€œhighly likelyâ€.

Ruth Davidsonâ€™s ruthlessly efficient attack line â€“ â€œget on with the day jobâ€ â€“ could prove lethal if the SNP is unable to shake criticism the party is obsessed with the constitution.

But with the vote split across three main parties in Scotland, it is all to play for. The troops now have to figure out a formula that will shore up potential losses while remaining in government at Holyrood.

It would be premature for anyone, least of all Davidson, to declare we have reached â€˜peak SNPâ€™.

A YouGov poll for the Times sees Sturgeonâ€™s party way out ahead on 35 percent, impressive for a party which has been in power for a decade, while Labour enjoys a 5 percent boost in support and the Tories are pushed from second to third place at Holyrood.

ScotParl voting intention (list):



SNP: 35% (-7)

LAB: 24% (+5)

CON: 23% (-)

GRN: 6% (-1)

LDEM: 6% (+1)



via @YouGov, 02-05 Oct

Chgs. w 2016 â€” Britain Elects (@britainelects) October 7, 2017

Ministers would point to support for their new programme for government, unveiled in September, which, after months of divisive campaigning, saw the First Minister take a more consensual approach.

Policies on business tax reform, extending free personal care to the under-65s, a ban on fracking, consulting with local government on education reform and a new National Investment Bank will quell some of the criticism levelled at her from left and right.

Perhaps seeing the writing on the wall after the Corbyn surge south of the border, Sturgeon also performed something of a U-turn and pledged to lift the public sector pay cap, too.

What she hasnâ€™t spelled out is how she will pay for it, with her Finance Secretary Derek Mackay expected to trigger emergency borrowing measures - something Conservative backers who lend the SNP their vote may take a dim view of in the long term.

But despite furiously attempting to square all these circles, Mackay insists the party is up for the fight.

Jane Barlow - PA Images via Getty Images First Minister Nicola Sturgeon and Finance Secretary Derek Mackay

â€œI think the party is still positive and upbeat and we have a strong and united membership,â€ says Mackay, who will chair this yearâ€™s conference. â€œWe are the ones who have returned from the summer recess with our tails up.

â€œIt is the opposition that look tired and weary.â€

With more than 118,000 members, the SNP is thought to be the second largest party in the UK, with Scottish Labour having just a fraction of that figure (21,500 to UK Labourâ€™s 570,000) and the Tories as a UK group reported to have fewer than 100,000, though no official figures have emerged since 2013.

But as the SNP has recorded a drop from 120,000 in 2014 when the party put on around 100,000 members post-independence campaign, chiefs are searching for growth opportunities in order to survive into the future.

Mackay went on: â€œThe Tory surge is well and truly over, their bubble has burst. They have fallen back into third place in Scotland in opinion polls and in membership.â€

While Mackay would insist the SNPâ€™s ten years in power have been â€œtransformationalâ€, scores would disagree.

Tax measures remain almost identical to those administered in England, despite promises of bold reform, economic growth sees the nation lagging behind other parts of the UK and despite Sturgeon staking her premiership on delivering better education outcomes, Scotlandâ€™s PISA (Programme for International Student Assessment) ratings slump to below England, Estonia, Finland and Slovenia.

Ken Jack - Corbis via Getty Images Party insiders view Angus Robertson as a leader-in-waiting after hitting the target during PMQs in Westminster

Labour frequently accuses Sturgeon of failing to fully use all of the welfare powers devolved to Edinburgh - though she will attempt to mitigate the impact of Universal Credit - and SNP voters who jumped ship to Corbynâ€™s Labour in June would say the party has failed to deliver on their promise of leading a progressive government.

Motions at the conference next week, put forward by various branches, seek to bolster the partyâ€™s leftist credentials.

While the party is already investigating a universal basic income, motions at the conference also call for the devolution of immigration controls, a resolution on treating drug misuse as public health rather than criminal matters and there will be a groundswell of support for Glasgow South MP Stewart McDonaldâ€™s bid to outlaw unpaid trial shifts with a private members bill in Westminster.

Maintaining their left of centre stance is good politics, considering Scottish Labour looks set to elect Corbyn-support Richard Leonard as its next leader.

A Survation poll of SNP voters found they were more likely to vote Labour if it pledged more left-wing measures such as decommissioning Trident (30 percent), a mandatory living wage (37 percent) and renationalising the railways (27 percent).

Mackay said: â€œWe have tried to show we are still radical and that we can deliver reforms. Our programme for government also shows that we are listening and engaging while also acting in the interests of the economy.â€

The YouGov poll showed three quarters of Scots (72 percent) were pessimistic about the current state of the Brexit negotiations, while the number of Scots who believe that the Leave vote was the wrong decision has grown since April.



Excluding donâ€™t knows, 66 percent of Scots thought Brexit was the wrong decision.

The same poll, however, showed virtually no shift in support for independence since Scotland voted No in 2014 by 55 percent and a surge in support for the pro-Union Scottish Labour Party.

PA Wire/PA Images Prime Minister Theresa May (left) meeting with Scotland's First Minister Nicola Sturgeon at Bute House in Edinburgh

Sturgeonâ€™s strategy was to link a â€œhard Tory Brexitâ€ so closely with a re-run of the independence poll, the issue must now be handled with extreme care if the party is to stem the flow of votes to their rivals.

Talk of â€˜Indy Ref 2â€™ has been firmly put on the back burner, with senior figures even urging for the second poll to be kicked further down the road, from pre-Brexit to post-Brexit transition period.

Though this is not a shift in party policy - Alex Salmond positioned the party as pro-European in the 90s - voters were riled by Sturgeonâ€™s â€œopportunisticâ€ use of the Brexit vote to further the independence cause.

The failed approach has also led to calls for chief executive Peter Murrell, Sturgeonâ€™s husband, to stand down.

Despite losing his Moray seat, Robertson will stay on as deputy leader, while former investment Skye and Lochaber MP Ian Blackford takes on the job of Westminster leader.

Should support for Sturgeon continue to wane among the public, party insiders say â€œleader in waitingâ€ Robertson may soon find a way into Holyrood - either via a by-election or in 2021.

Robertson in the meantime will turn his talents to building the next case for independence, which must be watertight on its economics.

One of the resolutions is for a Bank of Scotland, suggesting the independence movement could back a breakaway national bank with its own â€˜Scottish poundâ€™.

Young firebrand Mhairi Black has previously said she would be prepared to play a leading role in the next independence campaign.

But, with the wider economic picture and the Brexit negotiations with Europe still so unclear, noone in the party is yet willing to champion a â€˜Brexit or Independenceâ€™ manifesto.

Mackay said: â€œAfter the Westminster elections, the First Minister herself said that we would revisit the issue [of a second independence referendum] in light of Brexit.â€

However, he added that scepticism for Brexit was growing UK-wide, hinting the SNPâ€™s strategy would not change substantially.
TITLE: What Next For Nicola Sturgeon's SNP After Their General Election Pummeling?

TEXT:
If you didnâ€™t know already, the year is not 1939.

And since that fateful annus horribilis the world has learned a number of important lessons, one of which is - being a Nazi isnâ€™t OK.

Evidence of this can be seen in the myriad of films, books, speeches, you name it, that not only condemn an ideology that propagates genocide but roundly mocks it.

Only now its 2017 and the rulebook of human decency was last seen somewhere on the US presidential election campaign last year.

So it is with a large *sigh* that we tell you that some people out there are actually upset at the trailer for Wolfenstein II, the latest iteration of a franchise that for years now has sold on the premise it allows gamers to, almost exclusively, kill Nazis.

Itâ€™s latest guise uses the slightly familiar slogan of â€œMake America Nazi-Free Againâ€, which appears to have upset some people.

Here are some of the replies...

The amount of people legitimately upset by the new Wolfenstein trailer is equal parts sad and hilarious pic.twitter.com/icrl0CfiyO â€” 88 Fingers (@YungShaxx) October 6, 2017

imagine seeing the words "no more nazis" and reacting like this pic.twitter.com/5L9b8CPm3s â€” Vylash #TeamKICK (@MiraVylash) October 6, 2017

Oh a Trump joke, because the subtext is advocating murder of Trump supporters. Pretty funny, devs! â€” Captain Red Skeleton (@mokraz1982) October 6, 2017

Yeah well I wasn't about to play a game about endlessly killing white people anyway. GTA San Andreas is more my speed. â€” GÃ¶tz (@Gotz_Iron_Hand) October 6, 2017

And then there were those who perhaps need to read a book or two.

Can't wait to america the heck out of some Krauts. I miss killing some commie fascists. Haven't done that since medal of Honor Frontline â€” SpookyScaryKirito (@justinhose) October 6, 2017
TITLE: Wolfenstein II Is Upsetting People Because It's About Killing Nazis

TEXT:
La troisiÃ¨me plus grosse banque espagnole va transfÃ©rer son siÃ¨ge social hors de la Catalogne.

ESPAGNE - La troisiÃ¨me banque espagnole, CaixaBank, a dÃ©cidÃ©, ce vendredi 6 octobre, de transfÃ©rer son siÃ¨ge social hors de Catalogne "en raison de la situation politique et sociale actuelle dans la rÃ©gion", selon un communiquÃ©.

Le domicile social sera transfÃ©rÃ© de Barcelone Ã  Valence (sud-est) afin d'assurer "la protection des clients, actionnaires et employÃ©s" et de sauvegarder sa "sÃ©curitÃ© juridique et rÃ©glementaire", prÃ©cise la banque, dont le cours en Bourse a lourdement chutÃ© cette semaine, alors que les autoritÃ©s sÃ©paratistes menacent de dÃ©clarer l'indÃ©pendance unilatÃ©ralement. Ce changement "n'implique pas de mouvements d'employÃ©s", souligne-t-elle.

Banco de Sabadell, la cinquiÃ¨me banque espagnole, et le groupe Gas Natural ont eux aussi dÃ©cidÃ© de transfÃ©rer leurs siÃ¨ges sociaux hors de Catalogne, pour les mÃªmes raisons.

Banque aprÃ¨s banque...

La puissante CaixaBank, emblÃ©matique en Catalogne comme ailleurs en Espagne, explique aussi vouloir "garantir Ã  tout moment sa prÃ©sence dans la zone euro, sous la supervision de la Banque centrale europÃ©enne (BCE)", qui reprÃ©sente pour elle une source vitale de financement. SUMMARY:
NASA will land humans on the Moon again, confirmed American Vice President Mike Pence in a speech yesterday.
Speaking at NASA, the Vice President revealed that the Trump administration will ask NASA to direct its efforts into establishing a permanent base on the lunar surface.
This is a major policy change from the Obama administration which directed NASA to divert all its efforts to getting humans to Mars.
How will NASA land humans on the Moon?
It was the longest Moon landing, contained the longest Moonwalks and involved the longest time spend in lunar orbit.
TEXT:
NASA will land humans on the Moon again, confirmed American Vice President Mike Pence in a speech yesterday.

Speaking at NASA, the Vice President revealed that the Trump administration will ask NASA to direct its efforts into establishing a permanent base on the lunar surface.

NASA. via Getty Images Buzz Aldrin walks by some scientific equipment on the surface of the Moon during the Apollo 11 mission.

This is a major policy change from the Obama administration which directed NASA to divert all its efforts to getting humans to Mars.

While Mars is still very much on the agenda, it now looks as though the Moon will become the first step in that journey.

Speaking at the National Space Council meeting, Vice President Pence said that for too long America had not travelled beyond our own orbit.

You can watch the entire speech here:

Initially NASA had planned to test out its Mars mission by sending astronauts to an asteroid, however this will now be scrapped in favour of lunar missions instead.

How will NASA land humans on the Moon?

While thereâ€™s no official word from NASA it seems likely that the organisation will simply use the same spacecraft that it is currently developing for Mars: Orion and the Space Launch System rocket.

TOBIAS SCHWARZ via Getty Images

This would also tie in rather nicely with NASAâ€™s recent agreement with Russiaâ€™s own space agency Roscosmos to build a Deep Space Gateway space station either on the lunar surface or orbiting around it.

Interestingly, the origins of both Orion and the SLS lie with the Moon. Both programs had initially been given the green light by the Bush administration as part of an earlier restarting of the lunar mission program.

When was the last Moon mission?

The last time humans landed on the Moon was Apollo 17, in 1972.

It was a mission of endings as well, marking the last time that the Apollo spacecraft and Saturn V rocket would be used to send humans to the Moon. It was also the last time that humans travelled beyond low-Earth orbit.

NASA. via Getty Images

Apollo 17 was also a mission filled with records. It was the longest Moon landing, contained the longest Moonwalks and involved the longest time spend in lunar orbit.
TITLE: NASA Will Land Humans On the Moon Again

SUMMARY:
Lisa Wilkinson and husband Peter FitzSimons have continued their 25th wedding anniversary celebrations by saying 'I do' for the second time.
The pair -- who first wed in 1992 -- met after being introduced to each other by '60 Minutes' reporter Liz Hayes and according to FitzSimons, they "didn't muck around".
It was on a Sunday night, and I said: I'm tired of this, will you marry me?'
And she said: 'Yes, I will marry you'," he told Mia Freedman.
The pair are parents to Jake, 23, Louis, 21 and Billi, 19.
TEXT:
Lisa Wilkinson and husband Peter FitzSimons have continued their 25th wedding anniversary celebrations by saying 'I do' for the second time.

The pair -- who first wed in 1992 -- met after being introduced to each other by '60 Minutes' reporter Liz Hayes and according to FitzSimons, they "didn't muck around".

"It just felt right. It didn't feel hard. It was on a Sunday night, and I said: I'm tired of this, will you marry me?' And she said: 'Yes, I will marry you'," he told Mia Freedman.

We just got married...again! â¤ï¸â¤ï¸â¤ï¸ #25years #25thanniversary #sohappy #Ido ğŸ“·: @carlottamoye A post shared by Lisa Wilkinson (@lisa_wilkinson) on Oct 7, 2017 at 1:32am PDT

Wilkinson -- who is HuffPost Australia's Editor-at-large -- has previously said that even after a quarter of a century of marriage, she and FitzSimons remain absolutely smitten with each other.

"He's a fantastic dad," she told the 9Honey podcast.

"In terms of his professional life ... I think he's an exquisite writer he makes me cry constantly."

You may kiss your stunning bride â¤ï¸ #lisa&petegetmarried @lisa_wilkinson #25thanniversary A post shared by Carlotta Moye ğŸ“· (@carlottamoye) on Oct 7, 2017 at 1:21am PDT

Last week, Wilkinson posted a photo of the pair on their original wedding day saying that she "couldn't be more in love or grateful for the family we've built together".

The pair are parents to Jake, 23, Louis, 21 and Billi, 19.
TITLE: Lisa Wilkinson Celebrates 25th Wedding Anniversary By Saying 'I Do'

Nous devons commencer par rÃ©flÃ©chir Ã  notre organisation. La majoritÃ© des militants RÃ©publicains et UDI est aujourd'hui convaincue que la crÃ©ation de l'UMP fut une erreur majeure. Nous avons sciÃ© les branches historiques de la droite, gaullisme et centrisme, incarnÃ©es par le RPR et l'UDF, pour une entitÃ© abstraite sans racines, qui, avec le temps, a vu la gauche et le Front national lui rogner les ailes.

Le RPR Ã©tait bonapartiste, populaire, social, eurosceptique et jacobin. L'UDF Ã©tait girondine, europÃ©enne et patronale. Les procÃ¨s en "droitisation" ou en "gauchisation" n'existaient pas. S'il arrivait Ã  ses partis de s'affronter Ã©lectoralement, parfois fÃ©rocement, la nÃ©cessitÃ© de forger des alliances pour l'emporter Ã  terme, Ã©tait bien prÃ©sente Ã  l'esprit de tous leurs membres.

Ceux qui pensent de bonne foi, car ils sont attachÃ©s au pragmatisme Ã©conomique, qu'Emmanuel Macron va dans le bon sens, se trompent et s'en apercevront bientÃ´t. Les ordonnances travail ne sont pas la rÃ©volution annoncÃ©e et resteront sans effet sur l'Ã©conomie rÃ©elle. Les mesures fiscales, les mesures en matiÃ¨re de logement sont toujours les produits de la machine technocratique de Bercy oÃ¹ les ministres se succÃ¨dent sans impact rÃ©el. La loi de moralisation de la vie politique fut un exercice d'autodÃ©nigrement inutile et dommageable sur le long terme car c'est l'efficacitÃ© du politique qui permettra de renouer avec les citoyens et non une transparence dÃ©voyÃ©e rÃ©vÃ©lant son indigence.

La droite franÃ§aise a perdu le gaullisme ou plutÃ´t elle l'a abandonnÃ© au profit d'un modernisme dÃ©pourvu de sens, devenu religion. Malheureusement pour elle, Emmanuel Macron, plus promÃ©thÃ©en que jupitÃ©rien en l'occurrence, lui a volÃ© le feu modernisateur, la laissant contempler le sentiment de sa propre inutilitÃ©. Afin de parer Ã  cela, je veux remettre du sens dans notre droite. Le sens de la Nation, celui de l'Etat, de l'intÃ©rÃªt gÃ©nÃ©ral. Mon obsession n'est pas la droite forte mais la France et l'Etat forts. Mon souhait est que notre politique soit celle de l'humain d'abord et non celle des critÃ¨res du pacte de stabilitÃ© europÃ©en. Mon espoir est que notre famille soit capable de porter les idÃ©es nouvelles sur l'indÃ©pendance Ã©nergÃ©tique, la prÃ©servation de notre environnement et le bien-Ãªtre au travail. Le gaullisme n'est pas populiste, il est populaire ; il n'est pas autoritaire il est fort ; il n'est pas technocratique, il est humain, il n'est pas idÃ©ologue, il est pragmatique.

Ma droite est celle de l'enracinement contre le nomadisme, celle de la primautÃ© de la responsabilitÃ© individuelle sur la responsabilitÃ© collective, celle qui prend en compte le monde tel qu'il est et non tel que l'on aimerait qu'il soit pour Ã©laborer un projet, celle pour qui la Nation est l'horizon indÃ©passable de la dÃ©mocratie, celle d'une France, franÃ§aise dans sa culture et son histoire et enfin celle d'une France oÃ¹ l'Etat ne dicte pas Ã  chacun, tout le temps, la maniÃ¨re dont il doit vivre sa vie.

Ma droite est gaulliste, nationale, humaniste, sociale, populaire, patriote, volontariste en Ã©conomie, pro-entrepreneurs et pro-salariÃ©s, voilÃ  ce que j'aimerai pour mon parti, voilÃ  le sens de ma candidature.

TITLE: Ce que je souhaite pour l'avenir des RÃ©publicains

Protests have broken out across Russia on Putinâ€™s birthday as supporters of opposition leader Alexie Navalny demand that he be allowed to join the presidential race.
The wave of demonstrations on the 65th birthday of President Vladimir Putin comes as Navalny serves a 20-day jail term for calling for an unsanctioned protest.
The opposition leaderâ€™s headquarters said protests would be held in nearly 80 Russian cities, the Press Association reported.
Rallies numbering from a few dozen to a few hundred people were held in several cities in Russiaâ€™s far east and Siberia.
Most of the demonstrations have not been sanctioned by authorities, and police have reportedly detained protesters and activists in some cities.
TEXT:
Protests have broken out across Russia on Putinâ€™s birthday as supporters of opposition leader Alexie Navalny demand that he be allowed to join the presidential race.

The wave of demonstrations on the 65th birthday of President Vladimir Putin comes as Navalny serves a 20-day jail term for calling for an unsanctioned protest.

The opposition leaderâ€™s headquarters said protests would be held in nearly 80 Russian cities, the Press Association reported.

Rallies numbering from a few dozen to a few hundred people were held in several cities in Russiaâ€™s far east and Siberia.

Most of the demonstrations have not been sanctioned by authorities, and police have reportedly detained protesters and activists in some cities.

In Moscow, several hundred protesters, most of them young, gathered in Pushkinskaya Square, waving Russian flags and chanting â€œRussia will be free!â€ and â€œFree Navalny!â€

Anadolu Agency via Getty Images Alexei Navalny supporters in Moscow

Police warned the demonstrators that the rally has not been sanctioned and urged them to disperse, but did not immediately move to break up the protest.

Police and the National Guard showed up in full force in central Moscow and in St Petersburg, where a rally is set to be held later.

Navalny has declared his intention to run for president in the March election, even though a criminal conviction he calls politically motivated bars him from running.

OLGA MALTSEVA via Getty Images Russian police officers detain a supporter of opposition leader Alexei Navalny during an unauthorized rally in Saint Petersburg

The 41-year-old anti-corruption crusader has organised several waves of protests this year, casting a challenge to the Kremlin.

Putin has not yet announced his intention to seek re-election, but he is widely expected to run. With his current approval ratings topping 80%, he is set to win another six-year term in a race against torpid veterans of past election campaigns, like Communist Party chief Gennady Zyuganov.

Navalny argued that a high level of support for Putin results from the lack of real political competition and urged his supporters to help him get registered for the race.

â€œThe 86% approval rating exists in a political vacuum,â€ he said. â€œItâ€™s like asking a person who has been fed with rutabaga through his entire life how eatable they find it and the rating will be quite high. Listen, there are other things which are better than rutabaga.â€

The sarcastic analogy demonstrated his stinging style, which has recently helped him get broad support among youths. He has worked to expand his reach with videos exposing official corruption and YouTube live broadcasts.

His documentary about prime minister Dmitry Medvedevâ€™s alleged ill-gotten wealth has been viewed nearly 25 million times since its release in early March, helping galvanise protests.
TITLE: Protests Held In 'Almost 80' Russian Cities On Putin's Birthday Over Presidential Race

TEXT:
Streit um UnabhÃ¤ngigkeit spitzt sich zu: Spaniens Verfassungsgericht verbietet Plenarsitzung in Katalonien | dpa

Die spanische Regierung zeigt sich im Katalonienkonflikt hart und versucht alles, um die UnabhÃ¤ngigkeitsbewegung zu stoppen

Nun verbietet das Verfassungsgericht den Separatisten im Regionalparlament zusammenzukommen

Manche warnen schon vor einem BÃ¼rgerkrieg

Die spanische Regierung versucht alles, um die immer schneller rollende UnabhÃ¤ngigkeitsbewegung in Katalonien noch zu stoppen.

Nun gibt es den nÃ¤chsten Versuch: Wenige Tage vor der erwarteten UnabhÃ¤ngigkeitserklÃ¤rung der nordwestlichen Region hat das spanische Verfassungsgericht die dafÃ¼r vorgesehene Sitzung des katalanischen Parlamentes untersagt.

Dies berichteten spanische Medien am Donnerstag unter Berufung auf Justizkreise. Die katalanischen Sozialisten (PSC) - strikte Gegner der Separatisten - hatten Beschwerde gegen die geplante Sitzung eingereicht, weil sie die Verfassung verletzte und die Rechte der Abgeordneten missachte.

Das Regionalparlament wollte am kommenden Montag zusammentreten, um die Konsequenzen aus dem Volksabstimmung zu ziehen, bei der sich die groÃŸe Mehrzahl der Abstimmenden fÃ¼r die UnabhÃ¤ngigkeit von Spanien ausgesprochen hatte. Schon das Referendum war von der Justiz untersagt worden - ohne Konsequenzen.

An der Abstimmung hatten sich 42 Prozent der Stimmberechtigten beteiligt, 90 Prozent stimmten fÃ¼r die UnabhÃ¤ngigkeit. Jedoch waren die Gegner einer Abspaltung der Wahl Ã¼berwiegend ferngeblieben.

â¨ Mehr zum Thema: Der Katalonien-Konflikt gilt als Freiheitskampf - doch er ist vor allem ein Duell rigoroser Nationalisten

Kein Dialog mit der Regionalregierung

Der spanische MinisterprÃ¤sident Mariano Rajoy lehnt jeden Dialog mit der Regionalregierung Kataloniens ab.

In der Nacht zum Donnerstag wies er ein neues GesprÃ¤chsangebot der Separatisten energisch zurÃ¼ck. "Sie haben schon viel Schaden verursacht, ziehen Sie die Drohung einer Abspaltung zurÃ¼ck", hieÃŸ es in einem KommuniquÃ© an die Adresse des katalanischen Regierungschefs Carles Puigdemont.

Puigdemont hatte Madrid zuvor zu Verhandlungen aufgerufen. Er habe bereits viele Vermittlungsangebote erhalten und "es wÃ¤re unverantwortlich", diese nicht anzunehmen, erklÃ¤rte der 54-JÃ¤hrige in einer Fernsehansprache in Barcelona. Gleichzeitig stellte er klar, dass die PlÃ¤ne zur Ausrufung der UnabhÃ¤ngigkeit auf jeden Fall verwirklicht werden sollen.

Spanischen Medien zufolge werde es immer wahrscheinlicher, dass die Regierung versuche, die Regionalregierung zu entmachten und die Kontrolle Ã¼ber die autonome Region zu Ã¼bernehmen.

Oettinger: "BÃ¼rgerkrieg mitten in Europa"

EU-Kommissar GÃ¼nther Oettinger (CDU) warnte derweil vor der Gefahr einer dramatischen Eskalation: "Die Lage ist sehr, sehr besorgniserregend. Da ist ein BÃ¼rgerkrieg vorstellbar, mitten in Europa", sagte er bei einer Podiumsdiskussion in MÃ¼nchen.

"Man kann nur hoffen, dass zwischen Madrid und Barcelona bald ein GesprÃ¤chsfaden aufgenommen wird." Die EU kÃ¶nne sich in den Streit aber nicht aus eigenem Antrieb einmischen. "Eine Moderation durch die EU wÃ¤re nur denkbar, wenn wir gefragt werden, aber nicht ungefragt", betonte Oettinger.

â¨ Mehr zum Thema: Konflikt um Katalonien: Wie eine verfassungswidrige Abstimmung eine politische und soziale Krise auslÃ¶st

TEXT:
Die CSU hat bei der Bundestagswahl das schlechteste Ergebnis seit 1949 erzielt

Daher fordert die Partei nun umso lauter eine VerschÃ¤rfung der FlÃ¼chtlingspolitik

6 Zitate zeigen, wie absurd die Diskussion Ã¼ber die Obergrenze mittlerweile ist

Deutschland braucht eine Regierung - aber die CSU braucht Aufmerksamkeit. Also blockieren die Christsozialen die BemÃ¼hungen von FDP, GrÃ¼nen und CDU bei den Verhandlungen zur GrÃ¼ndung einer Jamaika-Koalition.

Zum Beispiel, indem sie offen die Partnerschaft mit der Schwesterpartei CDU in Frage stellen. Vor allem aber, indem die CSU bei jeder sich bietenden Gelegenheit auf ihre Forderung nach einer Obergrenze fÃ¼r FlÃ¼chtlinge pocht.

Dass FDP, GrÃ¼ne und CDU die Festlegung einer solche BeschrÃ¤nkung fÃ¼r Asylsuchende ablehnen, dass der Vorsitzende des Bundesverfassungsgerichts, Andreas VoÃŸkuhle, sie fÃ¼r unvereinbar mit dem VÃ¶lkerrecht hÃ¤lt - dass Deutschland dafÃ¼r womÃ¶glich sogar aus der Genfer FlÃ¼chtlingskonvention aussteigen mÃ¼sste: Der CSU ist es egal.

Die Lokalpartei will ihren bayerischen Stiefel durchziehen - sie muss es, denn an der Basis rumort, es nach dem schwÃ¤chsten Wahlergebnis seit 1949.

Und so wird die Obergrenzen-Diskussion zum Zwergenaufstand. Hier sind die 6 absurdesten Zitate und Aussagen in der CSU-Posse:

1. Alexander Dobrindt: "Die CSU ist die einzige Volkspartei"

38,8 Prozent der Wahlberechtigten in Bayern haben die CSU bei der Bundestagswahl gewÃ¤hlt. Bundesweit macht das einen Anteil von 6,2 Prozent der abgegebenen Stimmen. Rechnet man diesen Anteil auf die GesamtbevÃ¶lkerung um, haben 4,62 Prozent der Deutschen die bayerischen Christsozialen gewÃ¤hlt - etwas mehr als 3,8 Millionen Menschen.

Die CSU ist also eine Kleinpartei. In ihrem SelbstverstÃ¤ndnis ist dieser Umstand jedoch noch nicht angelangt. Und so sagte Alexander Dobrindt am Freitag dem Magazin "Focus": "Die CSU ist aktuell die einzige Volkspartei. Sie ist modern und in der politischen Struktur der Bundesrepublik unverzichtbar."

Kein Wunder, dass die Partei also glaubt, beim Thema Obergrenze auch bundesweite AnsprÃ¼che stellen zu kÃ¶nnen.

2. Nochmal Dobrindt: "Die Obergrenze hat einen thematischen Unterbau"

Dabei weiÃŸ die Partei, wie unpopulÃ¤r sie sich damit macht. Eine ihrer Taktiken ist deswegen: Die Obergrenze fordern - aber jeden Tag etwas anderes damit zu meinen.

Eigentlich ist die CSU-Definition der FlÃ¼chtlings-Obergrenze klar: Mehr als 200.000 Asylsuchende im Jahr sollen nicht nach Deutschland einreisen dÃ¼rfen. Doch gleich mehrere der bayerischen Lokalpolitiker haben diese Definition zuletzt aufgeweicht.

FederfÃ¼hrend war dabei Verkehrsminister Dobrindt. Der reinterpretierte den Begriff in einem Interview mit der "Augsburger Allgemeinen": "Die Obergrenze hat einen thematischen Unterbau und der heiÃŸt: Fluchtursachen bekÃ¤mpfen, Grenzen schÃ¼tzen, Integration fÃ¶rdern, RÃ¼ckfÃ¼hrungen beschleunigen."

3. Joachim Herrmann: "Es hat in der CSU-FÃ¼hrung nie jemand von einer BeschrÃ¤nkung des Asylrechts gesprochen"

In der FlÃ¼chtlingspolitik ist Bayerns Innenminister Joachim Herrmann ein Mann der harten Phrasen. Er fordert gern einmal hÃ¤rtere Grenzkontrollen, Smartphone-Verbote oder die prÃ¤ventive Gefangennahme und Aussetzung der Unschuldsvermutung fÃ¼r islamistische GefÃ¤hrder.

Auch die Obergrenze fordert Herrmann immer wieder - wenngleich er fortwÃ¤hrend betont, dass in Deutschland das Asylrecht gelte.

So sagte Herrmann der "Rheinischen Post" zuletzt: "Es hat in der CSU-FÃ¼hrung nie jemand von einer BeschrÃ¤nkung des Asylrechts gesprochen."

Das eine Obergrenze genau das zur Folge hÃ¤tte - wen kÃ¼mmert's?

4. Horst Seehofer: "Wir garantieren eine Obergrenze nach der Wahl"

Horst Seehofer schon mal nicht. Der verkÃ¼ndete im vergangenen Dezember vollmundig: "Wir garantieren eine Obergrenze nach der Wahl." Auf die Nachfrage, ob die CSU sonst in die Opposition gehe, sagte Seehofer: "Das haben Sie richtig verstanden."

Im August ruderte der CSU-Chef dann zurÃ¼ck. Die Zeiten im politischen Berlin hÃ¤tten sich geÃ¤ndert - und Ã¼berhaupt, die Zuwanderungszahlen seien ja nun zurÃ¼ckgegangen.

Da war die Obergrenze fÃ¼r Seehofer auf einmal keine Koalitionsbedingung mehr.

Parteikollege Dobrindt scheint das allerdings nicht mitbekommen zu haben. Er bekrÃ¤ftigte erst am Donnerstag, die Obergrenze sei fÃ¼r die CSU "nicht verhandelbar".

5. Angela Merkel: "Mit der CDU wird es eine Obergrenze nicht geben"

Das ist in der Tat ungÃ¼nstig. Denn das gleiche gilt fÃ¼r Bundeskanzlerin Angela Merkel.

Die hatte schon im vergangenen Jahr deutlich gemacht: "Mit der CDU wird es eine Obergrenze nicht geben." Bei ihrem ARD-Sommerinterview im Juli legte Merkel nach: "Zur Obergrenze ist meine Haltung klar: Das heiÃŸt, ich werde sie nicht akzeptieren."

Merkels klare Haltung zeigt, wie unsinnig die stÃ¶rrische Haltung der CSU bei der Obergrenze ist. Die Kanzlerin wird sich nicht von ihrem bayerischen Lokalpartner vorfÃ¼hren lassen. DafÃ¼r mÃ¼sste dieser dann schon tatsÃ¤chlich in die Opposition gehen - und das wÃ¼rde der CSU genauso schaden, wie der CDU.

6. Wolfgang SchÃ¤uble: "Juristen wissen, dass Ã¼berflÃ¼ssige Dinge nicht extra erwÃ¤hnt werden mÃ¼ssen"

Und so war es an Wolfgang SchÃ¤uble, Ende der vergangenen Woche der CSU den Spiegel vorzuhalten.

Der scheidende Finanzminister zeigte sich in einem Interview mit der "Bild am Sonntag" spÃ¼rbar genervt. "Hier wird um einen Begriff ein Scheinstreit gefÃ¼hrt, obwohl es inhaltlich keine wirklichen Differenzen gibt", sagte SchÃ¤uble.

Zwar erklÃ¤rte SchÃ¤uble auch, in der FlÃ¼chtlingspolitik gelte, was der ehemalige BundesprÃ¤sident Joachim Gauck gesagt habe: "Unser Herz ist groÃŸ, unsere MÃ¶glichkeiten sind begrenzt." Auf die Hilfsbereitschaft der Deutschen wÃ¼rden kommende Generationen stolz sein, die Ordnung mÃ¼sse in der BewÃ¤ltigung der FlÃ¼chtlingskrise aber bewahrt werden.

Angesprochen auf die Obergrenze sagte SchÃ¤uble jedoch in Richtung der CSU: "Juristen wissen, dass Ã¼berflÃ¼ssige Dinge nicht extra erwÃ¤hnt werden mÃ¼ssen."

Und ewig grÃ¼ÃŸt die Obergrenze

Doch die CSU tut genau das, aus einem guten Grund.

Denn die bayerischen Konservativen haben fÃ¼r sich schon immer in Anspruch genommen, der Ausdruck des Volkswillens zu sein. Das galt bei der MÃ¼tterrente und der PKW-Maut - und das gilt in der FlÃ¼chtlingspolitik.

Und tatsÃ¤chlich: Laut einer aktuellen Umfrage will eine Mehrheit der Deutschen, dass eine FlÃ¼chtlings-Obergrenze eingefÃ¼hrt wird. 54 Prozent der Befragten sprachen sich dafÃ¼r aus.

Das reicht der CSU als Rechtfertigung. Die EinfÃ¼hrung einer Obergrenze wird dadurch nicht wahrscheinlicher - ebenso wenig wie die Bildung einer Jamaika-Koalition.

Aber die Aufmerksamkeit der Republik, die ist der CSU gewiss. Und das ist schon einmal was, in diesen schwierigen Zeiten fÃ¼r die Konservativen.

(mf)
TITLE: Zwergenaufstand: Die merkwÃ¼rdige Obergrenzen-Posse der CSU in 6 Zitaten

SUMMARY:
Who actually led the sexual revolution?
While one cannot deny the major cultural influence that Hefner had on the sexual revolution, but his was not an intersectional or a feminist one.
But it was just a sexual revolution for him, not anyone else.
Itâ€™s astonishing how people have come to adore Hefner, a straight man, as the leader of the sexual revolution when his sexual virility has never been questioned.
His success came as a result of the sexual revolution, but he is not its cause.
TEXT:
Who actually led the sexual revolution? Iâ€™ll give you a hint, it wasnâ€™t Hugh Hefner. When Hefner, the creator of Playboy Magazine, died on September 28th, an Associated Press writer splashed across the headline, â€œHugh Hefner, leader of the sexual revolution, dies at 91.â€

The sexual revolution was a movement during the 1960s and 70s that moved away from the strict moral codes that disapproved of sexual expression, and instead embracing sexual desire and moving beyond heteronormative standards. Hefner launched Playboy in 1953, known for its naked models, the magazine is credited with normalizing nudity during this era and moving a once forbidden subject into mainstream discussions. But Hefnerâ€™s magazine wasnâ€™t uprooting any social norms, instead reinforcing patriarchal ideas about a womanâ€™s role as an object, this time just without clothes.

While one cannot deny the major cultural influence that Hefner had on the sexual revolution, but his was not an intersectional or a feminist one. He built his fame exploiting women, and justified it by calling it sexual liberation. But it was just a sexual revolution for him, not anyone else. Itâ€™s astonishing how people have come to adore Hefner, a straight man, as the leader of the sexual revolution when his sexual virility has never been questioned. His success came as a result of the sexual revolution, but he is not its cause.

That revolution belongs to the queer folks and feminists who fought against the strict standards that forbid them from expressing their sexualities. It belongs to the women who for once could acknowledge and discuss their sexualities and personal pleasures, instead of just for their partner. It belongs to the gay, lesbian, trans and asexual folks who fought for the ability to express sexualities openly, despite the heavy harassment and violence they faced.

So instead of heralding Hefner as its leader, letâ€™s celebrate the pioneers of the sexual revolution. Here are five true pioneers of the sexual revolution, who paved the way for the activists of today by fostering the open discussions about pornography, sexuality, contraception and nudity.

Helen Gurley Brown

For 32 years Helen Gurley Brown served as the Editor-in-Chief of Cosmopolitan. Todayâ€™s monthly sex advice is seen as sexist, but at the time it was revolutionary to even acknowledge that a woman could want to have sex. Brown redefined Cosmo to catered towards career women who were sexually active. The magazine discussed reproductive health and in 1962, she published Sex and the Single Girl, which insinuated a then unthinkable notion, that a woman could be sexual satisifed, ambitious and single.

Marsha P. Johnson

Johnson was African American trans-woman who co-founded Street Transvestites Action Revolutionaries (S.T.A.R.) in New Yorkâ€™s Greenwich Village, providing support and shelter for homeless LGBTQ folks. She played a central role in the Stonewall Riots in 1969, and would remain active in the gay organizing that took place following the riot. Her body was found in the Hudson River in 1992 in what was ruled a suicide, while friends insisted it was murder.

Estelle Griswold

1954 to 1965, Griswold was the Executive Director of the Planned Parenthood League of Connecticut, a state which forbid women from purchasing any kind of birth control. Griswold opened a birth control clinic in New Haven, Connecticut for which she was arrested. She fought back, taking the case to the Supreme Court in Griswold v. Connecticut which would not only overturned the law and allowed women to purchase contraception, but established the right to privacy.

Pat Maginnis

Pat Maginnis was one of the earliest abortion rights activists. Maginnis herself had gone to Mexico to have an abortion, but struggled to find a safe abortionist. While she was in college she founded Citizens Committee for Humane Abortion Laws to educate people about abortions, contraception and the dangers of self-induced abortions. Later, in 1966, she founded Association to Repeal Abortion Laws, an organization we know today as NARAL. The Association to Repeal Abortion Laws connected pregnant women with illegal abortion providers, allowing women access to safe abortions.

Betty Dodson
TITLE: Who Actually Led the Sexual Revolution? (Hint: It's Not Hugh Hefner)

Tout cet amour qu'elles nous ont montrÃ© Ã  ce moment, Ã§a m'a beaucoup aidÃ©e", a-t-elle racontÃ© Ã  la presse amÃ©ricaine. "Ã‡a m'a surtout poussÃ©e Ã  devenir aussi gentille et compatissante qu'elles l'ont Ã©tÃ© avec moi"!

C'est son passÃ© qui lui a permis de trouver sa vocation: devenir, elle aussi, infirmiÃ¨re. "Une fois que j'ai intÃ©grÃ© mon Ã©cole, je voulais uniquement me diriger vers l'oncologie pÃ©diatrique (le service dÃ©diÃ© aux enfants souffrant d'un cancer). Je ne voulais rien faire d'autre. Je suis allÃ©e Ã  l'Ã©cole uniquement pour Ã§a", explique-t-elle.

Aujourd'hui, nouvellement diplÃ´mÃ©e, elle a rÃ©alisÃ© son rÃªve. Elle espÃ¨re maintenant Ãªtre une source d'inspiration pour tous les enfants qui luttent, comme elle l'a fait. SUMMARY:
If chocolate ganache-stuffed brioche French toast topped with whipped cream, chocolate chips and more ganache sounds like a heavenly mouthful, prepare yourself for a chocolate coma.
With three different chocolate elements, this rich French toast recipe is not for the faint-hearted.
To create this death-by-chocolate breakfast, start by making the easy chocolate ganache (which you'll use to stuff the brioche and drizzle on top of the finished dish).
Fill the pockets with chocolate ganache, then place the slices into the chocolate milk mixture to soak up all the good stuff.
All that's left to do is cook the French toast in a frying pan with butter and serve with whipped cream (or ice cream), chocolate chips and an extra drizzle of ganache.
TEXT:
If chocolate ganache-stuffed brioche French toast topped with whipped cream, chocolate chips and more ganache sounds like a heavenly mouthful, prepare yourself for a chocolate coma.

With three different chocolate elements, this rich French toast recipe is not for the faint-hearted.

To create this death-by-chocolate breakfast, start by making the easy chocolate ganache (which you'll use to stuff the brioche and drizzle on top of the finished dish). Then it's time to make the chocolate milk mixture to place the brioche into before frying.

To stuff the slices of brioche with ganache, simply cut a wide slit into the bottom of each slice to create a pocket. Fill the pockets with chocolate ganache, then place the slices into the chocolate milk mixture to soak up all the good stuff.

All that's left to do is cook the French toast in a frying pan with butter and serve with whipped cream (or ice cream), chocolate chips and an extra drizzle of ganache. Yep, whoa.

Check out the video above and follow the full recipe here.
TITLE: Watch: How To Make Chocolate French Toast

CPOLÃ‰MIQUE - L'association la Voix de l'enfant s'est "indignÃ©e" vendredi 6 octobre de propos du chanteur Jean-Luc Lahaye, condamnÃ© pour corruption de mineure, qui dÃ©clare dans la bande-annonce d'un film bientÃ´t Ã  l'affiche que "ses copines sont au lycÃ©e".

Dans un communiquÃ©, l'association de protection des droits de l'enfant "s'indigne que de tels propos puissent Ãªtre tenus par le chanteur dans la bande-annonce d'un film dont la diffusion est majeure" et demande que "ce passage rÃ©vÃ©lant Ã  nouveau son attirance pour des lycÃ©ennes et faisant rÃ©fÃ©rence Ã  sa condamnation soit retirÃ©".

"La plaisanterie litigieuse, consistant en un trait d'humour ironique et dÃ©risoire, s'inscrit uniquement dans le caractÃ¨re comique de la rÃ©alisation et correspond strictement au script du film, dont Jean-Luc Lahaye n'est ni le dialoguiste, ni le rÃ©alisateur ni le producteur", a rÃ©agi l'avocat du chanteur, Me Jean-Baptiste Jacquenet-Poillot, Ã©galement dans un communiquÃ©.

Ce dernier a soulignÃ© que son client n'avait "jamais eu la moindre intention de blesser, de choquer ni de heurter quiconque" et qu'il regrettait "vivement si cela a pu Ãªtre le cas". "Jean-Luc Lahaye tient exprimer sa dÃ©solation face Ã  la une telle polÃ©mique ainsi qu'aux intentions qu'on lui prÃªte", a encore dit Me Jacquenet-Poillot

Jean-Luc Lahaye, 64 ans, a Ã©tÃ© condamnÃ© Ã  un an d'emprisonnement avec sursis le 18 mai 2015 pour corruption de mineure, pour avoir demandÃ© Ã  une jeune fille de 14 ans de s'adonner Ã  des jeux sexuels par webcam interposÃ©e. La Voix de l'enfant s'Ã©tait portÃ©e partie civile dans ce procÃ¨s.

L'ISF (impÃ´t sur la fortune) tel qu'on le connaÃ®t va disparaÃ®tre pour devenir un "impÃ´t sur la fortune immobiliÃ¨re" (IFI), de faÃ§on Ã  exempter de taxes les valeurs mobiliÃ¨res et les placements (actions, assurance-vie...).
Dans une chronique publiÃ©e par Le Monde ce samedi 7 octobre, l'Ã©conomiste classÃ© Ã  gauche -il a notamment participÃ© Ã  la campagne prÃ©sidentielle de BenoÃ®t Hamon- dÃ©nonce "une lourde faute morale, Ã©conomique et historique.
Entre 1980 et 2016, "le patrimoine des 1 % les plus fortunÃ©s, qui comprend plus de 70 % d'actifs financiers, est passÃ© de 1,4 Ã  4,5 millions d'euros", s'indigne-t-il.
Et de conclure en qualifiant l'instauration Ã  venir de l'IFI de "stratagÃ¨me politique [...] pour Ã©viter d'afficher une suppression sÃ¨che de l'ISF", avant d'appeler les dÃ©putÃ©s Ã  ne pas "se prÃªter Ã  une telle mascarade".

TEXT:
POLITIQUE - Une transformation qui passe mal. L'ISF (impÃ´t sur la fortune) tel qu'on le connaÃ®t va disparaÃ®tre pour devenir un "impÃ´t sur la fortune immobiliÃ¨re" (IFI), de faÃ§on Ã  exempter de taxes les valeurs mobiliÃ¨res et les placements (actions, assurance-vie...).

IntÃ©grÃ©e dans le projet de budget 2018, la mesure est censÃ©e stimuler l'activitÃ© en encourageant les contribuables les plus aisÃ©s Ã  investir dans "l'Ã©conomie rÃ©elle" et devrait entraÃ®ner un manque Ã  gagner de prÃ¨s de 3,2 milliards d'euros pour l'Ã‰tat. De quoi faire monter au crÃ©neau la gauche, qui dÃ©nonce un "cadeau fiscal". D'autant que les "produits ostentatoires", tels que les yachts ou les jets privÃ©s, pourraient Ãªtre exemptÃ©s - mÃªme si la majoritÃ© a l'intention d'y remÃ©dier.

"Totalement Ã  cÃ´tÃ© de la plaque"

Parmi ces critiques, celle de Thomas Piketty ne passe pas inaperÃ§ue. Dans une chronique publiÃ©e par Le Monde ce samedi 7 octobre, l'Ã©conomiste classÃ© Ã  gauche -il a notamment participÃ© Ã  la campagne prÃ©sidentielle de BenoÃ®t Hamon- dÃ©nonce "une lourde faute morale, Ã©conomique et historique. Cette dÃ©cision montre une profonde incomprÃ©hension des dÃ©fis inÃ©galitaires posÃ©s par la mondialisation".

ITV/Rex/Shutterstock Come on Cheryl, you could have thrown a few leaves or something on that outfitEarlier this year, she announced that sheâ€™d be back as Simonâ€™s right-hand woman at Judgesâ€™ Houses, only to eventually be ditched in favour of Cheryl.

TEXT:
Well, one of the worst-kept secrets in â€˜X Factorâ€™ history has officially been confirmed, with Cheryl Tweedy having posed with Simon Cowell as she makes her return to Judgesâ€™ Houses.

As was reported earlier in the series, Cheryl will be helping the music mogul whittle down his remaining acts down at the final stage of the competition before live shows, after two years away from the show.

While weâ€™re sure Cherylâ€™s fans will be excited to see back on the show that helped catapult her to national treasure status, one person who wonâ€™t be impressed is â€˜So Machoâ€™ singer, Sinitta.

ITV/Rex/Shutterstock Come on Cheryl, you could have thrown a few leaves or something on that outfit

Earlier this year, she announced that sheâ€™d be back as Simonâ€™s right-hand woman at Judgesâ€™ Houses, only to eventually be ditched in favour of Cheryl.

Sinitta recently fumed: â€œI will always love Simon. He is like a father figure meets brother figure and ex-lover figure to me, and of course my mentor for over three decades - but right now he can kiss my black ass.â€

Ken McKay/TalkbackThames/REX/Shutterstock That's a bit more like it

Cheryl first joined the show almost a decade ago in 2008, when she was still a member of girl group Girls Aloud, until eventually stepping down in 2011, after she and Simon fell out when he sacked her from the US version of the show.

In 2014, she and Simon buried the hatchet, and she spent two more series as a judge, until eventually bidding farewell for a second time, claiming she wanted to focus more on her career as a singer, rather than a TV talent show judge.

Among other stars helping out at Judgesâ€™ Houses will be Stormzy, appearing alongside Nicole Scherzinger, as well as Jack and Kelly Osbourne, who will be serving as advisers to their mum, Sharon Osbourne.

Meanwhile, itâ€™s thought that Louis Walsh will get a helping hand from â€˜Grace Kellyâ€™ singer Mika, who serves as a judge on the Italian version of â€˜X Factorâ€™, even claiming he learned Italian especially for the job.

Cheryl's Best 'X Factor' Moments
TITLE: Cheryl Tweedy's 'X Factor' Return Confirmed, In First Pic With Simon Cowell At Judges' Houses

Il en va ainsi Ã  chaque automne. La saison des Prix LittÃ©raire dÃ©bute avec son cortÃ¨ge de parutions attendues et son graal, le prix Goncourt. Rien de tout cela pour la secteur musical (Ã  l'exception Ã  une toute autre Ã©chelle du Disquaire Day).

Bien sÃ»r, la sortie franÃ§aise d'un nouvel album de Johnny Halliday Ã  grand renfort de prime time tÃ©lÃ©visÃ©s ou l'arrivÃ©e express du nouveau BeyoncÃ© saturÃ© de clips vidÃ©o tentent de remuer les masses inertes derriÃ¨re leur claviers. Mais rien n'y fait.

Le support discographique se dÃ©charne depuis ces 30 derniÃ¨res annÃ©es et ne soutient plus la comparaison avec son cousin feuillu qui,malgrÃ© les coups de butoir de la digitalisation, se paie mÃªme le luxe de grignoter les rayons de disque des enseignes spÃ©cialisÃ©es.

Comment en est-on arrivÃ© lÃ ?

L'objet livre tout d'abord se dÃ©fend mieux que le disque face aux ogres de la numÃ©risation. Il n'est pas encore venu le temps oÃ¹ un Spotify du livre uberisera nos bonnes vieilles librairies

Le livre reste Ã©galement un bien culturel plus exigeant et exclusif. Le Â« time to market Â» et la barriÃ¨re de la fabrication permettent Ã©galement un Ã©crÃ©mage que le disque n'a malheureusement pas le luxe de se payer. Quand on parle de 600 livres en rayonnage chaque automne, ce sont des centaines de nouveaux disques et titres qui dÃ©boulent chaque semaine et ceci tout au long de l'annÃ©e. Un encombrement qui ne peut trouver sa solution que dans une distribution universelle et radicale comme le streaming le permet dorÃ©navant.

Le livre, de part sa nature mÃªme, est moins piratable que le disque. Son prix d'impression reste paradoxalement le mÃªme mais on l'achÃ¨te avant tout pour son contenu immatÃ©riel, l'intelligence qui a prÃ© existÃ© Ã  son Ã©criture.

De fait, on n'a jamais vu les prÃ©sentoirs des marchÃ©s inondÃ©s de copies pirates de livre, comme cela est par exemple le cas pour un disque ou un DVD.

D'ailleurs l'implacable numÃ©risation qui touche les marchÃ©s du disque et du film aboutissent de plus en plus Ã  des "leaks" comme en a connu la saison 7 de Game of Thrones ou le dernier album de Lady Gaga.

On peut avancer une autre raison au manque d'Ã©vÃ¨nementialisation du disque. Sa promotion est plus souvent centrÃ©e autour d'un titre playlistÃ© en radio ou mis en orbite sur les chaÃ®nes musicales et youtube qu'Ã  son contenu intÃ©gral. Pour rappel le concept d'"album Å“uvre" est apparu dans la fin de annÃ©es 60 (le lÃ©gendaire "Smile" des Beach Boys en est le Rosebud ultime) et a dominÃ© le marchÃ© mondial jusqu'Ã  l'apparition du compact disque. DÃ¨s lors que les disques ont pu se parcourir par burinage numÃ©rique et l'Å“uvre disque a connu une lente dÃ©saffection des auditeurs, ceux-ci prÃ©fÃ©rant petit Ã  petit concevoir leurs playlists en fonction de leurs gouts et leurs envies.

Au final il n'est pas rare de voir cohabiter sur les iPads des millenials le dernier rap Ã  la mode Ã  deux clics de souris d'un vieux George Brassens, les deux fichiers Ã©tant identiques d'un point de vue numÃ©rique.

Cette perte de datation dont souffre actuellement le marchÃ© du disque fournit son lot d'anecdotes. Ainsi "All Night" tube de Parov Stelar sorti depuis quelques annÃ©es s'est retrouvÃ© rÃ©cemment Ã  la tÃªte du top NRJ comme un retour en grÃ¢ce. Le manager d'un groupe Ã©lectro franÃ§ais nous faisait Ã©galement la confidence d'avoir reÃ§u un appel d'une major du disque bien connue qui lui rÃ©clamait urgemment des informations sur un single entendu sur une radio FM car il leur semblait un tube potentiel.... sauf que le titre en question Ã©tait sorti depuis un an et demi.

Faut-il en rire ou en pleurer? Nous prÃ©fÃ©rons terminer sur une note humoristique en rappelant qu'une Ã©tude rÃ©cente a pointÃ© les mots clÃ©s qui menait le plus souvent vers des virus et autre cheval de troie. En tÃªte de cette liste... un musicien... notre DJ national David Guetta.

A specialist technical rescue team had to be mobilised after the animal got stuck in a field in the Norwood Green area, near Bradford, West Yorkshire, The Press Association reports.
West Yorkshire Fire and Rescue said on Facebook: â€œOur Technical Rescue and Cleckheaton crew had to help re-moove a cow that had gotten itself in an inescapabull position stuck in a sink hole!

TEXT:
Firefighters have said a cow rescued from a sink hole had got itself into an â€œinescapabull positionâ€.

A specialist technical rescue team had to be mobilised after the animal got stuck in a field in the Norwood Green area, near Bradford, West Yorkshire, The Press Association reports.

West Yorkshire Fire and Rescue said on Facebook: â€œOur Technical Rescue and Cleckheaton crew had to help re-moove a cow that had gotten itself in an inescapabull position stuck in a sink hole!

â€œCrews and the farmer managed to dig a hole around the trapped cow and once the hole was big enough they used used a lifting sling to cow-ordinate the animal out of the hole.

â€œThe cow was rescued unharmed.â€
TITLE: Cow Rescued From Sink Hole By West Yorkshire Firefighters, Who Say It Was In An 'Inescapabull Position'

TEXT:
Unpredictable, Unscripted, Organic: Why Lifestyle And Documentary Portraits As a south London documentary and lifestyle fine art family photographer it will be no surprise that I have a love of photographs and documenting family life. One way or another I've been documenting the lives of my children since the moment they breathed their first. London family photographer and mum: capturing precious moments, creating timeless portraits...

Family Life And Quality Time: A Solvable Problem Family life with children is hectic and time is always at a premium. Everyone - young and old - has their own busy schedules, and this means that there may only be a few moments available every day for activities which involve both parents and children. Psychologist

What Happens When You Switch Off From The World For 48 Hours? The FOMO (Fear Of Missing Out) subsided and my head began to clear. I felt great, relaxed and refreshed to the point when I wasn't even thinking about my phone, freeing up my brain! A two night stay in the great outdoors felt like twice as long and I returned home vowing to take some applied learning's with me: Mum first. Savvy marketer, growing entrepreneur and lifestyle photographer second. Love helping others grow. Always trying to be brave.

I Went On Strike At Home On a normal day I dropped the kids at school, came home, and did all the jobs waiting for me. By the time I sat down to do any work the day was half gone, I was fed up and frustrated and had lost my motivation for doing any work on my business. Author, Teacher and Leader on the art of unlocking human potential and is the UKâ€™s leading energy expert for personal and business success.

How To Have Your Photo Taken When You're Camera Shy! So you'd really like some lovely family photos together - all having fun, enjoying family time -photos that include you, but you ... London family photographer and mum: capturing precious moments, creating timeless portraits...

Is Time The Greatest Gift? I travelled from my home in Glasgow last week to see my parents in Northern Ireland. This was the first visit home without my husband or kids for years. Having the opportunity to press pause on our hectic family life for just a couple of days felt like such a precious gift Auntie l Mum of Two Boys l Co-founder of Be So Baby - effortlessly thoughtful gifts for babies and kids www.besobaby.com

Have A Truly Merry Christmas: New Ways To Manage Stress During The Holidays These stress levels are extremely familiar to me. I've lost track of the number of Christmases lost worrying about work in between cooking for the starving masses, wrapping presents, keeping everyone happy and ensuring everything looked picture-book-perfect for the stream of 'perfect family' essential insta-snap. Founder of make-up brand Studio 10

How To Survive A Family Christmas When You're Single And In Your 30s I am 35 years old, run my own business and overall am pretty happy with my life the way it is. However, being single can be hard during the Christmas season, and even more so when surrounded by my coupled-up family. Auntie l Godmother l Co-founder of Be So Baby - helping aunties buy thoughtful gifts for babies and kids www.besobaby.com

17 Signs You Are a British Family Abroad Most of the plane journey involves you discussing the weather, worrying about if your suitcases will be lost, how warm it is going to be when you get off the plane and if anyone ears have popped yet. Mummy, Blogger, Vlogger

Five Things That Are Awful at Home but Awesome on Holiday Why is it that when you go away on holiday in the UK - whether that's to a caravan, campsite or cottage - all those boring, everyday things you do at home magically become fun? We took the kids to Yorkshire for a mid-week break last week, and we noticed a few things while we were there. Recognize any of these? Editor, writer, blogger, wife and mother

The Secret Diary of an Eighteen-Month-Old 08:30: Tipped the toy basket over. Didn't fancy anything in there. Mummy tried to simulate car racing on the floor with tiny cars but she does it all wrong. Got cross at Mummy's toy car ineptitude. Writer, mother, blogger, procrastinator...Tea?

Taking Your Children Swimming Should Be an Olympic Sport When mummy tells you we are taking baby and niece swimming, a sudden sense of worry...no hang on a minute, a sense of, "I don't even like swimming; I'm afraid of my head being submerged under a pool of urine infested water", follows. Writer of Nostalgia, Fatherhood, Humour and Life.

The Reality of Decluttering With a Family The whole de-cluttering thing is everywhere at the moment and I'm sold on the concept, it totally makes sense but I'll be honest I struggle with the reality. Founder of Guilty Mothers Club, Lifebulb, Mother, Feminist

The 2016 Dictionary of Modern Parenting Modern parenting can be confusing. As a mother, I just want to know how many times a week I can feed a three year old biscuits for breakfast and still not blush whenever I say 'We don't really eat sugary snacks in our house'. TV Producer, Writer, Mum

Honest Parenting: The Truth Behind the Styled Photos Sick happens. Usually when you've just put your best silk top on for a keep-in-touch work day and wanted to prove you have Totally Got It Together. Embarrassment happens. Usually when your toddler announces the person in the (broken-down?) line next to you is really old and ugly. Baby blogger, journalist and author of six books
TITLE: Family Time: The Huffington Post UK
