Si ce prix Nobel honore ICAN International ainsi que celles et ceux qui agissent dans le mÃªme sens, c'est Ã©galement un cruel dÃ©saveu pour les pays qui, comme la France, pratiquent la politique de l'autruche. Notre pays semble oublier qu'il est signataire du TraitÃ© de Non-ProlifÃ©ration, dont l'article VI stipule qu'il "s'engage Ã  poursuivre de bonne foi des nÃ©gociations sur des mesures efficaces relatives Ã  la cessation de la course aux armements nuclÃ©aires Ã  une date rapprochÃ©e et au dÃ©sarmement nuclÃ©aire, et sur un traitÃ© de dÃ©sarmement gÃ©nÃ©ral et complet sous un contrÃ´le international strict et efficace".

Ce traitÃ© de dÃ©sarmement, 122 pays ont dÃ©cidÃ© de l'adopter cette annÃ©e, ce qui permettra vraisemblablement son entrÃ©e en vigueur dÃ¨s 2018, pour les cinquante ans du TraitÃ© de Non-ProlifÃ©ration. Malheureusement, ni la France, ni aucune des huit autres puissances nuclÃ©aires n'a daignÃ© participer aux discussions Ã  l'ONU pour un monde enfin dÃ©barrassÃ© des armes atomiques, et s'emmure dans un dÃ©ni coupable sur le danger de son armement nuclÃ©aire. Cette distinction est donc une condamnation de l'inaction des puissances nuclÃ©aires qui prÃ©fÃ¨rent l'apparent confort de l'immobilisme et la fausse impression de sÃ©curitÃ© Ã  la prise en compte de la rÃ©alitÃ© de la menace et Ã  l'audace du changement.

Comme l'a justement rappelÃ© la prÃ©sidente du ComitÃ© Nobel, "nous vivons dans un monde oÃ¹ le risque que les armes nuclÃ©aires soient utilisÃ©es est plus Ã©levÃ© qu'il ne l'a jamais Ã©tÃ© depuis longtemps". L'actualitÃ© et sa succession de dÃ©clarations irresponsables au sujet de la CorÃ©e du Nord ou de l'Iran nous interpellent sur l'urgence du dÃ©sarmement nuclÃ©aire, alors que certains Etats parlent de ces armes comme d'une solution et non d'un problÃ¨me. Car non seulement la possession d'armes nuclÃ©aires est incapable de rÃ©pondre aux dÃ©fis de la sÃ©curitÃ© internationale Ã  venir, qui ne ressembleront pas aux conflits de la Guerre froide, mais elle favorise la prolifÃ©ration nuclÃ©aire. Comment ne pas Ãªtre Ã©tonnÃ© par exemple lorsque l'on entend le mÃªme discours Ã  Washington, Ã  Paris et Ã  Pyong Yang sur le nuclÃ©aire "garantie ultime de la sÃ©curitÃ© du pays"!

Alors que la responsabilitÃ© qu'impose la dÃ©tention d'un arsenal nuclÃ©aire exigerait que la France entame dÃ¨s maintenant des nÃ©gociations sÃ©rieuses avec les autres puissances nuclÃ©aires Ã  propos du dÃ©sarmement, notre pays refuse de voir la rÃ©alitÃ© soulignÃ©e rÃ©cemment par deux tiers des Etats reprÃ©sentÃ©s Ã  l'ONU. Cette rÃ©alitÃ©, c'est que les armes aujourd'hui considÃ©rÃ©es comme positives et efficaces pour dissuader toute attaque ennemie, sont en rÃ©alitÃ© un danger pour l'humanitÃ©. La France, qui pourrait jouer un rÃ´le diplomatique actif et Ãªtre le porte-drapeau du dÃ©sarmement nuclÃ©aire, traite pourtant avec mÃ©pris cette coalition d'Etats qui ont compris les enjeux de la paix du XXIe siÃ¨cle.

Contrairement aux engagements auxquels elle a souscrit en signant le TNP, la France n'a pas entrepris d'avancÃ©es significatives vers le dÃ©sarmement depuis l'arrÃªt des essais nuclÃ©aires il y a vingt ans de cela. Profitant d'un dÃ©sintÃ©rÃªt de l'opinion publique et des mÃ©dias franÃ§ais savamment entretenu, les responsables politiques, Ã  de trop rares exceptions, refusent de couper les amarres avec le monde ancien. Pire, on se prÃ©pare Ã  "moderniser" notre arsenal nuclÃ©aire en doublant les crÃ©dits qui lui sont affectÃ©s La reconnaissance internationale accordÃ©e par ce prix Nobel est une invitation Ã  ouvrir un dÃ©bat qui demeure toujours interdit dans notre pays sur la pertinence et l'avenir des armes nuclÃ©aires.

SUMMARY:
Well, one of the worst-kept secrets in â€˜X Factorâ€™ history has officially been confirmed, with Cheryl Tweedy having posed with Simon Cowell as she makes her return to Judgesâ€™ Houses.
ITV/Rex/Shutterstock Come on Cheryl, you could have thrown a few leaves or something on that outfitEarlier this year, she announced that sheâ€™d be back as Simonâ€™s right-hand woman at Judgesâ€™ Houses, only to eventually be ditched in favour of Cheryl.

Cheryl's Best 'X Factor' Moments
TEXT:
Well, one of the worst-kept secrets in â€˜X Factorâ€™ history has officially been confirmed, with Cheryl Tweedy having posed with Simon Cowell as she makes her return to Judgesâ€™ Houses.

As was reported earlier in the series, Cheryl will be helping the music mogul whittle down his remaining acts down at the final stage of the competition before live shows, after two years away from the show.

While weâ€™re sure Cherylâ€™s fans will be excited to see back on the show that helped catapult her to national treasure status, one person who wonâ€™t be impressed is â€˜So Machoâ€™ singer, Sinitta.

ITV/Rex/Shutterstock Come on Cheryl, you could have thrown a few leaves or something on that outfit

Earlier this year, she announced that sheâ€™d be back as Simonâ€™s right-hand woman at Judgesâ€™ Houses, only to eventually be ditched in favour of Cheryl.

Sinitta recently fumed: â€œI will always love Simon. He is like a father figure meets brother figure and ex-lover figure to me, and of course my mentor for over three decades - but right now he can kiss my black ass.â€

Ken McKay/TalkbackThames/REX/Shutterstock That's a bit more like it

Cheryl first joined the show almost a decade ago in 2008, when she was still a member of girl group Girls Aloud, until eventually stepping down in 2011, after she and Simon fell out when he sacked her from the US version of the show.

In 2014, she and Simon buried the hatchet, and she spent two more series as a judge, until eventually bidding farewell for a second time, claiming she wanted to focus more on her career as a singer, rather than a TV talent show judge.

Among other stars helping out at Judgesâ€™ Houses will be Stormzy, appearing alongside Nicole Scherzinger, as well as Jack and Kelly Osbourne, who will be serving as advisers to their mum, Sharon Osbourne.

Meanwhile, itâ€™s thought that Louis Walsh will get a helping hand from â€˜Grace Kellyâ€™ singer Mika, who serves as a judge on the Italian version of â€˜X Factorâ€™, even claiming he learned Italian especially for the job.

Cheryl's Best 'X Factor' Moments
TITLE: Cheryl Tweedy's 'X Factor' Return Confirmed, In First Pic With Simon Cowell At Judges' Houses

TEXT:
Bees And Feet So worker bees in hives in Manchester have had tiny chip devices fitted, like mini backpacks, so that their movements can be tracked, recorded and analysed. The project is part of a scheme to track a whole range of animate and inanimate objects in the city to build up a picture of what happens there each day. English teacher, book-lover, @TweeterofWit, blogger, lifelong learner

NTAs Winners 2017: Who Should Win And Who Will Win? More heavyweight than the Soap Awards and less stuffy than the BAFTAs, the National Television Awards is always an entertaining night (if not always for the right reasons - I'm looking at you, Judy Finnigan). Entertainment Reporter, The Huffington Post UK

Why Cold Feet Remains A Cultural Phenomenon Feeling slightly nervous, I tuned into the first episode and was instantly drawn back into the narrative as though thirteen years had not passed. We were guided back into the characters' lives in a way that felt natural with just the right amount of nostalgia. Content marketer and writer of 'Twenty Something' blog

Why True Detective Is the Least Original Thing on TV Compared to the huge finales that US TV series have spoilt us with in recent years in terms of twists and action, the fact that this damp squib of an episode was a total letdown of a series ending was probably the only original thing about the entire show. Freelance writer, idiot musician, record label honcho and armchair social theorist

'Southcliffe': The 'Hamlet' Of British Television It is rare to watch a TV show in 2013 and realise, within about 15 minutes, that it might be one of the best British dramas of all time. But Channel 4's Southcliffe, which finished on Sunday, is something really rather special. Screenwriter and journalist

Fiction for Some, Reality for Many, Top Boy Is Back! Channel 4's gritty mini series Top Boy, returns this month with its second series. A mind-blowing ratings success for the broadcaster, its lead characters Dushane and Sully are back with their daily grind, about inner city life in East London. Producer, director, broadcaster, columnist

The Five Most Shocking TV Character Demises Contains Spoilers ***** Last week the Twittersphere erupted in a single collective yowl of shock and disbelief. The cause - the penultimate episode in series three of Game of Thrones. Writes about cultural and political issues from a left standpoint

Television Anonymous My first memory of the television is extremely vague. The year is 1994 or maybe 1995. My mother is watching The X-Files. I am hiding behind the sofa. There's a corpse, there are cockroaches, and I am terrified. Student of the Law; Fledgling Culture Critic;

'Blue Bloods' - Off-The-Peg Morality and The American Dreat Blue Bloods is a CBS-produced TV drama - now in its third season - airing on Sky Atlantic in the UK, which typifies the successful formula used to create a top-rating series stateside. Actor, writer and columnist

Doctor Who Is Missing The BBC had a nasty habit of wiping old recordings to reuse the tapes. Had it not been for one heroic BBC staff member, armies of fans and occasional discoveries in foreign TV archives it could have been a lot worse, but the fact remains that we are still missing 106 episodes. Glam Rocking and Leftwing Politicking

Fred West Didn't Win a BAFTA by Proxy Appropriate Adult did not glorify West, nor did it even try to humanise him; it just did a very good job of presenting him as he must have appeared to Janet Leach in real life: a very ordinary, plausible man who slowly revealed his horrifying secrets. Author. Screenwriter. Forester.

Julian Fellowes' Titanic: All Class and No Character Unlike the iceberg, of course, we could have seen Titanic's problems a mile off. It's clear from Fellowes' most recent creation Downton Abbey that he believes the mere proximity of people from different social classes is enough to make a decent drama. Forget character, story, emotion... Democracy blogger

They're Remaking Borgen in America? Now I Do Need to Suspend My Disbelief Imagine the scenario. It's the eve of a general election. Public satisfaction with the major parties of right and left is at an all-time low. In a televised debate the leader of a small, centrist party gives a stirring performance, surges ahead in the polls and wins the election, becoming prime minister of a multi-party coalition government. Democracy blogger

Great Expectations - the Sleeper Hit of Christmas TV I haven't felt such compulsion to be in front of a telly for a period drama since the 1990s adaptation of Pride and Prejudice and Colin Firth's Mr Darcy got his frilly shirt wet. Entertainment and culture correspondent

Celebrating Leo McGarry Day He's not just a high-ranking mandarin, he's the President's most important counsellor and the mastermind behind two election victories. He's not just a middle-aged politician, he's a sage with a staff who have intense loyalty toward him. In short, everyone should have a Leo. Writer and broadcaster

Kit Harington sure knows how to tell an engagement story.
On an episode of â€œThe Jonathan Ross Showâ€ that airs this Saturday, Harington shares how he popped the question to former â€œGame of Thronesâ€ co-star Rose Leslie â€• and uses a turn of phrase that makes the whole scene sound a lot dirtier than it probably was in real life.

One thing he and Leslie definitely got right?
Harington and Leslie, both 30, are generally pretty quiet about their relationship, though the actor did recently say the sweetest thing about his soon-to-be wife.
TEXT:
Kit Harington sure knows how to tell an engagement story.

On an episode of â€œThe Jonathan Ross Showâ€ that airs this Saturday, Harington shares how he popped the question to former â€œGame of Thronesâ€ co-star Rose Leslie â€• and uses a turn of phrase that makes the whole scene sound a lot dirtier than it probably was in real life.

â€œI did have some plans to do it, I was going to string up some lights in some trees and do all the romantic stuff, but we were in the country and we were under this beautiful night sky and had a log fire burning and red wine and I blew my load early.â€

Then, he backtracked.

â€œWhat I meant to say was, I popped my question a bit early,â€ he says, according to the Daily Mail.

Sure, Jon Snow.

One thing he and Leslie definitely got right? Announcing their engagement in a very proper, traditional way. The pair, who have been dating on and off since 2012, took out a space in The Times of London last month to spread the happy news:

Getty Images via Getty Images The announcement appeared in the Times of London on September 27.

Harington and Leslie, both 30, are generally pretty quiet about their relationship, though the actor did recently say the sweetest thing about his soon-to-be wife.

Speaking to Esquire in May, the actor said he keeps details of his relationship private â€œbecause itâ€™s as much [Leslieâ€™s] relationship as it is mine and I canâ€™t speak for both of us. But yeah, we are very, very happy. So thatâ€™s what Iâ€™ll say about that.â€

Aw. What more needs to be said?
TITLE: Kit Harington Just Made His Proposal To Rose Leslie Sound Pretty NSFW

SUMMARY:
The New York Times published an explosive report Thursday detailing famed Hollywood producer Harvey Weinsteinâ€™s decades of sexual harassment against women in the entertainment industry.
Actresses including Ashley Judd and Rose McGowan are reported to have been harassed by Weinstein, as well as a number of industry professionals, from production assistants to college students.
When did you meet YOUR Harvey Weinstein?
Here are 11 responses that show just how often this happens â€• and just how many women have come to see it as normal.
â€” Beejoli Shah (@beejoli) October 5, 2017Oh boy, in the tech world, I'd say about 1 in every 3 dudes I interacted with was some version of Harvey Weinstein.
TEXT:
The New York Times published an explosive report Thursday detailing famed Hollywood producer Harvey Weinsteinâ€™s decades of sexual harassment against women in the entertainment industry.

Actresses including Ashley Judd and Rose McGowan are reported to have been harassed by Weinstein, as well as a number of industry professionals, from production assistants to college students.

After the Times published the piece, Ontario-based writer Anne T. Donahue tweeted to her 39,000 followers asking about when they met their â€œHarvey Weinsteinâ€ â€• or when they were first harassed by an older man in the workplace â€• before sharing her own story.

When did you meet YOUR Harvey Weinstein? I'll go first: I was a 17-yr-old co-op student and he insisted on massaging my shoulders as I typed â€” Anne T. Donahue (@annetdonahue) October 5, 2017

He was my boss at a radio station and liked to me things like why "girls my age" liked giving blow jobs and not having sex. A GREAT TIME. â€” Anne T. Donahue (@annetdonahue) October 5, 2017

Donahue told HuffPost that after reading the Times report, she â€œwas angry and also not surprised.â€

â€œI donâ€™t think I know a single woman who hasnâ€™t been sexually harassed during the course of her life, especially at work or in school, which is terrible and awful and exhausting,â€ she continued. â€œSo I did what I usually do when Iâ€™m angry â€• I tweeted about it.â€

Donahue said that considering how angry the report made her, she figured other women might have the same reaction and want a space to tell their stories as well.

â€œThatâ€™s the thing about this shit: itâ€™s happened to so many of us,â€ she said. â€œAnd it makes us feel weak and powerless and worthless and full of self-doubt and completely alone ... so now Iâ€™m talking about it, and figured maybe a few other women would want to talk about whatâ€™s happened to them, too.â€

She was right.

Since she posted the tweet on Thursday afternoon, Donahue has received hundreds of responses.

â€œThe Weinsteins are everywhere, I tell you,â€ she said.

Here are 11 responses that show just how often this happens â€• and just how many women have come to see it as normal.

Was a 24 yr old single mother emailed by a senior exec who asked to watch the sunset/sunrise... â€” Meegan Read (@MeeganReadCBC) October 5, 2017

Only girl in a row of male coworkers. One was 5'8"ish, lots of small dick jokes abounded. I was the one he showed it to, to prove it wasn't. â€” Beejoli Shah (@beejoli) October 5, 2017

Oh boy, in the tech world, I'd say about 1 in every 3 dudes I interacted with was some version of Harvey Weinstein. â€” Alex F (@karmagypsy) October 5, 2017

I ALSO had a teacher who massaged female students' shoulders while we typed. This was fifth grade. What is it with the shoulder massages?! â€” Kaitlin Menza (@heykmenz) October 5, 2017

I had a male boss when I was 24 who would stand over his young female employees until we got up from our seat and hugged him â€” Emma Gray (@emmaladyrose) October 5, 2017

In the Army, a married senior NCO made comments about my appearance, propositioned me, and tried to take upskirt pics of me w/o my consent. â€” Anyabelle:Creation (@BookishPlinko) October 5, 2017

7th grade. was dropping off a proj. to my teacher before school, wearing a long skirt. he said "pretty skirt. don't you have a shorter one?" â€” kim windyka (@kimlw) October 5, 2017

I was 18 and learning how to drive. My instructor would KEEP ON resting his hand on my upper thigh while I was concentrating on the road. â€” Lenore Ramirez (@lenore_ramirez) October 5, 2017

Maybe a year ago when I was called in for a "meeting" with 1 person, who rubbed my knee for 15 mins to discuss literally nothing! â€” Amanda Luz (@ahenning91) October 5, 2017

I was an unpaid intern on a TV show, he took me into his dark office, asked what my career hopes were and told me all about a man's "needs" â€” Freethster (@freethy) October 5, 2017
TITLE: 11 Women Share Their First 'Harvey Weinstein' Moments Of Workplace Sexual Harassment

SUMMARY:
Currently, the more affluent OBC communities are better placed at taking advantage of the 27% reservation for OBCs in central government jobs and educational institutions.
It will also mean that the number of seats taken by the more affluent communities, such as, say, Yadavs, will reduce.
You can't please all, but lower OBCs are a very large chunk of the population â€“ around 35% of the population in Uttar Pradesh for instance.
Dominant OBC communities tend to be better mobilized by regional satraps.
In UPA-1, HRD minister Arjun Singh had managed to push OBC reservations on prestigious central educational institutions.
TEXT:
ADVERTISEMENT

The President of India has notified a commission to explore the idea of OBC sub-categorisation. It's an idea long overdue, and one that is sure to pay off rich dividends for the Bhartiya Janata Party in the 2019 general elections.

Sub-categorisation will divide the OBCs into two groups: the more affluent ones and the less affluent ones.

Currently, the more affluent OBC communities are better placed at taking advantage of the 27% reservation for OBCs in central government jobs and educational institutions.

Dividing this 27% pie into two will mean that the less affluent OBC communities â€“ such as, say, Teli, the prime minister's caste â€“ will be able to get somewhat more seats in jobs and colleges. It will also mean that the number of seats taken by the more affluent communities, such as, say, Yadavs, will reduce.

Sub-categorisation will divide the OBCs into two groups: the more affluent ones and the less affluent ones.

The political impact of such a move will be obvious. The lower OBCs will be thrilled and are likely to vote for the BJP for many elections to come. In short, it is the ultimate 'surgical strike'.

The upper OBCs, however, will be unhappy with the BJP and this may reflect in their choices before the electronic voting machines, but that's fine for the party. You can't please all, but lower OBCs are a very large chunk of the population â€“ around 35% of the population in Uttar Pradesh for instance.

This is in keeping with the big picture of how the BJP has been positioning itself. In many state elections, the BJP campaign has sought to marginalize and polarise against the dominant OBC or upper caste community. In Uttar Pradesh, it can not just an anti-Muslim but also anti-Yadav campaign. BJP leaders accused the incumbent Samajwadi Party government of benefitting 'only one caste and one religion' through its schemes.

The lower OBCs will be thrilled and are likely to vote for the BJP for many elections to come.

Similarly, the BJP has alienated Jats in Haryana, Patels in Gujarat and Marathas in Maharashtra â€“ all upper caste peasant communities that have been demanding inclusion in the OBC list. Their agitations for reservations are proof of how politically potent an issue reservations are even today.

Reservations remain a powerful political tool because they affect government jobs. In absence of a manufacturing growth, India's jobless growth keeps alive the politics of reservations. Government jobs are as prized as they ever were. They give communities access to power and privilege.

The move is also in keeping with the Modi-Shah duo's broad intention of rebranding the BJP as a party of the poor, rather than a Brahmin-Baniya party. Its upper caste core, as well as its Hindutva ideology, mean that the party can have limited success with Dalits. Dominant OBC communities tend to be better mobilized by regional satraps. Wooing them also alienates the large but disparate chunk of lower OBCs. The lower OBC â€“ such as a Teli selling tea for a living â€“ is the bull's eye of the target audience of the new BJP.

India's jobless growth keeps alive the politics of reservations.

Before every state election, governments add new communities to some OBC list or the other â€“ the states have their own lists for reservations. That OBC sub-categorisation works politically is proven by the 9 states that have already done it: West Bengal, Tamil Nadu, Maharashtra, Andhra Pradesh, Telangana, Karnataka, Jharkhand, Bihar and Haryana. And the union territory of Puducherry too.

Sub-categorisation of the central OBC list is an idea that has been long overdue. It would have been politically beneficial for the Manmohan Singh-led UPA to do so, but they didn't. In UPA-1, HRD minister Arjun Singh had managed to push OBC reservations on prestigious central educational institutions. He died in 2011, by which time the UPA had forgotten how to do the right thing politically.

It's unthinkable for the Yadav-dominated Samajwadi Party in Uttar Pradesh to have hurt Yadav chances at jobs and college seats through OBC quota. But why did Mayawati never do it? Caste politics rules in UP as much as in Bihar. Nitish Kumar's main instrument in creating long-term space for himself in Bihar politics has been OBC sub-categorisation.

That this has so far not been done in UP, or at the central level, are political gaps waiting to be exploited. The Modi government's intention to do OBC sub-categorisation of the central list could soon be replicated in Uttar Pradesh.

Also on HuffPost India:
TITLE: Why OBC Sub-Categorisation Will Be Modiâ€™s Ultimate Surgical Strike

Theresa May stepping down as prime minister would not solve the Toriesâ€™ â€œBrexit catastropheâ€, according to Parliamentâ€™s only Green MP.

Lucas said: â€œOurs is a very democratic, grassroots, bottom-up party, so essentially our policy is made by our members.
TEXT:
Theresa May stepping down as prime minister would not solve the Toriesâ€™ â€œBrexit catastropheâ€, according to Parliamentâ€™s only Green MP.

Caroline Lucas said Mayâ€™s disastrous party conference speech must have been â€œan excruciating experienceâ€, but that her resignation - being called for by a number of Conservative MPs, led by former party chairman Grant Shapps - would fail to address any problems.

Speaking to HuffPost UK ahead of the Greensâ€™ annual conference, which kicks off this weekend, Lucas said: â€œOn a personal level my heart goes out to her, in the sense that it was clearly an excruciating experience that you wouldnâ€™t wish on anybody. Having said that, the real disaster of that speech was not the prime ministerâ€™s cough, but more what was in the speech and a complete failure to address the overwhelmingly important issues of the day.

â€œOn housing, for example, the idea that an extra five thousand council houses a year is really going to go anywhere towards addressing the absolute housing crisis that we face is just for the birds and a demonstration of just how out of touch the Tories are.

Empics Entertainment Theresa May struggles through her conference speech

â€œThe content of the speech was what was so incredibly disheartening - the lack of vision and the lack of any kind of understanding about what people want to hear.

â€œThey are well aware that they face a problem, that they need to be attracting more young people to their cause, and yet what they were offering was just so insignificant and unhelpful, itâ€™s really hard to see what they were thinking.â€

Lucas, who is co-leader of her own party, said changing the leadership of the Conservative party would do nothing to address â€œthis absolute Brexit catastrophe at its heartâ€.

â€œWhoever takes over from Theresa is still going to have that same challenge,â€ she added.

â€œThey have obviously got a completely split parliamentary party on the issue, they canâ€™t keep the same line more than a couple of days and the negotiations themselves seem to be going incredibly badly.

â€œWhen youâ€™ve got the CBI themselves saying to the Conservative Party â€˜pull yourselves together, youâ€™re incompetent and incoherentâ€™, that surely demonstrates just what an abysmal state the party is in, so changing leader isnâ€™t going to help them.â€

Empics Entertainment The Greens want a 'ratification referendum' on Brexit

The Greens have long been pushing for a â€˜ratification referendumâ€™ on Brexit - a second chance for voters to decide whether they really want Britain to leave the EU once exit negotiations are complete.

Lucas said she hoped MPs from other parties who were concerned about the Brexit process would back her proposal for a second vote.

â€œWe need to banish any ideas of this extreme Brexit, that no deal is better than a bad deal, all of this empty rhetoric that does not bear any scrutiny, because itâ€™s quite clear that no deal would be an asbolute disaster for the economy,â€ she said.

â€œGet rid of that and look very seriously at the proposals for remaining inside the single market and maintaining freedom of movement.

â€œOne way that both parties [Labour and Conservatives] could square the circle of the dilemma they have at the moment in terms of split views is to support the Green proposal for a ratification referendum.

â€œThe process was started by the British people, who voted [Leave] by a narrow majority, and it feels to me that it should go back to them to have the final sign-off.

â€œIf they like what they see, fine, but if they donâ€™t, and if on balance they would prefer to remain inside the EU now they are equipped with an awful lot more information than they had when they voted to leave, then they should have the final say.â€

PA Archive/PA Images Caroline Lucas and Jonathan Bartley

Lucas, who job shares her leadership position with former Parliamentary hopeful Jonathan Bartley, said she hoped the hung parliament produced as a result of the 2017 election would afford her more chances to work with rival MPs.

â€œOne positive thing I have discovered about Westminster is that contrary to some of the appearances, it is possible to work cross-party on a case-by-case basis.

â€œYou can make headway on different issues and that obviously is crucial, because none of the opposition parties on their own are going to be enough - so we need to work together.â€

The Greens have so far enjoyed a surprisingly civil working relationship with environment secretary Michael Gove, who since returning to the cabinet has pledged to champion a number of environmental issues, including animal welfare, air quality and tackling climate change.

â€œTo his credit he does appear to want to make his mark on this department which is good, because recently we have had ministers who didnâ€™t seem to care very much about the brief they have been given,â€ Lucas said.

â€œHe is a big beast and he wants to make his mark, and as long as he is doing that in a positive way, then thatâ€™s great.

Leon Neal via Getty Images Caroline Lucas says environment secretary Michael Gove is a 'big beast'

â€œThat does not wipe clean his own voting record in this area - which has been far from positive - and there are plenty of challenges in terms of how he is going to square this new found environmental zeal with the fact the government is continuing to promote fracking and nuclear energy and airport expansion and HS2 and road-building and all of those other things.

â€œOn the one hand, the idea that Gove is turning the Conservative Party into the real Green Party is genuinely laughable, but on the other hand, if we do now have somebody in that department who for whatever reason, whether they believe in it or not, is willing to be more positive and engage more seriously with these issues then thatâ€™s good, but the jury is out to see which way it goes.â€

She said the Green conference, which is being held in Harrogate, Yorkshire, will focus on Brexit and its impact on the environment as its main theme.

Bartley will be in the spotlight as he delivers the leadersâ€™ speech on Monday, and among policy motions to be voted on are proposals for a new bank holiday to celebrate â€œthe contribution of migrants and people of colourâ€ and enabling Parliamentary candidates to remain in place up to 18 months after a general election without being subjected to a new selection process.

Lucas said: â€œOurs is a very democratic, grassroots, bottom-up party, so essentially our policy is made by our members.
TITLE: Caroline Lucas: Theresa May Quitting Cannot Solve Tories' Brexit Catastrophe

SUMMARY:
But is your standard routine leading to a plateau in fitness gains?
One of the most beautiful things about the human body is its resilience and its ability to adapt to physical demands like exercise training.
But, do we lose gains from exercise as our bodies get used to it?
from www.shutterstock.comThe training effect can only occur when adequate stimulus (exercise stress) is applied to the body, and sufficient recovery is allowed.
Progressively increasing load and adding variation are two important progression strategies to help ensure fitness gains are realised.
TEXT:
ADVERTISEMENT

If you start running the same distance every day you'll increase your base level of fitness, but you'll plateau after a while. from www.shutterstock.com.au

Many of us exercise on a regular basis, and we become comfortable with the same exercise routine. But is your standard routine leading to a plateau in fitness gains? Once the body becomes used to running a few kilometres each day, is it basically the same as doing no exercise?

One of the most beautiful things about the human body is its resilience and its ability to adapt to physical demands like exercise training. Our bones, muscles, tendons, heart, and lungs, will adapt to the stress exposed to it. This means if you undertake exercise that's physically challenging, your body will adapt to this stress to ensure the same activity feels slightly easier in the future.

This mechanism of adaptation is both a blessing and a curse. The adage "if you don't use it, you'll lose it" can be applied here. If you've ever been bedridden due to a major illness, or gone into hibernation over the winter, you'll be familiar with the dramatic loss of fitness associated with reduced exposure to physical stress (exercise training).

Read more - Health Check: in terms of exercise, is walking enough?

But, do we lose gains from exercise as our bodies get used to it? If we keep on with the same exercise regime, we'll maintain the current gains in fitness, but further gains will diminish and we'll eventually reach a plateau. These adaptive responses are called the "training effect".

from www.shutterstock.com

The training effect can only occur when adequate stimulus (exercise stress) is applied to the body, and sufficient recovery is allowed. Muscle is a great example. Many adaptations occur, but from a mechanical perspective, small micro-tears in the muscle are experienced when you lift a heavier weight than you normally would. Immediately after training, your body gets to work to heal the "damage" and rebuilds the muscle so it's strong enough to more easily cope with those demands in the future.

Progressively increasing load and adding variation are two important progression strategies to help ensure fitness gains are realised. Progressive overload refers to frequent yet small increases in stress. If stress is increased too rapidly or with insufficient rest, you can risk overtraining and injury. So, what's the solution to preventing a plateau in fitness?

Increase your intensity

When walking around the local lake for the first time a few months ago, you may have noticed your breathing was rapid but you could carry on a conversation (moderate intensity) or very rapid breathing where talking was more difficult (vigorous intensity). But now, you can walk the same route without a noticeable change in your breathing (light intensity). These are important cues to show that you're now fitter.

If the time it takes you to do the same route remains the same, you are no longer applying the same stress (moderate or vigorous intensity exercise). Intensity is important. To move beyond a plateau, you will need to walk or jog faster, take a slightly more undulating course, or introduce regular short bouts of higher intensity work (run for thirty seconds or so every few minutes) so you're exercising at a moderate to vigorous intensity.

Read more: Do you even lift? Why lifting weights is more important for your health than you think

Train for longer

Your endurance performance can be influenced by the amount of time you spend completing your desired activity. You might decide that one of your cycling, running or rowing sessions each week becomes a slightly longer one. Increasing all of your endurance workouts during the week is not recommended, as you might overdo it and injure yourself.

It's advised to increase your running distance by no more than 10% and certainly no more than 30% per week to move beyond a plateau without increasing the risk of injury.

Exercise more often

Increasing how often you train each week can help to move beyond a plateau in your fitness.

For example, increasing the total amount of weight lifted each week (total weekly volume) in the gym should translate to increased strength and muscle size.

Change the order of your exercises

Most of us are limited for time and cram both aerobic and resistance exercise into the same session, but this might cause an interference effect, resulting in smaller gains in muscle strength or size. Some strategies to reduce this effect is to separate most of your aerobic (running, cycling, rowing, swimming) exercise from your resistance training sessions by at least six hours. Alternatively, you can limit combined aerobic and resistance exercise sessions to three or fewer bouts per week.

Preventing a plateau can be tricky, but listen carefully and your body will give you clues along the way. Be mindful that sleep, good nutrition, flexibility, and recovery days are just as important for progressing your fitness as the most challenging session you do in the gym or on the road this week.

Clint Miller, Lecturer, Clinical Exercise Physiology, School of Exercise and Nutrition Sciences, Deakin University

This article was originally published on The Conversation. Read the original article.
TITLE: Health Check: Do We Lose Gains From Exercise As Our Bodies Get Used To It?

Danish police say they have found body parts, including the head, of journalist Kim Wall, as they investigate how she died after she boarded a submarine.
Wall, who was Swedish, disappeared two months ago, after she boarded the home-made submarine of inventor Peter Madsen, which later sank.
/ Reuters The home-made submarine "UC3 Nautilus", built by Danish inventor Peter Madsen, as it sails off Copenhagen on August 20, 2017Madsen was arrested after being rescued.
In September, he told a court Wall died in an accident when she was hit by the submarineâ€™s heavy hatch cover.
Scanpix Denmark / Reuters Peter Madsen arrives back on shore after his rescue in AugustMadsen had video footage on his computer showing women being violently killed, a court heard on Tuesday.
TEXT:
Danish police say they have found body parts, including the head, of journalist Kim Wall, as they investigate how she died after she boarded a submarine.

Her head was in a bag along with two legs. Police inspector Jens Moller said there was another bag containing her clothes.

Wall, who was Swedish, disappeared two months ago, after she boarded the home-made submarine of inventor Peter Madsen, which later sank.

TT News Agency / Reuters Kim Wall

Stringer . / Reuters The home-made submarine "UC3 Nautilus", built by Danish inventor Peter Madsen, as it sails off Copenhagen on August 20, 2017

Madsen was arrested after being rescued. He has been charged with her killing, which he denies. He also denies a charge of mutilating her corpse.

In September, he told a court Wall died in an accident when she was hit by the submarineâ€™s heavy hatch cover.

He claimed he â€œburied her at seaâ€ and then intended to kill himself. He initially claimed he safely dropped her off in Copenhagen before the submarine sank.

Scanpix Denmark / Reuters Peter Madsen arrives back on shore after his rescue in August

Madsen had video footage on his computer showing women being violently killed, a court heard on Tuesday.

A police prosecutor said officers found images â€œwhich we presume to be realâ€ of women being strangled and decapitated on the hard drive on Madsenâ€™s computer in a laboratory he ran.
TITLE: Kim Wall's Head And Other Body Parts Found By Danish Police Investigating Submarine Death

Je me suis levÃ©, j'ai allumÃ© une cigarette et je me suis assis dans une chaise en face des montagnes.
En 2014, le livre a Ã©tÃ© nommÃ© le troisiÃ¨me meilleur livre de tous les temps dans un sondage Rolling Stone.
TEXT:
Une photographie prise Ã  l'hÃ´tel du Colorado qui a inspirÃ© le roman Ã  succÃ¨s The Shining de Stephen King montre ce qui semble Ãªtre deux fantÃ´mes.

La famille Mausling d'Aurora, au Colorado, a participÃ© Ã  une visite guidÃ©e sur les esprits Ã  l'hÃ´tel Stanley Ã  Estes Park le mois passÃ©. AprÃ¨s leur retour Ã  la maison, ils ont remarquÃ© une photo prise par John ''Jay'' Mausling qui semble montrer une jeune fille descendre les marches.

John Mausling et sa femme, Jessica Martinez-Mausling, ont expliquÃ© au HuffPost par courriel qu'il n'y avait pas de jeunes filles dans leur visite guidÃ©e de 11 personnes.

Â«Au dÃ©but, on a essayÃ© d'Ãªtre logiques et on pensait qu'on l'avait peut-Ãªtre manquÃ©e, donc on a demandÃ© Ã  nos enfants, Ã  leurs copines et Ã  notre ami s'ils se souvenaient d'avoir vu une petite filleÂ», ont-ils Ã©crit. Â«Personne ne s'en souvenait. On ne se souvient pas d'avoir vu quoi que ce soit sur les escaliers au moment de prendre la photo.Â»

Voici un gros plan de la figure mystÃ©rieuse sur les escaliers:

Ben Hansen, ancien agent du FBI et animateur de Fact or Faked: Paranormal Files a dit qu'une analyse attentive de la photo ne montre aucun signe de trucage.

Â«J'aime vraiment cette photoÂ», a avouÃ© Hansen. Â«Supposant qu'elle n'est pas falsifiÃ©e, c'est une des meilleures photos d'Ã©vidence paranormale que j'ai vue. Si elle est fausse, je dois admettre leur niveau de dÃ©tail et de crÃ©ativitÃ© parce qu'il y a assez de signes faciles d'habitude qui suggÃ¨rent qu'on se fait jouer un tour.Â»

Et si c'est la fille fantÃ´me qui se dÃ©marque le plus, la photo pourrait prÃ©senter une deuxiÃ¨me apparition.

Les Mausling ont dit qu'au moment oÃ¹ la photo a Ã©tÃ© prise, il y avait seulement deux personnes sur les escaliers: la guide de la visite, et quelqu'un d'autre avec un tÃ©lÃ©phone cellulaire. Cependant, l'image montre ce qui pourrait Ãªtre une troisiÃ¨me figure qui semble monter les marches.

Hansen dit qu'il a supposÃ© que cette silhouette Ã©tait seulement une autre personne qui monte les marches, avec le mÃªme flou de mouvement entourant d'autres gens dans l'image. Il a ensuite remarquÃ© quelque chose d'autre.

Â«Ã€ travers la rampe et les barreaux, vous pouvez voir la moitiÃ© de la personne et ses souliers... mais je ne peux pas voir la moitiÃ© de la silhouetteÂ», dit-il.

Hansen a ajoutÃ© qu'il n'y a pas de test dÃ©cisif pour une photo de fantÃ´mes, donc c'est impossible d'Ãªtre certain de qu'il y a dans la photo. Les Mausling, quant Ã  eux, disent qu'ils ne croient pas nÃ©cessairement aux fantÃ´mes, mais qu'ils sont ouverts d'esprit et qu'ils n'ont pas Ã©cartÃ© la possibilitÃ© qu'ils peuvent exister.

Si l'hÃ´tel Stanley est une destination de choix pour les gens qui veulent visiter le parc national Rocky Mountain Ã  proximitÃ©, c'est aussi un endroit de prÃ©dilection pour ceux qui veulent vivre une expÃ©rience d'un autre monde. L'annÃ©e derniÃ¨re, une photo d'un supposÃ© fantÃ´me Ã  l'hÃ´tel a fait les manchettes autour du monde. La photo a Ã©tÃ© prise au mÃªme endroit.

By golly! I think I may have captured a #ghost at #StanleyHotel. #EstesPark Une publication partagÃ©e par Henry Yau (@ares415) le 12 Avril 2016 Ã  7h33 PDT

AprÃ¨s un sÃ©jour Ã  l'hÃ´tel en 1974, King l'a appelÃ© Â«le cadre parfait â€” peut-Ãªtre l'archÃ©type â€” pour une histoire de fantÃ´mes.Â» King a Ã©crit sur son site web officiel que lui et sa femme, l'auteure Tabitha King, Ã©taient les seuls invitÃ©s quand l'hÃ´tel allait fermer pour l'hiver.

Â«Cette nuit-lÃ , j'ai rÃªvÃ© que mon fils de trois ans courrait Ã  travers les corridors, regardait derriÃ¨re ses Ã©paules, les yeux grands ouverts, et criait. Il Ã©tait chassÃ© par un tuyau d'incendie. Je me suis rÃ©veillÃ© avec une secousse, en sueur, Ã  un pouce de tomber du lit. Je me suis levÃ©, j'ai allumÃ© une cigarette et je me suis assis dans une chaise en face des montagnes. Avant que la cigarette ne se termine, j'avais la structure du livre dans ma tÃªte.Â»

Ce rÃªve est devenu le troisiÃ¨me livre de King, The Shining, sorti en 1977, dont l'action avait lieu dans l'hÃ´tel hantÃ© Overlook. En 2014, le livre a Ã©tÃ© nommÃ© le troisiÃ¨me meilleur livre de tous les temps dans un sondage Rolling Stone.

Ce texte initialement publiÃ© sur le HuffPost Ã‰tats-Unis a Ã©tÃ© traduit de l'anglais.
TITLE: Des fantÃ´mes pris en photo au cÃ©lÃ¨bre hÃ´tel Stanley au Colorado

SUMMARY:
In the UK, it is estimated that one in 400 babies have a type of cerebral palsy.
If you aren't expecting a child with cerebral palsy then you probably won't be expecting incredible moments like thisWilliam cannot use words to communicate, but he can vocalise and tries really hard to express himself.
If you're (not) expecting a child with cerebral palsy you won't be expecting the overwhelming joy of hearing them laugh or responding to an "I love you" with a squeal.
If you're (not) expecting a child with cerebral palsy you won't be expecting life to be good, your child to be happy and people to want to spend time with them.
Today (Oct 6th) marks World Cerebral Palsy day and I hope by raising awareness of this condition, we can help prepare new parents should their child be diagnosed with Cerebral Palsy.
TEXT:
The day before our 12 week scan I remember a friend clearly saying "at least you'll know it doesn't have Down syndrome tomorrow" and my baby didn't. We 'passed' that test with flying colours, nope no down syndrome here.

But it never occurred to us that our baby might still be born with a disability.

I was 37 weeks pregnant when I noticed the baby had stopped moving. Back then (2009) midwives were advising that if your baby stopped moving it probably wasn't anything to worry about and that eating some chocolate or having a hot drink would probably wake up the baby.

So that's what I did. I ate chocolate, drank tea and didn't panic. Turns out maybe I should have.

William was born at 7.25pm that day via emergency c-section. But during the time he had stopped moving, he had suffered from a lack of oxygen which had led to severe brain damage and a condition we were later told was called Cerebral Palsy (CP).

William was diagnosed with brain damage when he was 4 days old

Until we were given that diagnosis we'd never even heard the term and hearing it that day was terrifying.

But we aren't alone. In the UK, it is estimated that one in 400 babies have a type of cerebral palsy. Figures indicate that with the birth rate in excess of 700,000 per year there may be as many as 1,800 new cases of CP in children each year source

I wonder whether we would have been more able to cope with the diagnosis of cerebral palsy had we been aware of its existence? Would it have been easier if we'd had a small understanding of what might lay ahead for William, and for us as his parents?

Conditions which can be diagnosed prior to birth can be researched so that parents can ready themselves and be a little more prepared to deal with the consequences when their baby arrives.



But if, like us, your baby's disability is caused at the end of the pregnancy or during birth then it's likely you are not prepared for it at all, especially if you've never even heard of the condition.

I don't want to panic expectant mothers or give them even more to worry about during their pregnancy, but I do feel it is important that this condition is discussed more openly because as Robyn Cummins, World CP Day Manager explains,

"Cerebral palsy is the most common physical disability in childhood and is also one of the least understood. There are over 17 million people living with CP and 350 million family, friends and supporters who care about them."

Perhaps if I had been aware of it then I might have taken William's reduced movements more seriously? Had I been aware of this condition when I was pregnant, although it still would have been devastating to hear the diagnosis, maybe it wouldn't have been so terrifying to think about the future.

I may have known a little more about what to expect for my baby. Not knowing what lies ahead can be terrifying. All you want to know is what might happen, how you'll deal with it, and who will help you through it.

What is cerebral palsy?

Cerebral Palsy is a complex, lifelong disability. It primarily affects movement, but people with CP may also have visual, learning, hearing, speech, epilepsy and intellectual impairments. It can be mild - a weakness in one hand - to severe - where people have little control over movements or speech and may need 24-hour assistance.

William's CP is at the severe end of the scale, GMFCS V, so his whole body is affected. He cannot sit or stand, he cannot use his hands and is non-verbal. All of this sounds terrible, and I know the very thought of your baby being as disabled as William, is terrifying.

That is why it is always important to balance the statistics, medical and physical issues with the daily reality and the positives.

William needs 24/7 care, but he loves being with people, whether they are children or 'grown-ups'. If you're (not) expecting a child with cerebral palsy you won't be expecting the feelings of relief, comfort and happiness when you see them build relationships with adults who want to help them as much as you do.

William cannot stand or sit unaided but he has support from an incredible NHS team who provide him with specialist equipment so he can sit comfortably and is able to stand up to play. If you're (not) expecting a child with cerebral palsy you won't realise how much you will come to rely on the NHS and how hard people will work to make sure your child is comfortable and able to participate in daily life.

If you aren't expecting a child with cerebral palsy then you probably won't be expecting incredible moments like this

William cannot use words to communicate, but he can vocalise and tries really hard to express himself. If you're (not) expecting a child with cerebral palsy you won't be expecting the overwhelming joy of hearing them laugh or responding to an "I love you" with a squeal.

William faces daily challenges but despite that he is one of the happiest children you could ever meet. He smiles all day, laughs at the silliest things and loves to watch the world. If you're (not) expecting a child with cerebral palsy you won't be expecting life to be good, your child to be happy and people to want to spend time with them.

He might not be able to do things in the same way that other children his age can but that doesn't mean that he doesn't live a full and active life. He cycles a bike, swims and even horse-rides at his incredible school. In fact, the main thing that holds him back isn't even his disability, it's the world around him not being adapted to cater for it.

As a family, of course it has changed our lives. Having a child with a disability means we don't do the same things other families do. But sometimes I am actually grateful for that! I don't have to stand in the cold watching a football game on a Sunday morning and I don't have to do the school run in the rain!

Having a child with CP is difficult, I won't lie and people often assume that I would want to 'cure' William if I could. But the truth is that no, I wouldn't change him for the world. Of course, if there was a 'cure' then I would do it for him, if I thought that was what he would want, but no, not for me.



To me he is perfect just the way he is.

Today (Oct 6th) marks World Cerebral Palsy day and I hope by raising awareness of this condition, we can help prepare new parents should their child be diagnosed with Cerebral Palsy.
TITLE: What To Expect When You Are (Not) Expecting A Child With Cerebral Palsy

TEXT:
Der russische PrÃ¤sident Wladimir Putin hat am 7. Oktober Geburtstag

Lieber Wladimir Wladimirowitsch,

ich kenne Sie seit mehr als anderthalb Jahrzehnten persÃ¶nlich; noch lÃ¤nger verfolge ich Ihr Wirken, habe mehrere BÃ¼cher darÃ¼ber geschrieben.

Zu Ihrem heutigen 65. Geburtstag mÃ¶chte ich Ihnen diese 10 WÃ¼nsche mit auf den Weg geben:

1. Dass Sie den Kontakt zur RealitÃ¤t wiederfinden

Macht macht selbst in demokratischen LÃ¤ndern einsam. Absolute Macht, wie Sie sie haben, koppelt einen von der Wirklichkeit ab.

In Ihrer Umgebung traut sich niemand mehr, Ihnen unangenehme Wahrheiten zu sagen.

Etwa, dass Ihr Auftritt als SÃ¤nger und Pianist vor laufenden Kameras nur peinlich war.

Sie erklÃ¤ren Ihren Vertrauten morgens die Welt, die erklÃ¤ren die Welt dann genau so den Chefredakteuren â€“ und abends sehen Sie im Fernsehen genau die Welt, die Sie am Morgen selbst entworfen haben.

Ich wÃ¼nsche Ihnen, dass Sie die StÃ¤rke finden, kritische Stimmen nicht mehr zu unterdrÃ¼cken.

FÃ¼r eine grundlegende RÃ¼ckkehr zur RealitÃ¤t, die ich Ihnen von Herzen wÃ¼nsche, wÃ¤re allerdings die ErfÃ¼llung meines zweiten Wunsches notwendig.

Mit 65 Jahren sind sie bereits fÃ¼nf Jahre Ã¼ber dem Renteneintrittsalter von russischen MÃ¤nnern, und auch wenn Sie Deutscher wÃ¤ren, dÃ¼rften Sie jetzt bald mit dem Arbeiten aufhÃ¶ren.

2. Ich wÃ¼nsche Ihnen: Gehen Sie in den Ruhestand

Fast 18 Jahre lange ein und dieselbe Arbeit zu machen, ist auch fÃ¼r weniger qualifizierte Jobs wie Arzt oder Professor ein langer Zeitraum; 18 Jahre an der Spitze Russlands ist fÃ¼r sie als Regierender sicher ebenso ermÃ¼dend wie fÃ¼r die Regierten.

Sie haben einmal gesagt, sie wÃ¼rden so hart arbeiten wie ein Sklave auf einer Galeere. WÃ¤hlen Sie die Freiheit, schmeiÃŸen sie ihr Ruder weg!

Sie legen damit nicht nur die Einsamkeit der Macht ab.

Sie lassen immer verbreiten: Russland ist umzingelt, und meinen damit die NATO. In Wirklichkeit sind Sie umzingelt. Von SchÃ¶nrednern und Claqueuren.

3. Ich wÃ¼nsche Ihnen, dass Sie endlich Ihre KGB-Brille ablegen kÃ¶nnen

Sie haben beim Geheimdienst gelernt, die Welt klar in Schwarz und WeiÃŸ zu teilen, in Freund und Feind.

KGB-Offiziere im mittleren Dienst wie Sie wurden darauf abgerichtet, Ã¼berall VerschwÃ¶rungen und Verrat, Provokationen und Angriffe zu wittern.

Viele Ihrer weltgewandteren Kameraden haben das abgelegt.

Ihre Politik zeigt, dass Sie bis heute in diesem Denken verfangen sind.

Die russischen Medien, die Sie steuern, lassen den Menschen stÃ¤ndig eintrichtern, die NATO plane einen Ãœberfall auf Russland.

Ich fÃ¼rchte, dass Sie selbst inzwischen daran glauben. An Ihre eigene Propaganda.

Wenn man Ã¼berall Verrat, Provokation und Aggression wittert, muss das Leben eine HÃ¶lle sein.

Ich wÃ¼nsche Ihnen, dass Sie sich aus dieser HÃ¶lle befreien.

Russland ist nicht von Feinden umzingelt.

Die NATO plant keinen Angriff auf Ihr Land.

Wir wollen Partnerschaft mit Russland â€“ nur tun wir uns schwer damit, solange Sie NachbarlÃ¤nder Ã¼berfallen und Ihre Kritiker gewaltsam ums Leben kommen.

4. Ich wÃ¼nsche Ihnen ehrliche und freie Wahlen

Niemand zweifelt daran, dass Sie im FrÃ¼hjahr zum vierten Mal zum russischen PrÃ¤sident gewÃ¤hlt werden, mit einem Ã¼berwÃ¤ltigenden Ergebnis.

Jeder, der Russland auch nur halbwegs kennt, ist sich bewusst, dass diese Wahlen massiv manipuliert werden.

Weil Sie Ihre Gegner gar nicht zur Wahl zulassen, sie in den Medien mit Schmutz bewerfen, statt sie zu Wort kommen zu lassen, weil Sie in und um die Wahllokale massiv und dreist betrÃ¼gen.

So ein Wahlsieg muss so befriedigend sein wie ein Boxkampf, in dem der Sieger seinen Gegner vorab knebeln und auf den Boden fesseln lÃ¤sst.

Ich wÃ¼nsche Ihnen den Mut, eine echte Wahl zuzulassen.

Sie wÃ¼rden dann erfahren, was die Menschen wirklich von Ihnen denken.

Und egal, wie die Wahl ausgeht - sie kÃ¶nnten in jedem Fall stolz sein: Auf einen Sieg, der er ehrlich wÃ¤re. Und sogar auf eine Niederlage kÃ¶nnten sie stolz sein, weil Sie die GrÃ¶ÃŸe gehabt hÃ¤tten, diese zu riskieren.

5. Ich wÃ¼nsche Ihnen, dass Sie keine Angst mehr haben vor Ihren politischen Konkurrenten

Gerade hat ein Moskauer Gericht wieder in einem peinlichen Schauprozess Ihren bekanntesten Kritiker, Alexej Nawalnij, fÃ¼r 20 Tage einsperren lassen.

Zum wiederholten Male.

Selbst Ihre Marionette Dmitrij Medwedew hat, als er pro forma fÃ¼r Sie PrÃ¤sident war, zugegeben, dass in Russland"Telefonjustiz" herrscht â€“ also Gerichtsurteile per Telefon von ganz oben an die Richter diktiert werden.

Es ist deshalb klar, dass auch Sie fÃ¼r das Urteil gegen Nawalnij Verantwortung tragen. Ebenso dafÃ¼r, dass sein Bruder, der drei kleine Kinder hat, seit Jahren unschuldig in Haft sitzt â€“ de facto als Geisel.

Sehr viele Menschen sitzen in Russland im Straflager, weil Sie gegen Sie sind.

Wer seine Gegner wegsperren lÃ¤sst, muss groÃŸe Angst haben.

Ich wÃ¼nsche Ihnen, dass Sie diese Angst besiegen.

Nicht nur Ihre Gegner werden dann frei sein â€“ auch Sie werden sich freier fÃ¼hlen.

6. Ich wÃ¼nsche Ihnen, dass Sie im 21. Jahrhundert ankommen. Oder zumindest im 17. Jahrhundert

Ihr politisches Denken ist nicht mal in den Zeiten Bismarcks verhaftet â€“ die Grundlagen fÃ¼r die SouverÃ¤nitÃ¤t von Nationalstaaten wurden bereits 1648 mit dem WestfÃ¤lischen Frieden gelegt.

Sie hingegen glauben immer noch, dass Russlands NachbarlÃ¤nder wie kleine Kinder nicht ganz erwachsen sind und Sie Ã¼ber deren Schicksal mitbestimmen mÃ¼ssen.

Sie sind deshalb in diesen LÃ¤ndern verhasst wie kaum ein anderer Politiker.

Lassen Sie diese LÃ¤nder in Ruhe.

Akzeptieren Sie, dass nicht Sie, sondern die Menschen in diesen LÃ¤ndern selbst Ã¼ber ihre Leben und ihr Schicksal entscheiden dÃ¼rfen.

Ich zweifle, ob die Menschen dort wirklich dankbar sein werden, wenn Sie sie endlich in Ruhe lassen â€“ dafÃ¼r haben sie zu viel Angst dort ausgelÃ¶st, und zu viele Menschen sind gestorben.

Aber zumindest der Hass gegen Sie wÃ¼rde nachlassen.

Und weniger gehasst zu werden, sollte befreiend wirken.

7. Ich wÃ¼nsche Ihnen, dass Sie Ihre Sowjetnostalgie ablegen. Sie ist schlecht fÃ¼r Sie und fÃ¼r Ihr Land

Sie haben den Zusammenbruch der Sowjetunion als die grÃ¶ÃŸte geopolitische TragÃ¶die des 21. Jahrhunderts bezeichnet.

Unter Ihnen ist es in Russland zu einer Stalin-Nostalgie gekommen. Der grausame MassenmÃ¶rder wird heute wieder gefeiert. Sie lassen Seine Verbrechen relativieren und seine angeblichen Verdienste preisen.

Sie stehen in der sowjetischen Denk-Tradition, wonach der Staat alles und der Mensch nichts ist.

Solange Russland diese Denkweise nicht ablegt, solange Stalin verehrt wird, hat Russland keine Zukunft. So treten Sie und Ihr groÃŸartiges Land immer wieder auf die alten Mistgabeln.

Ich wÃ¼nsche Ihnen, dass Sie verstehen, dass Russlands Zukunft nicht darin besteht, dass die NachbarlÃ¤nder es fÃ¼rchten.

Russland hat eine groÃŸe Zukunft, wenn die Nachbarn es beneiden.

Wenn die Menschen nicht auf Russlands Bedrohungspotential stolz sind, sondern Stolz sein kÃ¶nnten auf eine funktionierende Gesundheitsversorgung, auf wÃ¼rdige Renten, funktionierende Gesetze und eine erfolgreiche BekÃ¤mpfung von Korruption und WillkÃ¼r.

8. Ich wÃ¼nsche Ihnen, dass Sie in die GeschichtsbÃ¼cher nicht nur als Krieger eingehen

Sie sind fÃ¼r den Krieg in der Ostukraine verantwortlich, der mehr als 10.000 Menschen das Leben kostete und noch heute fast tÃ¤glich Opfer fordert.

Die Truppen von Ihnen und Ihrem VerbÃ¼ndeten Assad haben massive Kriegsverbrechen in Syrien begangen.

Sie tragen die politische Verantwortung fÃ¼r den Abschuss des Fluges MH-17 Ã¼ber der Ostukraine mit fast 300 Toten und fÃ¼r die Ermordung des Ex-KGB-Agenten Alexander Litwinenko in London 2006 mit radioaktivem Polonium, wie niederlÃ¤ndische Ermittler und ein britischer Richter feststellten.

Die Liste lieÃŸe sich lange fortsetzen.

Machen Sie sich ein Geburtstagsgeschenk, indem sie den blutigen Krieg in der Ukraine beenden. Sie mÃ¼ssen dazu nur die Grenzen dichtmachen und aufhÃ¶ren, aus Russland Waffen und Geld an Ihre BefehlsempfÃ¤nger zu liefern, die Sie als "pro-russische Rebellen" ausgeben.

Vielleicht haben Sie Angst, dass Frieden statt Krieg zu beginnen Sie schwÃ¤cher dastehen lÃ¤sst.

Das Gegenteil ist der Fall.

Ich wÃ¼nsche Ihnen, dass Sie das verstehen.

9. Ich wÃ¼nsche Ihnen, dass Sie nicht nur als Spitze der russischen Korruptions-Pyramide in die Geschichte eingehen â€“ sondern als jemand, der auch einen Teil seines Geldes zurÃ¼ckgibt

Sie mÃ¼ssen ja nicht gleich Robin Hood sein.

Enge Vertraute von Ihnen brachten es auf dubiose Weise zu unvorstellbaren MilliardenvermÃ¶gen, seit Sie an der Macht sind.

Ihre Kritiker bezeichnen Sie als reichsten Mann der Welt, weil sie sagen, dass Sie auf dieses Geld Zugriff haben.

Geben ist seliger als Nehmen, sagt ein deutsches Sprichwort.

In Russland leben Millionen Menschen in bitterer Armut; viele kÃ¶nnen sich nicht vollwertig satt essen, vielen fehlt das Geld fÃ¼r dringend benÃ¶tigte Operationen.

Sagen Sie Ihren Freunden, dass Sie â€“ als Geburtstagsgeschenk an Sie, statt Yachten und goldenen Toiletten fÃ¼r Ihre Flugzeuge â€“ zumindest einen Teil Ihrer Milliarden den Menschen in Russland zurÃ¼ckgeben sollen.

Die Dankbarkeit der Menschen wird ein schÃ¶nes Geburtstagsgeschenk an Sie werden.

10. Ich wÃ¼nsche Ihnen echte Freunde

Nicht solche wie Ex-Kanzler Gerhard SchrÃ¶der, deren angebliche Freundschaft mit Ihnen einen schalen Beigeschmack hat, weil er von Ihnen â€“ Ã¼ber den Umweg Ihrer Konzerne â€“ Unsummen an Geld verdient.

Genauso wie so viele Ihrer anderen Kumpels, die zu MilliardÃ¤ren wurden, beruhen solche Beziehungen auf AbhÃ¤ngigkeiten â€“ und nicht auf Freundschaft.

Ich wÃ¼nsche Ihnen Menschen, die kein Geld von Ihnen wollen, keine Macht, keine Posten â€“ sondern die Sie um Ihrer selbst willen wollen.

Solange sie Alleinherrscher sind, wird es fÃ¼r Sie sehr schwierig sein, solche echten Freunde zu finden.
TITLE: "Wladimir Wladimirowitsch, gehen Sie in Rente!": 10 GeburtstagswÃ¼nsche an Putin

SUMMARY:
A raft of Cabinet ministers and senior backbenchers came forward to defend May after her speech on Wednesday, which was marred by a persistent cough, a prank protest and a collapsing backdrop.
Chelmsford MP Vicky Ford told the BBC Shapps was â€œcompletely out of touchâ€ with the vast majority of MPs and Tory members.
â€” Michael Fabricant (@Mike_Fabricant) October 6, 2017Environment Secretary Michael Gove, who ran in last yearâ€™s leadership contest, said May should remain prime minister â€œas long as she wantsâ€.
â€œThe prime ministerâ€™s been doing a fantastic job.
She can decide sheâ€™s had enough and quit this autumn...but history suggests that party leaders, let alone prime ministers, rarely jump before they are pushed â€” David Cameron was the recent exception.
TEXT:
Theresa May today refused to stand down despite mounting pressure, claiming it is business as usual.

The embattled prime minister told reporters at an event in her Maidenhead constituency: â€œWhat the country needs is calm leadership and that is what I am providing, with the full support of my cabinet.â€

Mayâ€™s defiant message comes after Tory chairman Grant Shapps revealed on Friday morning he was leading a plot to oust her.

Shapps said he was one of five former Cabinet ministers among more than 30 Tory MPs who were â€œperfectly within their rightsâ€ to ask May to quit, and said she should â€œtake responsibilityâ€ for calling the snap general election and losing her Commons majority.

â€œWe did have a result that was not at all what anyone wanted, least of all what she wanted or anticipated, and... sometimes when things happen you have to take responsibility for them,â€ he told BBC Radio 5 Live.

Shapps later told Radio Fourâ€™s Today Programme that Number 10 had known for a while he was leading the rebels and phoned him before the conference, â€œpleadingâ€ with him not to say anything.

He also said he had only stepped forward because the party whips briefed The Times that he was leading the rebellion, and that he wanted to oust the prime minister by applying private pressure to â€œavoid embarrassmentâ€.

â€œIâ€™m very sorry the whips have not made that possible,â€ he said.

PA Wire/PA Images Grant Shapps is leading a plot to oust the PM

Shapps added that Mayâ€™s disastrous conference speech meant that â€œsome colleagues feel it would be better to have that leadership election sooner or rather laterâ€.

â€œThereâ€™s nothing wrong or illegitimate in saying we can do better than this,â€ he said.

A raft of Cabinet ministers and senior backbenchers came forward to defend May after her speech on Wednesday, which was marred by a persistent cough, a prank protest and a collapsing backdrop.

Despite the rearguard action, one MP texted the Government Chief Whip on Thursday evening to say May â€œneeds to go and go nowâ€, HuffPost UK revealed.

And on Friday Sky News revealed the PM had postponed a planned trip to China because Beijing had decided to â€œprioritise a visit from President Trumpâ€.

But making clear she intended to pursue business as usual, May said she had â€œhad a cold all weekâ€, and planned to update Parliament next week on progress since her Brexit speech in Florence and plans announced in her address to conference to introduce an energy price cap.

Yui Mok - PA Images via Getty Images Theresa May speaking in her constituency on Friday

The intervention, made from a fundraising event in Kent on Friday, could mean rebels will now face a longer fight to depose her.

In order to trigger an official confidence vote through the partyâ€™s 1922 Committee of backbenchers, 48 MPs would need to formally say she should stand down.

And while he would not give an exact figure on those who were backing his intervention, Shapps admitted it was less than the number needed.

Chelmsford MP Vicky Ford told the BBC Shapps was â€œcompletely out of touchâ€ with the vast majority of MPs and Tory members.

â€œFurthermore, I do not think itâ€™s what the public want. They want us to get on with the job...stick together and act as a team,â€ she added.

In a jibe at both Shapps and an election campaign blunder by Labourâ€™s shadow home secretary, Nadine Dorries, MP for Mid Bedfordshire, told Sky News: â€œIf Grant Shapps has 30 names then Diane Abbott is doing the counting.â€

Other backbenchers used social media to disparage the Shapps â€œplotâ€ and make it clear they were behind the prime minister.

Thanks Grant Shapps for rearranging my Day ... not! pic.twitter.com/bSggLYG5Cz â€” nigelevansRibbleV. (@nigelmp) October 6, 2017

Grant Shapps is an anagram of 'nag trash PPS'

Any more anagram suggestions or for his alter-ego Mike Green? â€” Michael Fabricant (@Mike_Fabricant) October 6, 2017

Environment Secretary Michael Gove, who ran in last yearâ€™s leadership contest, said May should remain prime minister â€œas long as she wantsâ€.

â€œThe prime ministerâ€™s been doing a fantastic job. She showed an amazing degree of resilience and courage this week,â€ he said on Friday morning.

â€œThe truth is that the overwhelming majority of Conservative MPs, the entirety of the Cabinet, the overwhelming majority of people want the prime minister to concentrate on doing the job which 14 million people elected her to do.

â€œIt would be disrespectful to those people to do anything other than concentrate on those areas where action is necessary.â€

Events which could now force the PMâ€™s hand include mass cabinet resignations - after her claim she has their full suppport - and longer term, poor performances for Conservative candidates in next yearâ€™s local elections.

PA Wire/PA Images George Osborne says the clock is ticking on May'd departure

Evening Standard editor and former chanceller George Osborne effectively used his paperâ€™s editorial to claim the â€œclock is tickingâ€ on Mayâ€™s departure and that her best option was to set her own timetable.

â€œBehind it all lies the simple fact: Mrs May called an election four months ago to increase her majority and her authority, and instead she lost both,â€ it read.

â€œAlmost everyone in the cabinet and the parliamentary party agrees she cannot possibly fight the next election. That makes her position much weaker than either John Majorâ€™s or Gordon Brownâ€™s.

â€œBluntly, there are three possible futures Mrs May now faces. She can decide sheâ€™s had enough and quit this autumn...but history suggests that party leaders, let alone prime ministers, rarely jump before they are pushed â€” David Cameron was the recent exception.

â€œThe second possible future is the one unfolding now: a bloody series of attempted coups, protestations of loyalty and bitter recriminations that ultimately leads to her exit.
TITLE: Theresa May Refuses To Quit: 'I Am Providing Calm Leadership'
