TEXT:
It sounds like â€œGame of Thronesâ€ Season 8 wonâ€™t be the Sam old thing.

News recently broke that the final seasonâ€™s episodes could come in at around $15 million each, and that the show will bring back directors Miguel Sapochnik and David Nutter.

â€œWe assembled a team of directors this year who have been in charge of some of our big episodes in the past,â€ John Bradley, who plays Sam Tarly on the show, told HuffPost. â€œMiguel and David have done some of the standout episodes of previous seasons. Clearly every single episode of the six youâ€™ve got left in Season 8 is gonna be monumental and needs somebody at the helm whoâ€™s done that kind of high-stakes, high-octane direction before for us.â€

â€œI think what we used to call Episode 9 in â€˜Game of Thronesâ€™ folklore â€” the episode when everything comes to a head and you get a lot of spectacular sequences â€” I think youâ€™re gonna get six â€˜Episode 9sâ€™ this year,â€ Bradley added. â€œYou can tell that because weâ€™ve got directors who have been in charge of some of the most huge setpieces in the past doing episodes all throughout the season.â€

Showrunners David Benioff and Dan Weiss are set to direct the finale, which Bradley calls â€œpoetic.â€

â€œItâ€™s in the right hands there,â€ the actor said. â€œThey know everything about the show. Theyâ€™ve been in charge of everything â€• every key decision in all seven seasons so far has been made by David and Dan. I think theyâ€™ve done an incredible job with this series. They deserve everything they get, and they deserve the right to finish this show off in the way they see fit. I donâ€™t think thereâ€™s anybody better qualified, so I canâ€™t wait.â€

The actor continued talking to HuffPost about â€œGame of Thrones,â€ explaining the reason Sam seemed to take credit for Gillyâ€™s (Hannah Murray) big discovery on the show, and opened up about his upcoming project, â€œAmerican Satan,â€ a supernatural thriller about a rock band that may find itself in an actual deal with the devil.

How do you fit in other projects while doing â€œGame of Thronesâ€?

Itâ€™s a little different this year because the way the schedule works out, but usually you have the last six months of the year taken by â€œGame of Thrones,â€ and the first six months of the year youâ€™re pretty much free to do whatever you want. So thatâ€™s been nice over the last few years â€• the fact that we have all this time to play around with things and do different projects and venture into slightly uncharted territory as far as our careers are concerned, but knowing that we have this security, that we have this brilliant thing to go back to in the last six months of the year. Thatâ€™s kind of a really nice comfort blanket.

We filmed [â€œAmerican Satanâ€] a long time ago now. We filmed it spring 2016 â€” March, April 2016. Yeah, it was a long time ago. This is the way they go with movies, the fact that you filmed them so long ago. Youâ€™ve kind of forgotten about them and you kind of have to refresh your memory before you can talk about them again. â€œAmerican Satan,â€ weâ€™re talking a good 18 months ago now.

So how did you refresh your memory?

By just reading the original script again, watching the movie for the first time, and kind of being reminded of that shooting experience, which was a strange shooting experience. On â€œGame of Thrones,â€ weâ€™re so used to having lots of time to shoot and a lot at our disposal, and â€œAmerican Satanâ€ was a little bit different, much more kind of a self-sufficient, resourceful thing going on. We had to shoot when we could on this project in this slightly less formulaic way. Itâ€™s a much less orthodox way of filming than Iâ€™m used to.

Thatâ€™s one of the things that first attracted me to it. Iâ€™ve done indie movies before, and I often like the kind of danger of them, that little bit of uncertainty, and that little bit of energy that comes from a group of people who have to make choices artistically and solve problems artistically when you donâ€™t necessarily have a lot of money to throw at a problem.

What can you tell us about your character, Ricky Rollins?

All the characters that I play tend to be in quite dark places, psychologically, and [donâ€™t have] that much faith in themselves. Theyâ€™re crippled by self-doubt or low self-esteem or envy of other people or a dissatisfaction with life. Theyâ€™re such great characters to play because you can deal with internal conflict, and you can deal with all those dark psychological areas a character like Samwell, especially, basically inhabits.

The thing that I found refreshing about this film is that I play a character for the first time really [whoâ€™s] beaming with self-confidence. Heâ€™s absolutely overflowing with self-confidence. He has absolute belief in himself and it may be deluded. It may be completely misguided belief in his own ability, but he has them. He can go into any room in any situation and take it by the scruff of the neck because he believes he is Superman. He believes he is bulletproof. This guy has not got any of that crippling Samwell Tarly self-doubt. Heâ€™s got absolute â€” perhaps wrongfully, but â€” absolute belief in himself.

Malcolm McDowell is in this movie. Did you talk about â€œA Clockwork Orange,â€ or is that taboo to bring up?

Twelve months before â€œAmerican Satanâ€ started shooting, I really became a kind of [Stanley] Kubrick obsessive ... then when I found out Malcolm McDowell was in this movie I was so desperate to get him to talk about it, and so I thought, â€œIâ€™m gonna ask him everything. This is going to be direct about what itâ€™s like to work with Stanley Kubrick.â€ And then I thought, â€œWell, maybe he wants to get away from all that. Maybe he talked enough about â€˜A Clockwork Orange.â€™ Maybe he just sees that as one movie in his career, and heâ€™s done lots of other great things he might want to talk about. Maybe heâ€™s sick of talking about Kubrick.â€

I kind of danced around the issue for a long time, and I wanted to bring it up so often â€” just kind of pin him down and get him on my own where I could finally ask him the question, â€œWhat was it like?â€ and hopefully he has some stories about him. I knew I had to walk on eggshells around [McDowell] a little bit because he may not be quite fond of me. I found out heâ€™s very, very happy to talk about Stanley Kubrick.

I think heâ€™s still incredibly proud to have worked with him and have that association with him. He told a famous story about Kubrick trying to con Malcolm out of money [...] I heard that story before when I was getting beamed into my Kubrick fascination, but to hear it from Malcolm and to hear him talk about those days in vivid detail, I really got an impression of what it was like to work with Kubrick.

In â€œGame of Thronesâ€ Season 7, thereâ€™s a scene where Gilly seems to uncover that Prince Rhaegar had an annulment, but Sam cuts her off. Then he brings up that info later to Bran. A lot of people on Twitter were upset, but what do you think about what happened?

Sam hasnâ€™t consciously plagiarized Gillyâ€™s idea there. Heâ€™s not giving her the elbow. Heâ€™s not really necessary taking credit for someone elseâ€™s work because â€¦ Sam heard that because heâ€™s so good at processing information now. He can take information in, almost subconsciously, and almost without thinking about it. His eyes and his ears are constantly attuned to absorbing information, so heâ€™s able to absorb that without even necessarily thinking about it. Sam is like a radio, and if thereâ€™s information in the air, he will pick it up, and he will store it whenever he needs it.

Itâ€™s not about him ... taking credit for her idea. He probably wasnâ€™t even aware of where he heard that information. He just knows he heard it somewhere in the air, and he was able to pick it up and process it.

What I will say that in fairness, Gilly did tell Sam that, and Sam didnâ€™t necessarily say that Gilly was the one who started that, but Jorah Mormont didnâ€™t go back to Daenerys saying Samwell Tarly cured him of greyscale. Heâ€™s not gone back there name-checking Sam for saving his life. Heâ€™s not mentioned the name Samwell Tarly to Jon Snow or Daenerys, so Samâ€™s not getting his credit there for something he actually did.

Although Sam is taking a little bit of credit for something that he didnâ€™t do, heâ€™s also not getting credit for something that he actually did, so I think in terms of the equilibrium, heâ€™s getting just the right amount of credit from a slightly different source than he probably deserved.

â€œAmerican Satanâ€ is in theaters Oct. 13.
TITLE: 'Game Of Thrones' Star Says Every Episode Of Season 8 Is 'Monumental'

Money Can't Buy You Happiness Say The Ringmasters Writer and comedy performer Madi Maxwell-Libby performs her poem Kids, Coins, Cuts in a vlog for HuffPost UK.

Conservatives.

TEXT:
One Day Without Us 2018 We want to restore the courage, heroism and dignity, the adventure and discovery that is part of the experience of migration. As migrants and non-migrants, we want to celebrate and acknowledge the contributions that migrants have made to our country in the past and continue to make today. Author, freelance journalist and blogger

A Year On And Theresa May Has Delivered Nothing But A Weak And Wobbly Government One year of Theresa May is as good a proof as any that Britain is held back by the Tories. The failed politics of austerity have led to a crisis in living standards, millions of children living in poverty, and our health services brought to its knees. Theresa May has failed to deliver on her message of equality and fairness, and has let down working families across the country through her chaotic government. Labour MP for Denton and Reddish

The Prime Minister's Decision To Leave Euratom Shows She Is Willing To Put Ideology Above Jobs And Nuclear Safety Frankly the national interest, access to cancer treatments, and the strength of British industries are far more important than the Prime Minister's pet concerns. That is why Labour has called a debate today in Parliament on our membership of Euratom and why we will continue to put pressure on the Prime Minister to drop her opposition to Euratom and to put jobs and nuclear safety first. Shadow Secretary of State for Exiting the EU, Labour MP for Holborn and St Pancras

I'm Talking But No One Is Listening In the poem Punchline, performed exclusively for HuffPost UK here, spoken-word artist KReimer talks about cuts to mental health services and how hard it is to get help. Spoken word artist, creative producer and Roundhouse Resident Artist

Letters Do Not Bring Good News. Just Bad News, In Good English John Akinde performs his poem Letters in an exclusive vlog for HuffPost UK. In it he touches on how a letter took away the place he called home in the name of gentrification, how letters tell him what money he owes, where to be, and that he needs to vote. However, he doesn't ever get a letter telling him who represents him. Artist and part of the Roundhouse Poetry Collective

Call Me Woman And Feel The Majesty Of It Roll Off Your Tongue Women are stronger when they march together, says writer Michelle Fisher in her poem Terms of Endearment. In a vlog for HuffPost UK she speaks about her disappointment in our female prime minister and her government's decisions, the election of Donald Trump and how when we march as one, we are strong. Writer and part of the Roundhouse Poetry Collective.

Money Can't Buy You Happiness Say The Ringmasters Writer and comedy performer Madi Maxwell-Libby performs her poem Kids, Coins, Cuts in a vlog for HuffPost UK. In it, she speaks about the severe inequality in our society today, benefit cuts and the children left behind. Writer and comedy performer

My Jihad Is About Judging Less And Loving More Spoken word artist Amani Z Saeed performs her poem Radical Love exclusively for HuffPost UK. In the vlog she speaks of her frustration with terrorism and the Islamophobia that follows. Spoken word artist and part of the Roundhouse Poetry Collective

Voting Is Protesting... In Their Language Benna has never voted before. In this vlog for HuffPost UK, in which he performs his poem Why I've Never Voted, he talks about how voting is protest. He says 'the things that happen when I don't vote are the same things that happen when my peers do,' and how it is down to young people to ensure that the 'views from down here' reach the 'silver spoon meeting rooms'. Spoken word artist, social entrepreneur and Roundhouse Resident Artist

I Am Voting, I Just Wish I Knew More Doug Deans, in the poem Bloody Right, describes a conversation between a father and daughter. In this vlog, Doug performs the poem and touches on the frustration one young woman is facing - she doesn't know who to vote for or whether she knows enough. Writer, performer and part of the Roundhouse Poetry Collective

Strong And Stable Kids Need Feeding! In the four years since it launched, The Universal Infant Free School Meals (UIFSM) policy has had a huge impact. Over 85% of children in theirâ€‹ first three years of primary school now eat a healthy school lunch, compared to less than 45% in 2013. That's something to be really proud of, so whyâ€‹ pull it so abruptly!? MBE, world-renowned chef and food campaigner

Putting Ourselves First In This Election This election isn't about the things it's supposed to be about. It's not about leaders, parties, candidates, rallies. It's not about wall to wall news coverage, interviews, speeches and gaffes. It's not about them. It's about us. Writer and musician, writing on politics, music and religion. www.twitter.com/joseph_finlay

The Labour Manifesto Is A New Deal For Public Health The Labour Party has proudly affirmed that the state should act in the interest of the many rather than the few. No doubt you will hear repeated scare-quotes, such as, "Labour plans amount to the biggest state intervention in the economy for decades", that redistribution is "dangerously left-wing" or "unworkable" and that nobody wants to see the return of the "the nanny, interventionist state". Doctor and campaigner working in the NHS, member of the BMA's Junior Doctors committee. Writing in personal capacity.

The Music Industry Is Uniting To Get Young People To Vote United, our brands are penetrating the echo-chamber and introducing the next generation to the policies affecting their future. Electoral registration creates a mental foothold, a subconscious investment which will lead to candidate selection and ultimately voting on June 8th. Music Editor, Headfirst Bristol

In Bury South, Labour Voters Are Plumping For Strong And Stable Over Principled And Weak We're in Bury South, a seat held by Labour's Ivan Lewis for twenty years. Around the table are eight local women aged between thirty and fifty. After some introductions, our moderator James Morris asks two questions. "Who did you vote for in 2015?" Each woman takes it in turn to reply. Labour. Labour. Labour. Labour. Labour. Labour. Didn't vote. Labour. "And second question, who would you vote for if the election were held tomorrow?" Conservatives. Conservatives. Conservatives. Conservatives. Conservatives. Conservatives. Conservatives. Conservatives. I settle back in my chair. This feels like a big deal. Elections analyst and political consultant
TITLE: Beyond Brexit

SUMMARY:
Sie verurteilten die Mutter und kritisierten, Lensing habe wohl mehr Interesse an ihrem Smartphone als an ihrem eigenen Kind.
Er schoss das Foto und stellte es ins Internet - vermutlich ohne darÃ¼ber nachzudenken, wie sich die Mutter dabei fÃ¼hlen kÃ¶nnte.
Mary Katherine Backstrom, Bloggerin bei Mom Babble setzte sofort einen Kommentar unter das Bild, in dem sie Lensing in Schutz nahm.
"Ich ignoriere die Bilder und die Kommentare und suche Halt bei denen, die wissen, wie ich wirklich bin", sagte Lensing.
"Ich habe keine Macht Ã¼ber das, was im Internet passiert und ich weiÃŸ, dass ich die beste Mutter fÃ¼r meine Kinder bin, dass ich sie liebe und in meiner Erziehung das Beste gebe."
TEXT:
Eine Mutter wurde von einem fremden Mann am Flughafen fotografiert

Sie blickt aufs Smartphone, wÃ¤hrend ihre zwei Monate Tochter vor ihr auf einer Decke liegt

Im Internet schlug ihr dafÃ¼r viel Kritik entgegen - ohne dass jemand die Geschichte hinter dem Bild kannte

Das Internet kann ein ziemlich mieser Ort sein. Vor einiger Zeit verbreitete sich ein Bild von Molly Lensing und ihrer Tochter im Internet und wurde wild diskutiert.

zut

Ein fremder Mann hatte die junge Mutter am Flughafen in Colorado fotografiert, als Lensing und ihre damals zwei Monate alte Tochter Anastasia auf dem RÃ¼ckweg von einem Familienbesuch waren.

Lensing sitzt wartend in der Halle und blickt auf ihr Smartphone, vor ihr auf dem Boden liegt ihr Baby auf einer Decke. Der Mann stellte das Bild bei Facebook ein und schrieb dazu: "Ich fÃ¼rchte mich vor dem Tag, an dem die Technologie Ã¼ber die Menschlichkeit triumphieren wird. Auf der Welt wird es nur noch eine Generation aus Idioten geben. - Albert Einstein."

Foto: Facebook

Es dauerte nicht lange, bis die Internet-User schonungslos ihre Meinung zu dem Bild kundtaten. Sie verurteilten die Mutter und kritisierten, Lensing habe wohl mehr Interesse an ihrem Smartphone als an ihrem eigenen Kind.

Lensing war geschockt, wie sehr ihre PrivatsphÃ¤re verletzte wurde

Weil das Bild sich so schnell verbreitete, dauerte es nicht lange, bis Lensing das Bild selbst entdeckte - und geschockt war, wie sehr ihre PrivatsphÃ¤re verletzt worden war.

â¨ Mehr zum Thema: Eine Schwangere wurde aus einem Restaurant geworfen - wegen ihres T-Shirts

Dass alle sie verurteilten, obwohl niemand wusste, in welcher Situation das Bild entstanden war, verletzte sie zutiefst.

Nun hatte sie das BedÃ¼rfnis, die Geschichte hinter dem Bild mit der Ã–ffentlichkeit zu teilen. "Wir hatten das Pech, am Flughafen festzusitzen, weil es an diesem Tag einen Systemabsturz gab", sagte Lensing gegenÃ¼ber "TODAY Parents", einem Format des Nachrichtensenders NBC.

(Im Video: "Ich schÃ¤mte mich fÃ¼r meine lauten Kinder - dann sagte ein Kindertherapeut diese 5 Worte zu mir"; der Text geht darunter weiter)





"Ich habe Anastasia mehrere Stunden im Arm gehalten und in ihrem BabytrÃ¤ger getragen"

Ihre FlÃ¼ge hÃ¤tten VerspÃ¤tung gehabt und sie sei zusÃ¤tzlich noch mehrfach umgebucht worden, sodass sie Ã¼ber 20 Stunden an verschiedenen FlughÃ¤fen habe warten mÃ¼ssen, sagte sie - und das mit einem zwei Monate altem Kind.

"Ich habe Anastasia mehrere Stunden im Arm gehalten und in ihrem BabytrÃ¤ger getragen", erzÃ¤hlte Lensing. "Meine Arme waren mÃ¼de und sie musste sich ausstrecken. Und ich musste meiner Familie mitteilen, wo ich bin - sie hatten sich schon gefragt, wo wir bleiben."

Ein Fremder Mann respektierte nicht ihre PrivatsphÃ¤re

All das schien den fremden Mann nicht zu interessieren, der sie ohne ihre Erlaubnis fotografierte - und er machte sich auch nicht die MÃ¼he, sie zu fragen. Er sah sie und verurteilte sie auf der Stelle.

Irgendein Mann, der nicht wusste, dass sie schon seit 20 Stunden mit ihrer Tochter festsaÃŸ. Ein Fremder, der es nicht lassen konnte, sich einzumischen.

Er schoss das Foto und stellte es ins Internet - vermutlich ohne darÃ¼ber nachzudenken, wie sich die Mutter dabei fÃ¼hlen kÃ¶nnte.

Lensing hatte kurz zuvor bei einem neuen Arbeitgeber als Kinderkrankenschwester angefangen.

"Ich hatte solche Angst, dass meine Mitarbeiter oder mein Chef dieses Bild und die Kommentare sehen und dann vielleicht denken, ich sollte nicht mehr mit Kindern arbeiten", sagte sie "TODAY Parents". "Aber zum GlÃ¼ck ist das nie passiert."

Lensing bekam UnterstÃ¼tzung von anderen MÃ¼ttern

Bei all der Kritik bekam Lensing aber von Anfang an auch viel UnterstÃ¼tzung von anderen MÃ¼ttern. Mary Katherine Backstrom, Bloggerin bei Mom Babble setzte sofort einen Kommentar unter das Bild, in dem sie Lensing in Schutz nahm.

"Nein, einfach nein", schrieb Backstrom. "Man sollte keine Fotos von erschÃ¶pften MÃ¼ttern am Flughafen machen - und sie dann auch noch in der Ã–ffentlichkeit bloÃŸstellen. Das ist widerlich und muss aufhÃ¶ren."

Backstrom ist selbst Mutter und kennt diese Situation sehr gut: "Mein Flug hatte auch schon mal VerspÃ¤tung, ich hatte kein einziges Mal meine Augen zugetan und ich hatte Angst, dass mein Baby vielleicht aus meinen Armen fallen wÃ¼rde, wenn ich weg dÃ¶se", schreibt sie.

â¨ Mehr zum Thema: Polizistin wurde aus dem Job gemobbt, als sie ein Baby bekam - das lieÃŸ sie nicht auf sich sitzen

"Ich habe keine Macht Ã¼ber das, was im Internet passiert"

Das Original-Bild wurde inzwischen von Facebook gelÃ¶scht - trotzdem wird es immer noch kopiert und geteilt. Lensing mÃ¼sse sich noch immer mit negativen Kommentaren auseinandersetzen, sagte sie "TODAY Parents".

"Ich ignoriere die Bilder und die Kommentare und suche Halt bei denen, die wissen, wie ich wirklich bin", sagte Lensing. "Ich habe keine Macht Ã¼ber das, was im Internet passiert und ich weiÃŸ, dass ich die beste Mutter fÃ¼r meine Kinder bin, dass ich sie liebe und in meiner Erziehung das Beste gebe."

â¨ Mehr zum Thema: An alle Mamas - wenn ihr euch das nÃ¤chste Mal mies fÃ¼hlt, lest den Facebook-Post dieser Mutter

(lk)

Sie stieg an Bord eines U-Bootes des dÃ¤nischen Ingenieurs Peter Madsen, Ã¼ber den Wall eine Reportage schreiben wollte.

TEXT:
Seit zwei Monaten wurde nach weiteren Ãœberresten der in DÃ¤nemark ermordeten Journalistin Kim Wall gesucht

Nun entdeckte die dÃ¤nische Polizei Walls Kopf und weitere Leichenteile der Schwedin

Wall soll von einem U-Boot-Bauer, Ã¼ber den sie schrieb, ermordet worden sein

Vor zwei Monaten machte ein Radfahrer in der Umgebung von Kopenhagen eine furchtbare Entdeckung: Nahe der Insel Amager fand er den Torso einer Frauenleiche. Arme und Beine fehlten, sowie auch der Kopf.

Den hat die dÃ¤nische Polizei nun gefunden. Bei der Leiche handelt es sich laut einem DNA-Test um die Journalistin Kim Wall. Der Fall um ihr Verschwinden und ihre Ermordung hatte weltweit fÃ¼r Aufsehen gesorgt.

U-Boot-Bauer unter Mordverdacht

Am 10. August wurde Wall das letzte Mal gesehen. Sie stieg an Bord eines U-Bootes des dÃ¤nischen Ingenieurs Peter Madsen, Ã¼ber den Wall eine Reportage schreiben wollte. Nachdem sich Wall in der Nacht nicht mehr meldete, riefen ihre Eltern die Seenotrettung.

Die Suche nach Wall begann - und endete mit dem grausigen Fund des Radfahrers. Die Polizei nahm den Erfinder Madsen fest, er steht unter Mordverdacht.

Madsen bestreitet jedoch, Wall ermordet zu haben. ZunÃ¤chst hatte er ausgesagt, die Journalistin nach der Fahrt mit dem U-Boot wieder an Land abgesetzt zu haben. Nach technischen Problemen sei das Boot dann gesunken.

SpÃ¤ter Ã¤nderte Madsen seine Aussage. Er behauptet nun, Wall sei bei einem UnglÃ¼ck an Bord des U-Bootes zu Tode gekommen. AnschlieÃŸend habe er die Leiche in die Bucht geworfen.

(ujo)
TITLE: Grausiger Fund: Kopf der in DÃ¤nemark ermordeten Journalistin Kim Wall wurde gefunden

16 Stars Who Were In 'Sex And The City' Before They Were Famous
TEXT:
Kim Cattrall is done talking about the canned â€˜Sex And The Cityâ€™ film, after it was revealed that her lack of involvement had thrown the brakes on the project.

Last month, the Daily Mail claimed that Kim had pulled out of playing Samantha Jones in a third big-screen adaptation of â€˜Sex And The Cityâ€™, due to producers failing to meet her apparent â€œdiva demandsâ€.

In response, Kim said sheâ€™d made no â€œdemandsâ€ but had simply decided not to do the film.

Jon Furniss via Getty Images The cast of 'Sex And The City'

â€˜Sex And The Cityâ€™ fans have been divided over the news, with some arguing that Kim should give them one last outing as Samantha (particularly after â€˜Sex And The City 2â€™ proved to be such a dud), and others claiming itâ€™s her right to not take part if she doesnâ€™t want to.

But it seems Kim is done with the conversation completely now, publicly urging one fan to â€œmove onâ€ from the topic.

One fan tweeted her saying he was â€œconfusedâ€ after reading she said she was â€œtoo oldâ€ to play Samantha, despite her having spoken out about Hollywood ageism in the past, to which she responded: â€œIâ€™ve played â€˜SAMâ€™ for 20 years. Am moving on & so should you.â€

Perhaps sensing the tweet would get media attention (or maybe we shouldnâ€™t be so cynical), she then urged him to watch her more recent series, â€˜Sensitive Skinâ€™, on Netflix.

Josh, I've played 'SAM' for 20 years. Am moving on & so should you. Try #SensitiveSkin my show on @Netflix https://t.co/mJYOybZMi8 â€” Kim Cattrall (@KimCattrall) October 6, 2017

â€˜Sex And The Cityâ€™ cast members Sarah Jessica Parker and Kristin Davis have both expressed their disappointment that the film was ultimately canned, with SJP saying: â€œWe had this beautiful, funny, heartbreaking, joyful, very relatable script and story.

â€œItâ€™s not just disappointing that we donâ€™t get to tell the story and have that experience, but more so for that audience that has been so vocal in wanting another movie.â€

By way of response, Kim admitted she thinks her former co-star â€œcould have been nicerâ€ about her decision not to return.

16 Stars Who Were In 'Sex And The City' Before They Were Famous
TITLE: 'Sex And The City' Star Kim Cattrall Is Done Talking About Third Film Drama

SUMMARY:
Lal Bahadur Shastri, India's second prime minister, who succeeded Jawaharlal Nehru in 1964, enters his 114th year on 2 October 2017, with muted remembrance from the nation, though his legacy as an astute statesman is more pertinent than ever in the prevailing political climate.
Since then, the family was looked after by a cousin of his mother's, well enough for Shastri to have eventually become the prime minister of the country.
Since Prime Minister Narendra Modi came to power in 2014, we haven't heard the last of his humble origins and, in contrast, the ills of the dynastic behemoth that is the Congress.
As a child, Shastri had a syncretic upbringing, studied Urdu under a maulavi, and later went on to work in the independence movement actively.
Shastri died, allegedly under mysterious circumstances, in Tashkent, of a cardiac arrest, a day after signing a major international treaty.
TEXT:
ADVERTISEMENT

In the rush to remember the Mahatma on his birth anniversary, it is easy to forget one of MK Gandhi's most ardent followers, also born this day and a leading light of independent India.

Lal Bahadur Shastri, India's second prime minister, who succeeded Jawaharlal Nehru in 1964, enters his 114th year on 2 October 2017, with muted remembrance from the nation, though his legacy as an astute statesman is more pertinent than ever in the prevailing political climate.

Born Lal Bahadur Varma, in 1904, to Sharada Prasad and Ramdulari Devi, he discarded his caste name and opted for the simple epithet of the scholar â€” "shastri" â€” after he becoming acquainted with Gandhi's anti-caste philosophy. Shastri's name had come up in the public discourse earlier this year during a controversy that erupted over the re-naming of Mughal Sarai railway station in Uttar Pradesh.

In a bitter battle of ideologies, Shastri was pitted by the Congress against Deen Dayal Upadhay, a right-wing thinker who has been resurrected for his centenary year by the ruling Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) government at the Centre and in the states it rules. But the differences between the two men could not have been starker.

As an earlier piece on HuffPost India pointed out, born a Kayastha, Shastri grew up in a milieu that valued perhaps that most robust expression of Bharatiya sanskar (a virtue the BJP and its allies have appropriated according to its whims): the joint family.

Shastri's mother, widowed at a young age when he was only a year old, moved to his grandfather's place, who also died within a couple of years. Since then, the family was looked after by a cousin of his mother's, well enough for Shastri to have eventually become the prime minister of the country.

Since Prime Minister Narendra Modi came to power in 2014, we haven't heard the last of his humble origins and, in contrast, the ills of the dynastic behemoth that is the Congress. While both statements are true to an extent, if you are looking for a politician of humble origins who soared to unexpected heights by dint of sheer hard work, you have to start with Shastri.

As a child, Shastri had a syncretic upbringing, studied Urdu under a maulavi, and later went on to work in the independence movement actively. A participant of the Salt Satyagraha in 1930, he had dropped out of a government school, inspired by Gandhi's call to students to join the Congress. He would end up spending over two years in prison for his involvement in revolutionary activities, before eventually rising through the ranks of his party.

After Nehru died in office, Shastri was chosen as his successor over the right-leaning Morarji Desai for his firm belief in Nehruvian socialism as an instrument of social change. He had already been the minister for transport, during which time women were allegedly appointed as conductors for the first time.

Noted for his quiet demeanour, Shastri had a firm sense of self. "Perhaps due to my being small in size and soft of tongue, people are apt to believe that I am not able to be very firm," he had once said. "Though not physically strong, I think I am internally not so weak."

It was this inner fortitude that allowed him to take momentous decisions, such as steering a nation through the war with Pakistan in 1965, helping it recover its morale from the humiliating defeat in 1962 against the Chinese, and inspiring the public to collective action to tackle a crippling food shortage in the 1960s. When revolts erupted in Madras during his term over fears of imposition of Hindi as national language, mirroring a familiar discontent of our time, Shastri stepped in decisively to restore harmony.

Like a true leader of the people, Shastri stepped down from the role of railways minister in 1956, after a devastating accident led to the death of over 150 people in Tamil Nadu. Such a decision, which may have appeared obvious to a man of his integrity and conscientiousness, must seem odd to the leaders of today. India's last railway minister was removed from his portfolio after many more had died this year alone in a series of mishaps and tragedies that continue to wreak havoc across the country.

"Perhaps due to my being small in size and soft of tongue, people are apt to believe that I am not able to be very firm"

Among the several highlights of Shastri's career were his initiatives to create a dairy and farming revolution in India in a bid to make it self-sufficient in milk production and agriculture. "In the long run, the economic condition of the country will improve only if we plan the economy in a rational and scientific manner," he'd said, without losing focus from the industrial growth of the nation.

Shastri died, allegedly under mysterious circumstances, in Tashkent, of a cardiac arrest, a day after signing a major international treaty. Leaders like him, always hard to find, are now a vanishing generation.

Also on HuffPost
TITLE: Why India Mustn't Forget Lal Bahadur Shastri In The Rush Over Gandhi Jayanti

Jon Snow has been the face of Channel 4 News since 1989.
Jon Snow joined ITN in 1976 and became Washington Correspondent in 1984.
Since then, he has travelled the world to cover the news â€“ from the fall of the Berlin Wall and the release of Nelson Mandela, to Barack Obama's inauguration and the earthquake in Haiti.
His many awards include the Richard Dimbleby Bafta award for Best Factual Contribution to Television (2005), and Royal Television Society awards for Journalist of the Year (2006) and Presenter of the Year (2009).
TEXT:
Jon Snow has been the face of Channel 4 News since 1989.

Jon Snow joined ITN in 1976 and became Washington Correspondent in 1984. Since then, he has travelled the world to cover the news â€“ from the fall of the Berlin Wall and the release of Nelson Mandela, to Barack Obama's inauguration and the earthquake in Haiti.

His many awards include the Richard Dimbleby Bafta award for Best Factual Contribution to Television (2005), and Royal Television Society awards for Journalist of the Year (2006) and Presenter of the Year (2009).

TEXT:
Die Mehrheit der US-BÃ¼rger denkt, dass Trump ungeeignet ist, dass PrÃ¤sidentenamt auszufÃ¼hren

Doch Doug Sosnik, einer der renommiertesten Politikstrategen des Landes, glaubt: Trump wird wiedergewÃ¤hlt werden

Im Video oben seht ihr, warum zudem ein vorzeitiges Ende von Trumps Amtszeit unwahrscheinlich

Was soll man noch schreiben, Ã¼ber einen Mann, der auf jedem Meter derart aneckt, dass die ganze Welt erzittert? Ãœber Donald Trump, der sich mit seinem Rassismus, seiner Kriegstreiberei und seiner UnfÃ¤higkeit zu Regieren zum unbeliebtesten US-PrÃ¤sidenten der Neuzeit gemacht hat?

Doug Sosnik hat diese Frage in einem Artikel fÃ¼r die "Washington Post" fÃ¼r sich beantwortet: Er schreibt, dass Donald Trump seine Wiederwahl im Jahr 2020 gelingen wird. Obwohl 56 Prozent der US-BÃ¼rger ihn fÃ¼r ungeeignet halten, sein Amt auszufÃ¼hren. Und obwohl Trumps Beliebtheitswerte am Freitag wieder einmal auf ein Rekordtief fielen.

Sosnik war jahrelang Top-Berater des ehemaligen US-PrÃ¤sidenten Bill Clinton. Er ist als Politstratege fÃ¼r die Demokratische Partei in den USA tÃ¤tig.

Laut ihm gibt es gleich vier GrÃ¼nde, warum Trump sich Hoffnungen auf eine zweite Amtszeit im WeiÃŸen Haus machen kann:

Grund 1: Trump braucht keine Mehrheit fÃ¼r den Wahlsieg

Die Mehrheit der US-Amerikaner hat Donald Trump nicht gewÃ¤hlt. Seine Konkurrentin Hillary Clinton hat bei der Wahl drei Millionen Stimmen mehr bekommen als der jetzige US-PrÃ¤sident.

Trump gewann, weil es bei Wahlen in den USA darum geht, mehr WahlmÃ¤nner und -frauen fÃ¼r sich zu gewinnen als der Gegner.

Und das tat Trump. Mit Wahlsiegen in wichtigen Staaten wie Florida, die besonders viele Wahlmandate stellen. Doug Sosnik argumentiert nun: Bei der Wahl im Jahr 2020 kÃ¶nnte Trump auf die gleiche Weise gewinnen. "Trump weiÃŸ, dass die absolute Mehrheit zu gewinnen keine Voraussetzung ist, sondern hÃ¶chstens ein Anspruch", schreibt Sosnik.

TatsÃ¤chlich seien aber zwei der letzten drei PrÃ¤sidenten ohne absolute Mehrheit gewÃ¤hlt worden: George W. Bush - und eben Trump.

Grund 2: Die Politikverdrossenheit in den USA hilft Trump

Das Vertrauen in die Politik ist in den USA schwer beschÃ¤digt. Nicht nur die Demokraten haben damit zu kÃ¤mpfen, sondern auch die Republikaner. Donald Trumps Wahlsieg war Ausdruck dieses Frusts, dieser Wut auf das politische Establishment in Washington.

Sosnik schreibt, dass diese Stimmung im Land die Wahrscheinlichkeit erhÃ¶he, dass 2020 ein dritter, unabhÃ¤ngiger Kandidat sich um den Posten im WeiÃŸen Haus bemÃ¼hen werde. AuÃŸerdem kÃ¶nnten noch weitere Kandidaten vom politischen Rand das Duell von Republikanern und Demokraten stÃ¶ren.

"So ein breites Kandidatenfeld kÃ¶nnte dafÃ¼r sorgen, dass die Anti-Trump-Front aufgespalten wird", schreib Sosnik. "Das wÃ¼rde ihm die Wiederwahl sichern, wenn seine AnhÃ¤nger gleichzeitig weiter zu ihm halten."

Grund 3: Trumps Beliebtheit wird unterschÃ¤tzt

Und danach sieht es aus.

Zwar sehen nur 32 Prozent der US-BÃ¼rger Donald laut einer Umfrage der Nachrichtenagentur AP Donald Trumps PrÃ¤sidentschaft derzeit positiv - doch Sosnik glaubt, dass Erhebungen wie diese Trumps Beliebtheit unterschÃ¤tzen. So wÃ¼rden die Umfragen alle Wahlberechtigten berÃ¼cksichtigen. Und nicht nur diejenigen, die tatsÃ¤chlich als WÃ¤hler registriert und gewillt sind, zur Wahl zu gehen.

Hinzu kommt laut Sosnik: "Viele WÃ¤hler wollen einfach nicht offen zugeben, dass sie Trump gewÃ¤hlt haben und unterstÃ¼tzen."

Grund 4: Der fanatische Kern von Trumps AnhÃ¤ngerschaft

Dem harten Kern von Donald Trumps AnhÃ¤ngerschaft geht das anders. Sie halten eisern und lautstark zu ihrem PrÃ¤sidenten. Egal, was dieser macht. Sosnik erinnert in diesem Zusammenhang daran, dass Trump einmal im Wahlkampf sagte, er kÃ¶nne mitten auf der Fifth Avenue in Manhattan jemanden erschieÃŸen, und seine Fans wÃ¼rden weiter zu ihm halten.

Und noch einer weiteren Gruppe an AnhÃ¤ngern kÃ¶nne der US-PrÃ¤sident sich gewiss sein: "Denen, die ihm weiter die Treue halten, weil sie fest davon Ã¼berzeugt sind, dass er das System in die Luft jagen und echte VerÃ¤nderungen bewirken wird."

Sosniks Fazit: In einem gespaltenem Land wird Trump gewinnen

Ob Trump dies gelingen wird, bleibt hÃ¶chst fraglich. Auf jeden Fall hat der US-PrÃ¤sident mit einer RekordfÃ¼lle an politischen Traditionen in den Vereinigten Staaten gebrochen. Warum sollte er also nicht wiedergewÃ¤hlt werden, obwohl er so unbeliebt ist, wie noch nie ein PrÃ¤sident zuvor?

FÃ¼r Sosnik ist klar, dass Trump dies in einem politisch gespaltenem Land gelingen kann. "Wenn die Demokraten Trump schlagen wollen, mÃ¼ssen sie sich hinter einem Kandidaten vereinen", schreibt der Wahlkampf-Stratege.

Soll heiÃŸen: Einen innerparteilichen Grabenkampf, wie er 2016 zwischen Hillary Clinton und dem Senator Bernie Sanders stattfand, kÃ¶nnen sich die Demokraten bei der nÃ¤chsten Wahl nicht erlauben.

Die Demokraten dÃ¼rfen Trump auf keinen Fall unterschÃ¤tzen, warnt Sosnik. Er schreibt: "Es wÃ¤re ein Fehler zu glauben, Trump kÃ¶nnte 2020 nicht gewinnen. Genau so, wie es ein Fehler war zu glauben, er wÃ¼rde erst gar nicht PrÃ¤sident werden."
TITLE: Renommierter Politik-Analyst: "Donald Trump ist auf dem besten Weg, wiedergewÃ¤hlt zu werden"

SUMMARY:
Image caption Steve Hewlett 1958-2017Full text of the lecture as delivered at the Royal Television Society on 28 September 2017:I am honoured to be asked to deliver this, the first annual Steve Hewlett memorial lecture.
Thank you to the RTS, the Media Society and to Rachel for inviting me to deliver it.
It's great to have Steve's boys - Freddie, Billy, Bertie - here, his sister Sue and other members of the family too.
Steve's death was news - national news - which, had he been here to see it and to see you all gathered here for the first annual Steve Hewlett memorial lecture - would have produced one of those characteristically laconic Hewlett chuckles.
It was news, of course, because millions had grown used to turning up the car radio or stopping the ironing or waiting before turning on the kettle to make sure they not miss the latest weekly instalment of the Hewlett cancer chronicle - in which a middle aged man described the pain in his oesophagus; the splitting of his nails or chapping of his feet; the search for the drug or the treatment that might buy him some relief and some more time before the end which he sensed and we sensed was coming all too fast.
TEXT:
Image caption Steve Hewlett 1958-2017

Full text of the lecture as delivered at the Royal Television Society on 28 September 2017:

I am honoured to be asked to deliver this, the first annual Steve Hewlett memorial lecture.

Thank you to the RTS, the Media Society and to Rachel for inviting me to deliver it. It's great to have Steve's boys - Freddie, Billy, Bertie - here, his sister Sue and other members of the family too.

Steve's death was news - national news - which, had he been here to see it and to see you all gathered here for the first annual Steve Hewlett memorial lecture - would have produced one of those characteristically laconic Hewlett chuckles.

It was news, of course, because millions had grown used to turning up the car radio or stopping the ironing or waiting before turning on the kettle to make sure they not miss the latest weekly instalment of the Hewlett cancer chronicle - in which a middle aged man described the pain in his oesophagus; the splitting of his nails or chapping of his feet; the search for the drug or the treatment that might buy him some relief and some more time before the end which he sensed and we sensed was coming all too fast.
TITLE: Nick Robinson

"Ã‰coute l'arbre et la feuille" a Ã©tÃ© publiÃ© aux Ã©ditions Flammarion.

LIVRE - C'est un livre pour ceux qui veulent voyager, se mettre au vert et Ã©couter les histoires (millÃ©naires) que les arbres nous racontent. Il vient d'Ãªtre publiÃ© par David G. Haskell aux Ã©ditions Flammarion ce 4 octobre.

Le nom de ce biologiste et Ã©crivain vous dit peut-Ãªtre quelque chose. Il est l'auteur de "Un an dans la vie d'une forÃªt", finaliste du prix Pulitzer. Pendant un an, jour aprÃ¨s jour, saison aprÃ¨s saison, il a observÃ© un mÃ¨tre carrÃ© de verdure, au beau milieu d'une forÃªt des Appalaches.

Cette fois-ci, avec "Ã‰coute l'arbre et la feuille", Haskell s'intÃ©resse Ã  plus de 10 arbres mythiques autour du monde. LÃ  aussi, il scrute les moindres dÃ©tails sur les troncs, les feuilles et les branches. Mais surtout, il Ã©coute. Il Ã©coute (parfois scientifiquement) le craquement de l'Ã©corce, le bruit de la sÃ¨ve, le ballet des fourmis, la pluie sur les feuilles, les chants des oiseaux. Des sons si bien restituÃ©s Ã  l'Ã©crit qu'Haskell nous emmÃ¨ne avec lui dans la canopÃ©e, comme dans la 86e rue de Broadway.

Ces enregistrements sont accessibles sur son site. Nous avons, nous, reproduit son pÃ©riple sur la carte ci-dessous. Chaque Ã©tape s'accompagne des dessins de Valentine Plessy. Elles vous donneront un aperÃ§u de l'incroyable voyage Ã©colo-sensible de cet aventurier Ã  la main verte.

TEXT:
WASHINGTON â€• On Friday, visitors to the Washington Monument are being greeted by an unusual sight and sound: a large video screen playing President Donald Trumpâ€™s infamous â€œAccess Hollywoodâ€ tape, accompanied by statistics about sexual assault. Itâ€™s playing for 12 hours, on a continuous loop.

In other words, in the shadow of a memorial shaped like a giant phallus, people get to hear the president of the United States talk about grabbing women â€œby the pussy.â€

Amanda Terkel/HuffPost UltraViolet set up a large video screen playing the Donald Trump "Access Hollywood" video Friday.

The womenâ€™s rights group UltraViolet set up the display Friday, approximately one year after the 2005 tape became public. Trump and Billy Bush, then of â€œAccess Hollywood,â€ were caught on a hot mic bragging about their sexual conquests.

â€œAnd when youâ€™re a star, they let you do it,â€ Trump said. â€œYou can do anything. ... Grab them by the pussy.â€

â€œThatâ€™s why I donâ€™t like Donald Trump,â€ one teenage girl said as she walked by the screen, right after the part where Trump said, â€œI moved on her like a bitch.â€

The video display attracted plenty of attention, with many people stopping for a moment to take a picture. Most were surprised UltraViolet was given permission to put up the video on public land, and one Canadian visitor said it was â€œrefreshing that it was allowed.â€

Everyone who spoke with HuffPost said they remembered Trumpâ€™s comments. One man, originally from Australia, said he felt Trump and the tape represented the â€œdemiseâ€ of the U.S. political system and its position in the world.

The display was, in many ways, a fitting coda to the week, where there were plenty of other stories about toxic masculinity.

For starters, Las Vegas is still recovering from one of the largest mass shootings in history, carried out by Stephen Paddock. Employees at a Starbucks he frequented remember him verbally abusing his girlfriend on various occasions. As HuffPostâ€™s Melissa Jeltsen has noted, â€œOver the past few years, a number of mass killers and violent terrorists have had one striking thing in common: They practiced their abuse on family members before targeting the public.â€

Then New York Times had a blockbuster story filled with allegations Hollywood producer and Democratic mega-donor Harvey Weinstein has been sexually harassing women for years.

On Thursday, BuzzFeed published documents showing how Breitbart News has smuggled white nationalist ideas into the mainstream. Buried in the story was a disturbing section about how male journalists at reputable publications gave suggestions about ways the conservative site could attack women online. Mitchell Sunderland, a senior staff writer for Viceâ€™s womenâ€™s section, encouraged Breitbart News to go after writer Lindy West, saying it should â€œmock this fat feminist.â€

The Atlantic came out with an in-depth look at the heartbreaking death of Tim Piazza, a young man who died during hazing at a Penn State fraternity. He and the other pledges were forced to drink massive amounts of alcohol and then run an obstacle course. He later opened a door that happened to lead to the basement, and fell down the stairs. No one in the fraternity called 911 until 12 hours later.

And Rep. Tim Murphy (R-Pa.) resigned after it was revealed that he had pressured a woman to have an abortion while publicly touting his anti-abortion stance. Murphy was having an extramarital affair with the woman. The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette also reported that Murphy mistreated his staff.

Trump supporters quickly jumped on the Weinstein news to use as a cudgel against Democrats.

Not a single mention of big Democrat donor #HarveyWeinstein in hard copy of @washingtonpost pic.twitter.com/qfktuhSfRF â€” Sean Spicer (@seanspicer) October 6, 2017

Will She/they all Disavow? Embattled Hollywood Producer Harvey Weinstein Raised Big Bucks For Hillary Clinton & Dems https://t.co/6PHQaAQFNm â€” Donald Trump Jr. (@DonaldJTrumpJr) October 6, 2017

The @GOP emails list with Harvey Weinstein political donations to Dems, @GOPChairwoman "returning this dirty money should be a no brainer." pic.twitter.com/mX0u2LOddw â€” Anthony Terrell (@AnthonyNBCNews) October 6, 2017

Those attacks rang rather hollow, considering the president they are supporting is a man who has been accused of sexual assault by multiple women.

And on Friday, the administration of this man rolled back requirements for employers to provide birth control coverage in health care plans for their workers.

Women could have found some consolation in the fact that there may be a 45-foot-tall statue of a woman on the National Mall beginning next month. But it turns out that woman will be naked.
TITLE: Trump's 'P***y' Tape Is Playing All Day In The Shadow Of A Giant Phallus

TEXT:
Chizzy Akudolu has brushed off the suggestion that her early â€˜Strictly Come Dancingâ€™ exit was rooted in racism.

Last week, Chizzy became the first of this yearâ€™s â€˜Strictlyâ€™ contestants to be given her marching orders, following a dance-off against comedian Brian Conley.

Gareth Cattermole via Getty Images Chizzy Akudolu

However, Chizzy has now had her say on the matter, claiming she doesnâ€™t believe it to be the case.

Speaking to Metro, she explained: â€œThere are real racial injustices going on in the world and I think is dangerous to throw the race card in for something that has no bearing.

Chizzy had a particularly emotional reaction when she first discovered that sheâ€™d be leaving the competition, leaving us all crying along at home with her, later thanking professional partner Pasha Kovalev for helping her throughout her time on the show.

She said: â€œThis dude, I have loved every minute dancing with him and it will continue because I will just be going round his house to dance now. But I donâ€™t have his address so if anyone could email me I would appreciate it.â€

The remaining celebrity contestants will hit the dance floor with their professional partners for the third time tonight (7 October) for Strictlyâ€™s annual Movies Week.

12 Most Controversial 'Strictly Come Dancing' Moments
TITLE: Strictly Come Dancing's Chizzy Akudolu Addresses Viewers' Racism Claims

Sechs Millionen Besucher haben das diesjÃ¤hrige, lÃ¤ngste Oktoberfest der Geschichte besucht, getrunken haben sie sieben Millionen MaÃŸ Bier. 127 Ochsen und 59 KÃ¤lber verspeisten die Besucher aus dem In- und Ausland, auch unzÃ¤hlige Hendl und Brezel fanden reiÃŸenden Absatz. Ein friedliches Oktoberfest

Bei den KÃ¶rperverletzungen gab es einen deutlichen RÃ¼ckgang, nur in 49 FÃ¤llen mussten die Beamten der Wiesenwache zu einer SchlÃ¤gerei mit MaÃŸkrÃ¼gen ausrÃ¼cken. Allerdings mussten 251 betrunkene Besucher ihren FÃ¼hrerschein abgeben und bei 353 Autofahrern lag die Promillegrenze Ã¼ber dem erlaubten Wert.

Besucher aus aller Welt

Immer wieder wurde eine junge NiederlÃ¤nderin auf der StraÃŸe belÃ¤stigt

Also startete sie eine Racheaktion und verÃ¶ffentlicht Selfies mit den MÃ¤nnern

Die Fotos seht ihr im Video oben

Die meisten Frauen kennen das: Wenn sie alleine unterwegs sind,pfeifen ihnen fremde MÃ¤nner hinterher, rufen ihnen nach und belÃ¤stigen sie.

Im Englischen wird das "Catcalling" genannt. Die junge NiederlÃ¤nderin Noa Jansma war so genervt davon, dass sie eine Gegenaktion auf Instagram startete. Unter dem Titel "Dear Catcallers" stellt sie Bilder von den MÃ¤nnern ein, die ihr nachgestellt haben.

Ein Mann sei ihr mit dem Auto gefolgt und habe gefragt, ob sie nicht einsteigen wolle, schreibt sie zum Beispiel. Ein weiterer Kommentar lautet: "Mein Name ist nicht 'Baby'."

"Sie dringen vor allen Leuten in meine PrivatsphÃ¤re ein, also dringe ich in ihre ein"

Ein Ã¤lterer Mann habe sie unvermittelt gefragt, ob sie ihn kÃ¼ssen wolle. Ein anderer habe immer wieder gehupt und gesagt, ihr Anblick lÃ¶se "wilde Gedanken" in ihm aus.

Im GesprÃ¤ch mit der "BBC" stellte Jansma klar, sie wolle die MÃ¤nner mit den Fotos nicht bloÃŸstellen. Sie sagte: "Wenn diese MÃ¤nner mich darum bitten sollten, die Fotos von Instagram zu lÃ¶schen, werde ich das tun, denn ich will ihre Leben nicht ruinieren."

Es gehe ihr vielmehr darum, ihnen den Spiegel vorzuhalten. Jansma wÃ¶rtlich: "Sie dringen vor allen Leuten in meine PrivatsphÃ¤re ein, also dringe ich in ihre ein."

TEXT:
Susie Essman was a few minutes late, thanks to the %*#@$ leader of the free world.

â€œAssholeâ€™s in town,â€ she muttered as she sat down. President Donald Trump had returned to New York City to address the United Nations, causing a presidential buildup of traffic between Essmanâ€™s prior engagement and ours on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, just down the block from her apartment.

Essmanâ€™s mouth is famous, perhaps even more so than she is. It is certainly one of the most iconically foul weapons on television. Eighteen years since Essman first agreed to join Larry Davidâ€™s HBO show â€œCurb Your Enthusiasm,â€ it is hard to read certain phrases without hearing her distinctive New York cadence. Four-eyed fuck! Fat piece of shit! Sick fucko asshole! Freak of fucking nature! Car-wash cunt!

HBO â€œWhat is hilarious to me is that I have now become beloved and iconic for telling people to go fuck themselves,â€ Susie Essman said.

Essman and those around her say she shares little in common with the character she plays on television. â€œSheâ€™s not like Susie Greene in real life,â€ said Joy Behar, her best friend of more than three decades. Greene is the justifiably embittered housewife of Hollywood manager Jeff Greene, played by â€œCurbâ€ executive producer Jeff Garlin â€• the kind of woman who tells her perpetually cheating husband that if he so much as utters the word â€œdivorce,â€ she will take him for everything heâ€™s worth and then thumbtack his testicles to the wall. Essman, 62, is kind, quiet and thoughtful â€• a seasoned stand-up comedian, shaped by the New York City clubs of the 1980s and happily married to a man who works far outside the industry.

But as â€œCurb Your Enthusiasmâ€ returned last Sunday for its first season in six years, and its ninth in total, thereâ€™s no question that the character and her creator have one thing in common: Neither is going to let any stupid fuck tell her how to live her life anymore.

Even as a young girl watching â€œI Love Lucy,â€ Essman always gravitated to the Ethel Mertzes of the world, not the Lucy Ricardos.

â€œLucy always pissed me off because it was always like, â€˜Wah, wah, wah â€• Rickyâ€™s going to be mad at me that I bought a hat,â€™ you know?â€ she said as she ate her bacon and scrambled eggs (well-done) last month. â€œGrow some balls.â€

â€œI didnâ€™t feel that way about Ethel,â€ she added. â€œEthel wasnâ€™t beholden to Fred in the same way.â€

Essman had wanted to be an actress ever since she was a child growing up just north of New York City in Westchester County. But in elementary school, Essman realized she wouldnâ€™t be able to live life as a Lucy even if she wanted to. In first grade, the part of Mrs. Claus in a school play went to her best friend. At her sleepaway campâ€™s production of â€œThe Wizard Of Oz,â€ Essman didnâ€™t get the role of Dorothy either. The part went to a supposedly talentless blonde instead, leaving a young Essman with the role of the Wicked Witch of the West. Enraged, she performed the part with an incomparable passion, repeatedly screaming â€œIâ€™m meltingâ€ during her characterâ€™s death scene. The performance earned her a standing ovation. Watching as the crowd cheered, she realized something.

â€œI was never going to be the ingenue,â€ she says now. â€œBecause I was too New York, too Jewish, too whatever. I was always going to be the best friend.â€ But she didnâ€™t care. That night, Essman decided she liked being the Wicked Witch of the West plenty.

Those closest to her were often less than supportive of Essmanâ€™s acting ambitions growing up. Her mother, who taught Russian at Sarah Lawrence College, and her father, an internist, wanted Essman to apply to law school. Her college boyfriend told her that her dream was ridiculous.

â€œI had very little encouragement from anybody,â€ she said.

After graduating SUNY Purchase with a degree in urban studies, Essman spent most of her 20s waitressing in the city, too scared to dive headfirst into acting but not quite able to give up the idea. She took a few classes here and there, but found herself simultaneously bored by them and ridden with performance anxiety. When there were assignments, sheâ€™d skip class altogether. â€œI was so scared to get up and do anything,â€ she said. She met a man, and the two of them entered into an unhealthy relationship. At one point, she even applied to law school like her parents wanted â€• and got in â€• but she couldnâ€™t bring herself to go. Confused as to where her life was headed, she entered a depression. â€œI was just so lost,â€ she said.

In July 1983, a broken Essman entered intensive psychoanalysis at the advice of her therapist. That same month, she got onstage at an open mic at the Mostly Magic comedy club on Carmine Street. She pulled together a couple characters that would get a laugh in her acting classes â€• among them a Jewish mother and a â€œjappyâ€ girl from Long Island â€• and did five minutes. It was a decision that would change her life, even if it didnâ€™t seem like it at the time.

About two months later, she received a call from a man she had met that night named Burt Leavitt. He had opened a club called Comedy U. with a friend in the city, and he wanted Essman to perform, but she was still struggling with depression and suicidal thoughts. â€œI was in a very bad place,â€ she said. â€œI was in the worst place I ever could have been in.â€ Nevertheless, she agreed â€• it might have even helped her to overcome her usual anxiety. â€œ[I]f I hadnâ€™t been in such dire straits â€” suicidal and depressed and feeling like I had no options in life at all â€” I donâ€™t know if I ever would have gotten up on stage,â€ she later wrote in her memoir, What Would Susie Say? Bullsh*t Wisdom About Love, Life and Comedy.

The first time went fine. The second time went great. But the night after, she spiraled and decided to take â€œevery pill in my medicine cabinet from aspirin to Valium to Tums,â€ she later recalled. Quickly, she realized she didnâ€™t want to die. She called her friend and then her father, who told her to make herself vomit.

â€œI did, and the rest is a blur,â€ she wrote.

Essman came out of the experience changed. â€œThere was something about actually having acted on my suicidal thoughts that banished them,â€ she wrote. A few days later, Leavitt called her again and offered her a paying gig on the weekends at the Comedy U. She took it and started working there regularly. After a while, she tried speaking in her own voice, rather than hiding behind characters. She began performing at other clubs.

â€œAfter about three months, I remember feeling like this is what I was meant to do with my life,â€ she said, smiling. â€œAnd I became a comic.â€

YouTube By 1988, Susie Essman was performing as part of HBO stand-up comedy specials.

Over the next half-decade, Essman worked relentlessly to perfect her newly discovered talent. â€œSeven nights a week, many clubs a night,â€ she said. In 1987, she performed over 400 shows. By 1988, she had appeared on an HBO special. By 1989, she had appeared on Johnny Carson. â€œShe was very much well-respected,â€ said Behar.

She stopped caring so much about what other people thought, too. To stand out, she had to. There had been â€œnearly a hundredfold increaseâ€ in full-time comedy clubs since the early 1970s, Rolling Stone wrote in 1988. But there was something a bit different about Essman. With her thick New York accent, she was so distinctly a product of the tri-state, which she played up in her act, joking about her hunky Italian ex-boyfriend from the Bronx and how the gentile bridal showers of Connecticut compared with her own Jewish familyâ€™s more brash get-togethers. She also adopted something of her fatherâ€™s dirty mouth â€• â€œâ€˜Fuckâ€™ every other word,â€ as she described it.

But most notable was the way Essman talked about sex. â€œShe was ahead of her time,â€ said Ilana Glazer, co-creator of Comedy Centralâ€™s â€œBroad City,â€ a blissed-out riff on life at loose ends for two sexually liberated twentysomething women in New York City.

When joking about men, Essman could be simultaneously honest and brutal. Often single and unashamed of it, a Fredless Ethel, she talked about the men who turned her on and the men who turned her off â€• sex every which way. When Oscar-winning actress Sally Field needed a stand-up coach for a 1988 film she starred in called â€œPunchline,â€ she looked through hundreds of tapes before eventually deciding on Essman, saying, â€œ[Essman] commands the audience to be with her and a lot of it comes from her sexuality.â€

Over time, Essman began to create what Glazer described as â€œa space where women can be loud [and] opinionated ... not the standard-narrative white woman.â€

â€œShe was single and fucking people and living that real New York life before â€˜Sex In The City,â€™â€ Glazer added. â€œâ€˜Broad Cityâ€™ is trying to capture some essence of what Susie really lived.â€

It wasnâ€™t always easy being a woman in the New York City comedy scene. â€œThey would never put two women on a show together,â€ Essman said. â€œThey kind of assumed that if you have two women on a show, theyâ€™re both going to be talking about their periods.â€ But she was unwilling to blame any lack of success on her gender. â€œI hate victimhood â€• hate it,â€ she said. â€œI was always just like: â€˜Iâ€™m going to be so good that they canâ€™t deny me. Iâ€™m going to be such a great comedian that they cannot use this against me.â€™ And that was my goal.â€

Marc Janks/HuffPost

Standing there with a microphone in her face and the comedy world in front of her, Essman was ready to show them all. Comedy Central had initially resisted the New York Friars Clubâ€™s suggestion that Essman participate in the televised 1999 roast of comedian Jerry Stiller. â€œIâ€™m not sure why,â€ she later wrote. â€œToo old, too female, too Jewish, too who knows?â€

Essman had joined the exclusive club, famous for its extravagantly vulgar celebrity roasts, a few years before, in 1995. The club was the stuff of legend â€• Frank Sinatra signed Essmanâ€™s admission certificate â€• but it hadnâ€™t allowed women in until 1988, and it hadnâ€™t let women onto the dais during a roast until 1990. Even after those walls were broken down, biases against female comedians remained. â€œThey didnâ€™t think women were funny. Especially if you were relatively attractive. That confused the shit out of them,â€ Essman said.

But she earned the Friars Clubâ€™s respect, enough that it pushed for her to perform against Comedy Centralâ€™s wishes. Eventually, the network relented.

She wanted to prove women could keep up â€• for more reasons than one. By the mid-â€™90s, Essman had started to get a bit fed up. She had been in the comedy scene for over a decade. Many of her friends had headed West for jobs in Los Angeles, but she had been unwilling. â€œI never thought about moving,â€ she said. â€œ[Los Angeles] just doesnâ€™t feel like home to me.â€ The decision cost her. She was in her 40s and still struggling to make a decent living. Sure, she had bit parts here and there, but nothing was sticking.

â€œI was very frustrated because â€• I mean, especially in those days, I was good,â€ she said. â€œIt was like, â€˜OK, how much better do I have to be before I start making some money?â€™â€

Up onstage during the roast, the frustration was transmuted into one of the dirtiest, filthiest, most heinous sets of the night. To start: â€œIâ€™m very hoarse tonight. I have a sore throat. Jerry knows why. I know why. Enough said,â€ she said. She turned to Maury Povich: â€œYou know, Maury, I always wondered why you married Connie Chung. And then I realized: We all know Jews love to eat Chinese. Once a week, right?â€ And on and on.

She was the kind of woman whom she had admired as a child â€• wicked, beholden to no one â€• and she killed. One man took notice. Just before he sat down to watch the Stiller roast, â€œSeinfeldâ€ co-creator Larry David had wrapped a one-hour mockumentary for HBO called â€œLarry David: Curb Your Enthusiasm.â€ He was planning to transform the special into a full-on television show, and he needed someone to play his best friendâ€™s wife. For the part, he needed a woman who could be ferocious and crass, with a mouth that had to be heard to be believed. Watching the roast, he realized what he needed was Susie Essman.

The two had known each other back in the 1980s, when they were both in the stand-up scene. When David called up his old acquaintance and told her about the part, she asked for a script. No script, he said, just rough outlines of scenes. He added that the show would be more or less improvised. Oh, and Essman would only receive union day scale, too. With no contract and no real commitment, she decided to accept the role and see where it went anyway.

Essman and David never really discussed the character of Susie Greene. But Essman knew exactly whom she wanted her to be. In high school, she had marveled at girls who, unlike her, were totally secure in themselves. That was what she wanted to create in Greene â€• an East Coast housewife who never second-guessed her choices, fashion or otherwise.

Essman appeared in a few episodes of Season 1. But Susie Greene didnâ€™t become a fully formed man-killing machine, Essman said, until seven episodes into Season 2. Larry and Jeff have stolen the head of one of her daughterâ€™s dolls, and here is Susie Greene, confronting them on the driveway, snarling, Spaghetti Western music playing in the background. â€œWhereâ€™s the head?â€ she asks, arms folded across her chest. Jeff and Larry are silent, terrified. Susie asks again: â€œI know you took the dollâ€™s head. Where is it?â€

Then once more, with power.

â€œWHEREâ€™S THE FUCKING HEAD?â€

HBO Susie Essman didn't truly make her presence felt on "Curb Your Enthusiasm" until a Season 2 episode entitled â€œThe Doll."

It was a little slice of the Jersey Turnpike, set down in Pacific Palisades. The scene, in an episode entitled â€œThe Doll,â€ would serve as Essmanâ€™s breakout moment, which is probably why she still considers the episode her favorite. â€œItâ€™s the first time you see how deeply feared I am with Jeff and Larry,â€ said Essman.

Over the seasons, she would skewer her â€œfat piece of shitâ€ husband plenty. But her real wrath was saved for Larry. Whether it was because he didnâ€™t want an house tour, got her daughter drunk, ruined a school tour, doubted her respect for wood or didnâ€™t love her shimmering Packers sweater, Essman let that four-eyed fuck have it. The show, in general, revolved around everyone ridiculing Larry into moral oblivion, and no one ridiculed better than Essman.

By Season 3, â€œCurbâ€ fans were regularly stopping Essman in the streets of Manhattan and begging her to rip into them. Women in particular have come to love Susie Greene, Essman has said, going so far as to tell her that Greene is â€œtheir hero.â€

â€œThe thing that people really love about Susie â€¦ is her comfort with her anger, especially women,â€ she said. â€œHer complete comfort with being angry unapologetically, I think, is liberating for women to see.â€

She enjoys the physical process of playing her, too. â€œAfter we do a screaming-shouting scene, I go back to my hotel [and] I feel so relaxed, I fall asleep. I feel like I got a massage, you know?â€ she said.

Marc Janks/HuffPost

In the almost two decades that sheâ€™s been playing Susie Greene, Essman has come to be defined by the role, and in some ways limited, too. â€œIâ€™m definitely pigeonholed and typecast,â€ she said. While many of TVâ€™s most famous male comedians are well known for their stand-up routines, few people know of Essman as a stand-up comedian who woodshedded for two decades before â€œCurb.â€

â€œPeople really have trouble giving credit to women. I mean, they just fucking do,â€ Glazer said. â€œAnd I get it â€• itâ€™s uncomfortable. Itâ€™s not what weâ€™re used to seeing. But Larry David didnâ€™t create Susie Greene. He knew Susie Essman, who perfected herself.â€

Years ago, when Glazer and â€œBroad Cityâ€ co-creator Abbi Jacobson were working on the web series that would become their hit Comedy Central show, they dreamed of having Essman play Glazerâ€™s mother. â€œShe [was] just so Jew-y and ethnic and New York and unapologetic,â€ said Glazer.

But Glazer wasnâ€™t a â€œCurbâ€ diehard. She was a fan of Essman, the stand-up comedian, who had helped inspire Glazer to speak proudly and frankly about sex and a womanâ€™s place in the world. A few years after Season 8 of â€œCurbâ€ wrapped up, the pair finally got their wish when Essman joined the show as Ilanaâ€™s handbag-addicted mother, a casting decision that looked instantly perfect as Glazer and Essman ran around New York City together.

In real life, Essman became something like family to the two comedians. â€œI have the deepest respect for them. I feel like theyâ€™re my little sisters [and] that theyâ€™re my legacy in a certain way,â€ Essman said. â€œThey are the outgrowth of some of the stuff I was doing.â€

Glazer agrees. â€œâ€˜Broad Cityâ€™ would not be covering the content that it is had Susie Essman not been doing the stand-up that she did starting in the â€™80s,â€ Glazer said. â€œShe really feels like our mother â€• who created a world for us.â€

Last spring, Essman got a call from Larry David. After five years, he was seriously thinking about Season 9. Sheâ€™s hopeful it wonâ€™t be the last one. â€œItâ€™s not as though these are the characters that weâ€™re going to grow out of. Itâ€™s not â€˜Baywatch,â€™â€ she said. Since the show first started, Essmanâ€™s life has both changed dramatically and not at all. She still does some stand-up comedy and still lives in and loves New York City. But the once-perpetually single Essman is married, a little older and a bit more removed from the scene. She hasnâ€™t become a star. She still has to work to pay the bills. But sheâ€™s fine with all that, and she doesnâ€™t care what you think about her life or her world anyway.

In a way, sheâ€™s become a bit more like her character â€• secure in herself and her ability to tell everyone else to fuck off.

â€œWhat is hilarious to me is that I have now become beloved and iconic for telling people to go fuck themselves,â€ she said. â€œFor the rest of my life, that will be my legacy.â€

How does she feel about that?

â€œItâ€™s fine. You could be known for worse.â€
TITLE: The Return Of The Greatest %*#@$!^ Mouth On Television

TEXT:
NEW YORK â€• President Donald Trump's administration issued a new rule Friday that allows all employers to opt out of including birth control in their health insurance plans for any moral or religious reason, rolling back the Obama-era requirement that guaranteed contraception coverage at no cost to 62 million women.

Requiring insurance plans to cover birth control imposes a "substantial burden" to the free exercise of religion guaranteed by the U.S. Constitution, and could promote "risky sexual behavior" among adolescents, the administration told reporters Thursday night.

The Affordable Care Act deemed contraception an essential part of women's preventive health care for the first time in history, requiring that it be covered under most insurance plans, along with prenatal care, breast exams and well-woman visits. The birth control mandate compelled for-profit employers to cover the full range of contraceptives, including the pill, the intrauterine device and the Plan B morning-after pill, at no out-of-pocket cost to women, while carving out exemptions for churches and nonprofit religious organizations.

The Trump administration, which is stacked with officials who oppose contraception, will now allow any employer or for-profit company, regardless of whether they are religious, to refuse to include the coverage in their health insurance plans for moral reasons. This could mean that tens of thousands to hundreds of thousands of women in the United States will once again have to pay out of pocket for birth control.

"I think what the Trump administration is trying to do is effectively gut the rule without repealing it, because repealing it would be so unpopular," said Gretchen Borchelt, vice president for reproductive rights and health at the National Women's Law Center. "They're taking contraception coverage away from women without justification."
TITLE: Trump Rolls Back Obama's Birth Control Coverage Rule

SUMMARY:
And they'll do it for one reason: to express their opposition to Adani's proposed Carmichael mine.
The national day of action has been organised by the Stop Adani Movement, in conjunction with grassroots climate action movement 350.org.
Stop Adani organised some polling around the mine, the ethics of which were called into serious question by Four Corners earlier this week, as they have been many times before.
Even among One Nation voters, more people are opposed or strongly opposed than support the mine.
And it is crazy the Turnbull Government is now considering a billion dollar handout to help Adani build it.
TEXT:
This Saturday, Australians will turn out in 45 well-known locations across the country from Bondi to Bells Beach and just about everywhere else. And they'll do it for one reason: to express their opposition to Adani's proposed Carmichael mine.

The national day of action has been organised by the Stop Adani Movement, in conjunction with grassroots climate action movement 350.org. Stop Adani organised some polling around the mine, the ethics of which were called into serious question by Four Corners earlier this week, as they have been many times before.

And it seems that Australians -- who generally have bullshit detectors second to none -- are onto the fact that this mine does not make economic or environmental sense.

The results of the ReachTEL poll are super revealing. Look below and you'll see that virtually all Australians, no matter what their political stripes, oppose the Carmichael mine, construction of which could start within weeks.

Even among One Nation voters, more people are opposed or strongly opposed than support the mine. Opposition is also high among National Party voters, who mostly live in rural electorates and would tend to favour agriculture over mining.

There is also extremely strong and widespread opposition to the $1 billion Federal government loan which has been offered to Adani to build the rail line to the Abbot Point coal terminal, about two hours from the mine.

Two thirds of Australians want the Queensland government to use its power to veto the loan.

Prominent businessman and Australian Conservation Foundation President, Mr Geoff Cousins AO, will speak at the Bondi protest event.

"Adani's new dirty coal mine will damage everything it touches," he said ahead of the day of protest.

"It will pollute where they dig up. It will pollute when they burn the coal. And it'll make the world a more dangerous place by fuelling global warming.

"It is astounding that our elected representatives are bending over backwards to give Adani preferential treatment to help it build a massive dirty coal mine that will threaten our Great Barrier Reef. And it is crazy the Turnbull Government is now considering a billion dollar handout to help Adani build it. The Turnbull Government must stop the loan and not let this mine go ahead."

One thing politicians love better than royalties from huge resources projects is votes. If this new polling is any guide -- not to mention Saturday's widespread protests -- they might just have to start listening.
TITLE: Even One Nation Voters Overwhelmingly Oppose Adani's Carmichael Megamine

SUMMARY:
An animal cruelty investigation in Texas is shedding light on the disturbing conditions that can surround commercial pet breeding facilities.
SPCA of Texas A fan covered with dirt inside the structure that housed 100 dogs and puppies.
SPCA of Texas Puppies inside cages at the facility in Greenville, Texas.
SPCA of Texas An SPCA of Texas worker holds a recently rescued dog.
Animal welfare organizations typically recommend that people adopt pets from animal shelters and rescue groups, instead of buying them from breeders.
TEXT:
An animal cruelty investigation in Texas is shedding light on the disturbing conditions that can surround commercial pet breeding facilities.

The owner of a large-scale dog breeding operation near the city of Greenville agreed Tuesday to relinquish 117 animals â€” 93 adult dogs, 22 puppies and two cats â€” to the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals of Texas, a local animal welfare agency that operates shelters and spay-and-neuter clinics.

Local law enforcement, working in cooperation with the SPCA of Texas, had seized the animals the previous week. Most of the dogs and puppies were living inside a metal structure next to the home, according to a news release from the nonprofit.

Photos show dogs crammed inside small, dirty cages and crates in a room where a fan was thick with dust and debris. Investigators said they could smell dog feces and urine from the road near the building, and inside the scent was so strong it made them gag.

SPCA of Texas A fan covered with dirt inside the structure that housed 100 dogs and puppies.

Some of the dogs came to the organization soaked in urine, while others had medical conditions like eye ulcers or ear infections due to heavily matted fur, said Victoria Albrecht, a spokeswoman for the SPCA of Texas.

Most of the dogs are now doing well.

â€œFor the most part these dogs seem very friendly and enjoy receiving attention and affection,â€ Albrecht told HuffPost in an email.

A Facebook video posted this week showed workers removing matted fur from a male poodle mix, who appeared in good spirits.

â€œEven after everything heâ€™s been through this little guy wouldnâ€™t stop giving our team kisses and all he really wanted was to be held, which we were happy to do for him!â€ the group wrote on Facebook.

Dog breeds represented including Maltipoos, Pomeranians, Shih Tzus and Yorkies, according to Today.

SPCA of Texas Puppies inside cages at the facility in Greenville, Texas.

The owner of the operation, whose name has not been released, is accused of violating state regulations surrounding large-scale breeders, which set standards on space, shelter, ventilation, food and medical care.

Albrecht said the organizationâ€™s animal cruelty investigator told her the puppies were being sold for approximately $700 to $1,200. It was unclear where the puppies were being sold, though it was not out of the home directly, she said.

SPCA of Texas An SPCA of Texas worker holds a recently rescued dog.

Animal welfare organizations typically recommend that people adopt pets from animal shelters and rescue groups, instead of buying them from breeders. However, if someone is set on purchasing a pet from a breeder, there are steps that can help ensure youâ€™re not supporting a puppy mill operation.
TITLE: More Than 100 Dogs Rescued From Cramped, Filthy Cages In Puppy Mill Bust
